revision.text:
[[File:Ljungris July 2013.jpg|thumbnail| 300px|Traditional [[sod roof]] in [[Ljungris]], Sweden ]] [[File:Norðragøta, Faroe Islands (2).JPG|thumb|200px|Traditional [[sod roof]]s can be seen in many places in the [[Faroe Islands]].]] [[File:British Horse Society Head Quarters and Green Roof.jpg|thumbnail| 300px|Green roof at the [[British Horse Society]] headquarters]] [[File:20080708 Chicago City Hall Green Roof.JPG|thumb|200px|Green roof of [[Chicago City Hall]]]]
A '''green roof''' or '''living roof''' is a [[roof]] of a [[building]] that is partially or completely covered with vegetation and a growing medium, planted over a [[Waterproofing#Construction waterproofing|waterproofing membrane]]. It may also include additional layers such as a [[root barrier]] and [[drainage]] and [[irrigation]] systems.<ref name="multiple">Rodriguez Droguett, B. (2011). Sustainability assessment of green infrastructure practices for stormwater management: A comparative emergy analysis (M.S.). Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/900864997/abstract/6E6468B55EF454FPQ/1</ref> [[Container garden]]s on roofs, where plants are maintained in pots, are not generally considered to be true green roofs, although this is debated. Rooftop ponds are another form of green roofs which are used to treat [[greywater]].<ref>Özyavuz, Murat, B. Karakaya, and D. G. Ertin. "The Effects of Green Roofs on Urban Ecosystems." GreenAge Symposium 2015.</ref> Vegetation, soil, drainage layer, roof barrier and irrigation system constitute green roof.<ref>EPA (2017) Green Roofs. U.S. EPA. Available from: http://www.epa.gov/heatisland/strategies/greenroofs.html</ref>
Green roofs serve several purposes for a building, such as [[Absorption of water|absorbing]] [[rainwater]], providing [[Building insulation|insulation]], creating a habitat for wildlife, increasing benevolence<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.greenroof.hrt.msu.edu/benefits/index.html|title=Benefits of Green Roofs|website=www.greenroof.hrt.msu.edu|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref> and decreasing stress of the people around the roof by providing a more aesthetically pleasing landscape, and helping to lower urban air temperatures and mitigate the [[heat island effect]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vandermeulen|first1=Valerie|last2=Verspecht|first2=A.|last3=Vermeire|first3=B.|last4=Van Huylenbroeck|first4=G.|last5=Gellynck|first5=X.|title=The use of economic valuation to create public support for green infrastructure investments in urban areas|journal=Landscape and Urban Planning|date=November 30, 2011|volume=103|issue=2|pages=198–206|doi=10.1016/j.landurbplan.2011.07.010|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169204611002428|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> Green roofs are suitable for retrofit or redevelopment projects as well as new buildings and can be installed on small garages or larger industrial, commercial and municipal buildings.<ref name="multiple" /> They effectively utilize the natural functions of plants to filter water and treat air in urban and suburban landscapes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sftool.gov/explore/green-building/section/76/green-roof/system-overview#green-roof/extensive-green-roofs|title=System Overview : Planted Roof : GSA Sustainable Facilities Tool|website=sftool.gov}}</ref> There are two types of green roof: intensive roofs, which are thicker, with a minimum depth of {{convert|12.8|cm|abbr=on}}, and can support a wider variety of plants but are heavier and require more maintenance, and extensive roofs, which are shallow, ranging in depth from {{convert|2|cm|abbr=on}} to {{convert|12.7|cm|abbr=on}}, lighter than intensive green roofs, and require minimal maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Volder|first=Astrid|author2=Dvorak|title=Event size, substrate water content and vegetation affect storm water retention efficiency of an un-irrigated extensive green roof system in Central Texas|journal=Sustainable Cities and Society|date=February 2014|volume=10|pages=59–64|doi=10.1016/j.scs.2013.05.005|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S221067071300036X|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref>
The term ''green roof'' may also be used to indicate roofs that use some form of green technology, such as a [[cool roof]], a roof with [[solar thermal collector]]s or [[photovoltaic panels]]. Green roofs are also referred to as ''eco-roofs'', ''oikosteges'', ''vegetated roofs'', ''living roofs'', ''greenroofs'' and ''VCP<sub>H</sub><ref name="VCP">{{cite web |url=http://personnel.univ-reunion.fr/ajean/typosite/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824075700/http://personnel.univ-reunion.fr/ajean/typosite/index.html |archivedate=24 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> (Horizontal Vegetated Complex Partitions)''
==Environmental benefits== <!-- Image size is wider than default thumb owing to inclusion of substantial text --> [[File:CalifAcadSciRoof 0820.JPG|thumb|200px|upright|A modern green roof at [[California Academy of Sciences]], constructed for low maintenance by omitting many native plant species in favor of the hardiest varieties<ref>''California'' (magazine of the University of California Alumni Association), Sept/Oct 2008, cover and pp. 52–53</ref>]]
=== Thermal reduction and energy conservation === Green roofs improve and reduce energy consumption.<ref>Li, W. (2013). A scenario planning approach for school green roofs to achieve stormwater management benefits: A case study of Brier’s Mill Run Subwatershed</ref> They can reduce [[HVAC|heating]] by adding [[mass]] and thermal resistance value, also can reduce the heat island by increasing evapotranspiration.<ref>Santamouris, M. (2014). Cooling the cities – A review of reflective and green roof mitigation technologies to fight heat island and improve comfort in urban environments. Solar Energy, 103(Supplement C), 682–703.</ref> A 2005 study by Brad Bass of the [[University of Toronto]] showed that green roofs can also reduce heat loss and energy consumption in winter conditions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.news.utoronto.ca/bin6/051117-1822.asp |title = University of Toronto – News@UofT – Green roofs in winter: Hot design for a cold climate |date=17 November 2005 |accessdate =10 June 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080411230309/http://www.news.utoronto.ca/bin6/051117-1822.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 11 April 2008}}</ref> A modeling study found that adding green roofs to 50 percent of the available surfaces in downtown Toronto would cool the entire city by 0.2 to 1.4 °F (0.1 to 0.8 °C).<ref>Reducing Urban Heat Islands: Compendium of Strategies, Green Roofs. Available from:https://www.epa.gov/heat-islands</ref>
A green roof reduces cooling (by [[evaporative cooling]]) loads on a building by fifty to ninety percent,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roofgreening.ca/living_roofs.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105055802/http://www.roofgreening.ca/living_roofs.php |archivedate=5 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> especially if it is glassed-in so as to act as a [[terrarium]] and [[passive solar building design|passive solar]] heat reservoir.
A concentration of green roofs in an urban area can even reduce the city's average temperatures during the summer, combating the [[urban heat island effect]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2000/essd16mar_1m.htm|title=Here Comes Urban Heat|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515014040/http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2000/essd16mar_1m.htm|archivedate=15 May 2008|deadurl=yes|accessdate=10 June 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Traditional building materials soak up the sun's [[solar radiation|radiation]] and re-emit it as heat, making cities at least {{convert|4|C-change}} hotter than surrounding areas. On Chicago's City Hall, by contrast, which features a green roof, roof temperatures on a hot day are typically {{convert|1.4|–|4.4|C-change}} cooler than they are on traditionally roofed buildings nearby.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/11/1115_021115_GreenRoofs_2.html|title=Plant-Covered Roofs Ease Urban Heat|accessdate=10 June 2008}}</ref> Green roofs are becoming common in Chicago, as well as in Atlanta, Portland, and other United States cities, where their use is encouraged by regulations to combat the urban heat-island effect. Green roofs are a type of [[Low-impact development (UK)|low impact development]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bae.ncsu.edu/stormwater/PublicationFiles/BMPs4LID.pdf|title=Urban Waterways|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719085522/http://www.bae.ncsu.edu/stormwater/PublicationFiles/BMPs4LID.pdf|archivedate=19 July 2006|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the case of Chicago, the city has passed codes offering incentives to builders who put green roofs on their buildings. The Chicago City Hall green roof is one of the earliest and most well-known examples of green roofs in the United States; it was planted as an experiment to determine the effects a green roof would have on the microclimate of the roof. Following this and other studies, it has now been estimated that if all the roofs in a major city were greened, urban temperatures could be reduced by as much as 7 degrees Celsius.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/6002705/site/newsweek/|title=Is that a Garden on Your Roof? - Enterprise The Future of Energy - MSNBC.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070907051136/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6002705/site/newsweek/ <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->|archivedate=7 September 2007|accessdate=10 June 2008}}</ref>
=== Water management === Green roofs can reduce [[stormwater]] runoff<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roofgreening.ca/content/Improved_Final.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706202511/http://www.roofgreening.ca/content/Improved_Final.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> via [[water-wise gardening]] techniques. Green roofs play significant role in retrofitting the [[Low-impact development (U.S. and Canada)|Low Impact Development]] (LID) practices in urban areas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shafique|first=Muhammad|last2=Kim|first2=Reeho|date=2017-06-20|title=Retrofitting the Low Impact Development Practices into Developed Urban areas Including Barriers and Potential Solution|url=https://www.degruyter.com/view/j/geo.2017.9.issue-1/geo-2017-0020/geo-2017-0020.xml?format=INT|journal=Open Geosciences|volume=9|issue=1|pages=240–254|doi=10.1515/geo-2017-0020|issn=2391-5447|via=}}</ref> A study presented at the Green Roofs for Healthy Cities Conference in June 2004, cited by the EPA, found water runoff was reduced by over 75% during rainstorms. See the PDF at <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/heatisland/resources/pdf/GreenRoofsCompendium.pdf|title=Heat Islands - US EPA|first=US|last=EPA, OAR, OAP, CPPD|website=US EPA|date=2014-02-28}}</ref> for more information. Water is stored by the roof's substrate and then taken up by the plants, from which it is returned to the atmosphere through transpiration and evaporation.
Green roofs decrease the total amount of runoff and slow the rate of runoff from the roof. It has been found that they can retain up to 75% of rainwater, gradually releasing it back into the atmosphere via [[condensation]] and [[transpiration]], while retaining pollutants in their soil.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2017-05/documents/reducing_urban_heat_islands_ch_3.pdf|title=Green Roofs – Heat Island Effect|author=U.S. EPA|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> Many green roofs are installed to comply with local regulations and government fees, often regarding [[stormwater]] runoff management.<ref>{{cite book|title=Green Roofs : Ecological Design and Construction|author=Earth Pledge|publisher=Schiffer Pub.|year=2005|location=Atglen, PA}}</ref> In areas with [[combined sewer|combined sewer-stormwater systems]], heavy storms can [[sanitary sewer overflow|overload]] the [[water treatment|wastewater system]] and cause it to flood, dumping raw sewage into the local waterways. Often, phosphorus and nitrogen are in this category of environmentally harmful substances even though they are stimulating to the growth of plant life and agriculture. When these substances are added to a system, it can create mass biological activity since they are considered limiting factors of plant growth and by adding more of them to a system, it allows for more plant growth.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.ars.usda.gov/is/np/Phos&Eutro2/agphoseutro2ed.pdf|title=Agricultural Phosphorus and Eutrophication|last=Sharpley|first=A.N.|date=September 2003}}</ref> Elevation 314, a new development in Washington, D.C. uses green roofs to filter and store some of its storm water on site, avoiding the need for expensive underground sand filters to meet D.C. Department of Health storm-water regulations
=== Ecological benefits === Green roofs create natural [[habitat]] as part of an [[urban wilderness]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roofgreening.ca/content/Habitat_Final.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706202518/http://www.roofgreening.ca/content/Habitat_Final.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Even in high-rise urban settings as tall as 19 stories, it has been found that green roofs can attract beneficial insects, birds, bees and butterflies. A recent list of the bee species recorded from green roofs (worldwide) highlights both the diversity of species, but also the (expected) bias towards small ground-nesting species (Hofmann and Renner, 2017). Rooftop greenery complements wild areas by providing stepping stones for songbirds, migratory birds and other wildlife facing [[habitat destruction|shortages of natural habitat]].
Green roofs also serve as a [[green wall]], filtering [[pollutant]]s and [[carbon dioxide]] out of the air, helping to lower rates of diseases such as asthma.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roofgreening.ca/content/AirQuality_Final.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706202524/http://www.roofgreening.ca/content/AirQuality_Final.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They can also filter pollutants and heavy metals out of rainwater.
=== Carbon sequestration === An additional environmental benefit of greens roofs is the ability to sequester carbon. Carbon is the main component of plant matter and is naturally absorbed by plant tissue. The carbon is stored in the plant tissue and the soil substrate through plant litter and root exudates.<ref name="Rowe 2100–2110">{{Cite journal|last=Rowe|first=D. Bradley|date=2011-08-01|title=Green roofs as a means of pollution abatement|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0269749110004859|journal=Environmental Pollution|series=Selected papers from the conference Urban Environmental Pollution: Overcoming Obstacles to Sustainability and Quality of Life (UEP2010), 20–23 June 2010, Boston, USA|volume=159|issue=8–9|pages=2100–2110|doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2010.10.029|pmid=21074914}}</ref> A study on green roofs in Michigan and Maryland found the above ground biomass and below ground substrate stored on average between 168 g C m<sup>−2</sup> and 107 g C m<sup>−2</sup> . Variations occurred among the different species of plant used. Substrate carbon content averaged 913 g C m<sup>−2</sup> and after the subtraction of the original carbon content the total sequestration was 378 g C m<sup>−2</sup>.<ref name="Getter 7564–7570">{{Cite journal|last=Getter|first=Kristin L.|last2=Rowe|first2=D. Bradley|last3=Robertson|first3=G. Philip|last4=Cregg|first4=Bert M.|last5=Andresen|first5=Jeffrey A.|date=2009-08-25|title=Carbon Sequestration Potential of Extensive Green Roofs|journal=Environmental Science & Technology|language=EN|volume=43|issue=19|pages=7564–7570|doi=10.1021/es901539x}}</ref> The sequestration can be improved by changing plant species, increasing substrate depth, substrate composition, and management practices. In a study done in Michigan above ground sequestration ranged from 64 g C m<sup>−2</sup> to 239 g C m<sup>−2</sup> for S. acre and S album.<ref name="Getter 7564–7570" /> Also, by increasing the substrate depth would allow for more area of carbon storage and diversify the types of plants with greater potential of carbon storage. The direct carbon sequestration techniques and methods can be measured and accounted for. Green roofs also indirectly reduce CO<sub>2</sub> given off by power plants through their ability to insulate buildings.<ref name="Rowe 2100–2110" /> Buildings in the US account for 38% of the total carbon dioxide emissions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usgbc.org/articles/green-building-facts|title=Green Building Facts {{!}} U.S. Green Building Council|website=www.usgbc.org|access-date=2016-02-29}}</ref> A model supported by the U.S. Department of Energy found a 2 percent reduction in electricity consumption and 9-11% reduction in natural gas when implementing green roofs.
=== Other === *Help to insulate a building for sound; the soil helps to block lower frequencies and the plants block higher frequencies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenroofs.org |title=Green Roofs for Healthy Cities |website=Greenroofs.org |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref> *If installed correctly many living roofs can contribute to [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] points *Increase agricultural space *Green roofs not only retain rainwater, but also moderate the temperature of the water and act as natural filters for any of the water that happens to run off.
[[File:ESF-Gateway-Green-Roof-2014.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Green roof planted with [[sand dune ecology|dune plants]] from the shores of Lake Ontario, [[State University of New York College of Environmental Science and Forestry|SUNY-ESF]], Syracuse, NY]]
==Costs and financial benefits== [[File:Tongyang - downtown - apartment complex - CIMG9860.JPG|thumb|[[Roof garden]]s provide residents of an apartment complex in [[Tongyang, Hubei|Tongyang]] Town, [[Tongshan County, Hubei]] with fresh produce]]
A properly designed and installed extensive green-roof system can cost $108–248/m2 ($10–23/ft2) while an intensive green roof costs $355–2368/m2 ($33–220/ft2) however, since most of the materials used to build the green roof can be salvaged it is estimated that the cost of replacing a green roof is generally one third of the initial installation costs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sproul|first1=Julian|last2=Wan|first2=Man Pun|last3=Mandel|first3=Benjamin H.|last4=Rosenfeld|first4=Arthur H.|title=Economic comparison of white, green, and black flat roofs in the United States|journal=Energy and Buildings|date=March 2014|volume=71|pages=20–27|doi=10.1016/j.enbuild.2013.11.058|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378778813007652|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref>
With the initial cost of installing a green roof in mind, there are many financial benefits that accompany green roofing. *Green roofing can extend the lifespan of a roof by over 200% by covering the waterproofing membrane with growing medium and vegetation, this shields the membrane from ultra-violet radiation and physical damage.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Carter|first=Timothy|author2=Keeler|title=Life-cycle cost–benefit analysis of extensive vegetated roof systems|journal=Journal of Environmental Management|date=May 2008|volume=87|issue=3|pages=350–363|doi=10.1016/j.jenvman.2007.01.024|pmid=17368704|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301479707000436|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> Further, Penn State University’s Green Roof Research Center expects the lifespan of a roof to increase by as much as three times after greening the roof.<ref name="hortweb1" /> *It is estimated that the installation of a green roof could increase the real estate value of an average house by about 7%.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bianchini|first=Fabricio|author2=Hewage|title=Probabilistic social cost-benefit analysis for green roofs: A lifecycle approach|journal=Building and Environment|date=December 2012|volume=58|pages=152–162|doi=10.1016/j.buildenv.2012.07.005|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S036013231200193X|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> *Reduction in energy use is an important property of green roofing. By improving the thermal performance of a roof, green roofing allows buildings to better retain their heat during the cooler winter months while reflecting and absorbing solar radiation during the hotter summer months, allowing buildings to remain cooler. A study conducted by Environment Canada found a 26% reduction in summer cooling needs and a 26% reduction in winter heat losses when a green roof is used.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenroofs.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26&Itemid=40 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502015516/http://www.greenroofs.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26&Itemid=40 |archivedate=2 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> With respect to hotter summer weather, green roofing is able to reduce the solar heating of a building by reflecting 27% of solar radiation, absorbing 60% by the vegetation through photosynthesis and evapotranspiration, and absorbing the remaining 13% into the growing medium. Such mitigation of solar radiation has been found to reduce building temperatures by up to 20 °C and reduce energy needs for air-conditioning by 25% to 80%. This reduction in energy required to cool a building in the summer is accompanied by a reduction in energy required to heat a building in the winter, thus reducing the energy requirements of the building year-round which allows the building temperature to be controlled at a lower cost.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Saadatian|first=Omidreza|author2=Sopian, K. |author3=Salleh, E. |author4=Lim, C. H. |author5=Riffat, S. |author6=Saadatian, E. |author7=Toudeshki, A. |author8=Sulaiman, M. Y. |title=A review of energy aspects of green roofs|journal=Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews|date=July 2013|volume=23|pages=155–168|doi=10.1016/j.rser.2013.02.022|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S136403211300124X|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> *Depending on the region in which a green roof is installed, incentives may be available in the form of stormwater tax reduction, grants, or rebates. The regions where these incentives will most likely be found are areas where failing storm water management infrastructure is in place, urban heat island effect has significantly increased the local air temperature, or areas where environmental contaminants in the storm water runoff is of great concern.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Jeffrey A.|author2=Rugh, C. L. |author3=Fernandez, R. T. |author4=Xiao, L. |title=Green Roof Stormwater Retention|journal=Journal of Environmental Quality|date=May 2005|volume=34|issue=3|pages=1036–1044|doi=10.2134/jeq2004.0364|pmid=15888889|url=https://www.agronomy.org/publications/jeq/articles/34/3/1036?highlight=&search-result=1|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> An example of such an incentive is a one-year property tax credit is available in [[New York City]], since 2009, for property owners who green at least 50% of their roof area.<ref name="EL NYC">[http://www.environmentalleader.com/2008/06/29/tax-credits-for-green-rooftops-in-nyc/ 'Tax Credits For Green Rooftops In NYC'], Environmental Leader, 29 June 2008. Retrieved 10 July 2012.</ref>
==Disadvantages== [[File:City University of Hong Kong Hu Fa Kuang Sports Centre roof collapses site on 21st May 2016.jpg|thumb|The addition of a green roof to an existing structure led to this collapse at the [[City University of Hong Kong]].]]
The main disadvantage of green roofs is that the initial cost of installing a green roof can be double that of a normal roof.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Getter|first=Kristin L.|author2=Rowe, D. Bradley|title=The Role of Extensive Green Roofs in Sustainable Development|journal=HortScience|year=2006|volume=41|issue=5|pages=1276–1285}}</ref> Depending on what kind of green roof it is, the maintenance costs could be higher, but some types of green roof have little or no ongoing cost. Some kinds of green roofs also place higher demands on the [[waterproofing]] system of the structure, both because water is retained on the roof and due to the possibility of roots penetrating the waterproof membrane. Another disadvantage is that the wildlife they attract may include [[Pest (organism)|pest]] insects which could easily infiltrate a residential building through open windows.
The additional mass of the soil substrate and retained water places a large strain on the structural support of a building. This makes it unlikely for intensive green roofs to become widely implemented due to a lack of buildings that are able to support such a large amount of added weight as well as the added cost of reinforcing buildings to be able to support such weight.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Currie|first=Beth|author2=Bass, B.|title=Estimates of air pollution mitigation with green plants and green roofs using the UFORE model|journal=Urban Ecosystems|date=December 2008|volume=11|issue=4|pages=409–422|doi=10.1007/s11252-008-0054-y}}</ref> Some types of green roofs do have more demanding structural standards especially in seismic regions of the world. Some existing buildings cannot be retrofitted with certain kinds of green roof because of the weight load of the substrate and vegetation exceeds permitted [[static load]]ing. The weight of a green roof caused the collapse of a large sports hall roof in Hong Kong in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|last2=Cheung|first2=Karen|title=Roof collapses at City University sports centre, three injured|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/05/20/breaking-roof-collapses-at-cityu-at-least-three-injured/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=20 May 2016}}</ref> In the wake of the disaster numerous other green roofs around the territory were removed.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tsang|first1=Emily|title=Chinese University of Hong Kong to remove green roofs, Buildings Department issues new guidelines for immediate safety checks|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/1952707/chinese-university-hong-kong-remove-green-roofs|work=South China Morning Post|date=24 May 2015}}</ref>
Green roofs require significantly more maintenance and maintenance energy compared to a standard roof. Standard maintenance include removing debris, controlling weeds, deadhead trimming, checking moisture levels, and fertilizing.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://columbia-green.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/CGT_Maintenance_July2014.pdf | title = Green Roof Maintenance | last = | first = | date = | website = Columbia-green.com | publisher = | access-date =2017-06-23 }}</ref> The maintenance energy use for green roofs has many variables including: climate, intensity of rainfall, type of building, type of vegetation, and external coatings.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal | last = Saadatian | first = Omidreza | last2 = Sopian | first2 = K. | last3 = Salleh | first3 = E. | last4 = Lim | first4 = C. H. | last5 = Riffat | first5 = Safa | last6 = Saadatian | first6 = Elham | last7 = Toudeshki | first7 = Arash | last8 = Sulaiman | first8 = M. Y. | date = 2013-07-01 | title = A review of energy aspects of green roofs | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S136403211300124X | journal = Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews | volume = 23 | pages = 155–168 | doi = 10.1016/j.rser.2013.02.022 }}</ref> The most significant effect comes from scarce rainfall which will increase the maintenance energy due to the watering required. During a 10-year roof maintenance cycle a house with a green roof requires more retrofit embodied energy than a house with a white roof. The individual components of a green roof have CO<sub>2</sub> implications during the manufacturing process have additional implications compared to a conventional roof.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Bozorg Chenani | first = Sanaz | last2 = Lehvävirta | first2 = Susanna | last3 = Häkkinen | first3 = Tarja | date = 2015-03-01 | title = Life cycle assessment of layers of green roofs | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959652614012773 | journal = Journal of Cleaner Production | volume = 90 | pages = 153–162 | doi = 10.1016/j.jclepro.2014.11.070 }}</ref> The embodied energy for green roof components are {{convert|23.6|kg|0|abbr=on}} CO<sub>2</sub> per square meter of green roof. This value is equivalent to 6448 g C m<sup>−2</sup> which is significantly greater than 378 g C m<sup>−2.</sup> <ref name=":0" />
Both sod roofs and LWA-based (Lightweight Aggregates) roofs have been found to have a negative impact on the quality of their resulting runoff.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Teemusk|first=Alar|last2=Mander|first2=Ülo|date=2011-07-14|title=The Influence of Green Roofs on Runoff Water Quality: A Case Study from Estonia|journal=Water Resources Management|language=en|volume=25|issue=14|pages=3699–3713|doi=10.1007/s11269-011-9877-z|issn=0920-4741}}</ref>
==Types== [[File:Intensive extensive green roofs.png|thumb|right|200px|An intensive and an extensive green roof]] [[File:Torvtak 2.png|thumb|Section of a [[Gudbrandsdal]] type [[sod roof]] with elaborate "turf log"]] Green roofs can be categorized as intensive, semi-intensive, or extensive, depending on the depth of planting medium and the amount of maintenance they need. Extensive green roofs traditionally support 10-25 pounds of vegetation per square foot (50–120 kg/m<sup>2</sup>)<ref>[http://www.eot.state.ma.us/smartgrowth/07toolkit/LID/regional_planning/LID/green_roofs.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703122305/http://www.eot.state.ma.us/smartgrowth/07toolkit/LID/regional_planning/LID/green_roofs.html |date=3 July 2010 }}</ref> while intensive roofs support 80-150 pounds of vegetation per square foot (390–730 kg/m<sup>2</sup>).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raingardennetwork.com/greenroofs.htm |title=Green Roof |publisher=Raingardennetwork.com |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> Traditional [[roof garden]]s, which require a reasonable depth of soil to grow large plants or conventional lawns, are considered intensive because they are labour-intensive, requiring irrigation, feeding, and other maintenance. Intensive roofs are more park-like with easy access and may include anything from kitchen herbs to shrubs and small trees.<ref name="Seattle, 2007">{{cite web |title = City Green Building – Green Roofs |author = Seattle Department of Planning and Development |date = 3 November 2008 |url = http://www.seattle.gov/dpd/greenbuilding/ourprogram/resources/technicalbriefs/dpds_009485.asp#whatis |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080907154958/http://seattle.gov/dpd/GreenBuilding/OurProgram/Resources/TechnicalBriefs/DPDS_009485.asp#whatis |archivedate = 7 September 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Extensive green roofs, by contrast, are designed to be virtually self-sustaining and should require only a minimum of maintenance, perhaps a once-yearly weeding or an application of slow-release fertiliser to boost growth. Extensive roofs are usually only accessed for maintenance.<ref name="Seattle, 2007" /> They can be established on a very thin layer of soil (most use specially formulated composts): even a thin layer of [[Mineral wool|rockwool]] laid directly onto a watertight roof can support a planting of ''[[Sedum]]'' species and [[moss]]es. Some green roof designs incorporate both intensive and extensive elements. To protect the roof, a waterproofing membrane is often used, which is manufactured to remain watertight in extreme conditions including constant dampness, ponding water, high and low alkaline conditions and exposure to plant roots, fungi and bacterial organisms.<ref name="Green (Planted) Roofs">{{cite web |title=Green (Planted) roofs |author=The Vinyl Roofing Division of the Chemical Fabrics & Film Association |date=22 June 2012 |url=http://vinylroofs.org/resources/green-planted-roofs/index.html}}</ref>
Advances in green roof technology have led to the development of new systems that do not fit into the traditional classification of green roof types. Comprehensive green roofs bring the most advantageous qualities of extensive and intensive green roofs together. Comprehensive green roofs support plant varieties typically seen in intensive green roofs at the depth and weight of an extensive green roof system.<ref>{{cite web |title=Comprehensive Green Roofs |author=Omni Ecosystems |date=9 March 2013 |url=http://www.omni-ecosystems.com/green-roof |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209012756/http://www.omni-ecosystems.com/green-roof/ |archivedate=9 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Another important distinction is between pitched green roofs and flat green roofs. Pitched [[sod roof]]s, a traditional feature of many Scandinavian buildings, tend to be of a simpler design than flat green roofs. This is because the pitch of the roof reduces the risk of water penetrating through the roof structure, allowing the use of fewer waterproofing and drainage layers.
==History== [[File:Authentic Viking recreation.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Re-creation of [[Viking]] houses in [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]]]] [[File:Heidal.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Sod roofs on 18th-century farm buildings in [[Heidal]], Norway.]]In ancient times green roofs consisted of cave-like structures or [[sod roof]]s covered with earth and plants commonly used for agriculture, dwelling, and ceremonial purposes. These early shelters provided protection from the elements, good insulation during the winter months, and a cool location in the summer. Unfortunately for modern conveniences, these were neither waterproof nor was there any system to keep out unwanted burrowing wildlife.<ref name=":1">{{cite web | url=http://www.greenrooftechnology.com/history-of-green-roofs | title=History of Green Roof Technology, Green Walls, Living Walls}}</ref>{{disputed-inline|for=trad birchbark underlayer|date=October 2018}}
[[File:MEC's green roof among others.jpg|thumb|200px|left|On the green roof of the [[Mountain Equipment Co-op]] store in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada.]] Modern green roofs, which are made of a system of manufactured layers deliberately placed over roofs to support growing medium and vegetation, are a relatively new phenomenon. However, green roofs or [[sod roof]]s in northern [[Scandinavia]] have been around for centuries. The modern trend started when green roofs were developed in Germany in the 1960s, and has since spread to many countries. Today, it is estimated that about 10% of all German roofs have been “greened”.<ref name="hortweb1">{{cite web |url = http://hortweb.cas.psu.edu/research/greenroofcenter/history.html |title = Penn State Green Roof Research: About Green Roofs |website = Hortweb.cas.psu.edu |accessdate = 10 June 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20020824142025/http://hortweb.cas.psu.edu/research/greenroofcenter/history.html |archivedate = 24 August 2002 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
A number of European Countries have very active associations promoting green roofs, including Germany, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Norway, Italy, Austria, Hungary, Sweden, the UK, and Greece.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efb-greenroof.eu |title=European Federation of Green Roof Associations – EFB |publisher=Efb-greenroof.eu |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> Germany is the first country started to develope green roof systems and marketed on a large scale.<ref name=":1" /> The City of Linz in Austria has been paying developers to install green roofs since 1983, and in Switzerland it has been a federal law since the late 1990s. In the UK, their uptake has been slow, but a number of cities have developed policies to encourage their use, notably London and Sheffield.
Green roofs are also becoming increasingly popular in North America, although they are not as common as in some parts of Europe. Numerous North American cities offer tax incentives to developers who integrate green roofs in their buildings. Toronto and San Francisco legally mandate new buildings to include green roofs <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www1.toronto.ca/wps/portal/contentonly?vgnextoid=83520621f3161410VgnVCM10000071d60f89RCRD&vgnextchannel=3a7a036318061410VgnVCM10000071d60f89RCRD |title=City of Toronto Green Roof Bylaw |publisher=City of Toronto |accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sf-planning.org/san-francisco-better-roofs |title=San Francisco Better Roofs |publisher=City of San Francisco Planning Department |accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref>
Rooftop [[greywater treatment|water purification]] is also being implemented in green roofs. These forms of green roofs are actually [[Waste stabilization pond|treatment ponds]] built into the rooftops. They are built either from a simple substrate (as being done in [[Dongtan, Shanghai|Dongtan]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eukn.org/eukn/themes/Urban_Policy/Urban_environment/Environmental_sustainability/dongtan-eco-city_1348.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016104747/http://www.eukn.org/eukn/themes/Urban_Policy/Urban_environment/Environmental_sustainability/dongtan-eco-city_1348.html |archivedate=16 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>) or with plant-based ponds (as being done by WaterWorks UK Grow System<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwuk.co.uk/grow.htm |title=Water Works UK : Green Roof Water Recycling System (GROW) |website=Wwuk.co.uk |date=2008-02-22 |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref> and Waterzuiveren.be<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waterzuiveren.be/concepten/dakvijvers |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913204124/http://www.waterzuiveren.be/concepten/dakvijvers |archivedate=13 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Plants used include [[calamus (palm)|calamus]], [[Menyanthes trifoliata]], [[Mentha aquatica]], etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toontoelen.be/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=684&Itemid=58 |title=Dakvijvers |website=Toontoelen.be |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref>)
Several studies have been carried out in Germany since the 1970s. Berlin is one of the most important centers of green roof research in Germany. Particularly in the last 10 years, much more research has begun. About ten green roof research centers exist in the US and activities exist in about 40 countries. In a recent study on the impacts of green infrastructure, in particular green roofs in the Greater Manchester area, researchers found that adding green roofs can help keep temperatures down, particularly in urban areas: “adding green roofs to all buildings can have a dramatic effect on maximum surface temperatures, keeping temperatures below the 1961–1990 current form case for all time periods and emissions scenarios. Roof greening makes the biggest difference…where the building proportion is high and the evaporative fraction is low. Thus, the largest difference was made in the town centers.”<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gill | first1 = S.E. | last2 = Handley | first2 = J.F. | last3 = Ennos | first3 = A.R. | last4 = Pauleit | first4 = S. | title = Adapting Cities for climate Change: The Role of the Green Infrastructure | url = | journal = Built Environment | volume = 33 | issue = 1| pages = 122–123 | doi=10.2148/benv.33.1.115| year = 2007 }}</ref>
==Brown roofs== Industrial [[brownfield]] sites can be valuable ecosystems, supporting rare species of plants, animals and invertebrates. Increasingly in demand for redevelopment, these habitats are under threat. "Brown roofs", also known as "biodiverse roofs",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brownroofs.co.uk/brown-roof-biodiversity.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017120946/http://www.brownroofs.co.uk/brown-roof-biodiversity.php |archivedate=17 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> can partly mitigate this loss of habitat by covering the flat roofs of new developments with a layer of locally sourced material. Construction techniques for brown roofs are typically similar to those used to create flat green roofs, the main difference being the choice of growing medium (usually locally sourced rubble, gravel, soil, etc...) to meet a specific biodiversity objective.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://greenroofs.org/grtok/materials_browse.php?id=59&what=view |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319200626/http://www.greenroofs.org/grtok/materials_browse.php?id=59&what=view |archivedate=19 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In Switzerland, it is common to use alluvial gravels from the foundations; in London, a mix of brick rubble and some concrete has been used. The original idea was to allow the roofs to self-colonise with plants, but they are sometimes seeded to increase their biodiversity potential in the short term. Such practices are derided by purists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brownroofs.co.uk/brown-roof-habitats.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102070717/http://www.brownroofs.co.uk/brown-roof-habitats.php |archivedate=2 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The roofs are colonised by spiders and insects (many of which are becoming extremely rare in the UK as such sites are developed) and provide a feeding site for insectivorous birds. [[Laban Dance Centre|Laban]], a centre for contemporary dance in London, has a brown roof specifically designed to encourage the nationally rare [[black redstart]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livingroofs.org/livingpages/caselaban.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705085128/http://www.livingroofs.org/livingpages/caselaban.html |archivedate=5 July 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A green roof, 160m above ground level, and claimed to be the highest in the UK and Europe "and probably in the world" to act as nature reserve, is on the Barclays Bank HQ in [[Canary Wharf]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2005/aug/12/conservationandendangeredspecies.uknews | title = Wildlife flourishes 32 floors above the Thames | publisher = The Guardian}}</ref> Designed combining the principles of green and brown roofs, it is already home to a range of rare invertebrates.
== ASLA Award Green Roof Projects == 2017 Award: Seeding Green Roofs for Greater Biodiversity and Lower Costs, Lincoln, NE, USA. ''Richard Sutton''
2013 Award: Green Roof Innovation Testing (GRIT) Laboratory, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. ''John H. Daniels'', Brooklyn Botanic Garden Visitors Center, Brooklyn. ''HMWhite'', and NYC Parks Green Roof: A Living Laboratory for Innovative Green Roof Design, New York, NY. ''NYC Parks''
2012 Award: Lafayette Greens: Urban Agriculture, Urban Fabric, Urban Sustainability, Detroit. ''Kenneth Weikal Landscape Architecture'']
2011 Award: Manassas Park Elementary School Landscape, Manassas Park, VA. Siteworks]
2009 Award: California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco, CA. ''SWA Group'', Changi Airport Terminal 3 Interior Landscape, Singapore. ''Tierra Design (S) Pte Ltd'', Corporate Headquarters, San Francisco, CA. ''OLIN'', Macallen Building, South Boston, MA. ''Landworks Studio, Inc.'', and Museo del Acero Horno3, Monterrey, Mexico. ''Surfacedesign Inc.+ Harari arquitectos''
2008 Award: Gannett/USA Today Headquarters, McLean, Virginia. Michael Vergason Landscape Architects, Ltd.
2007 Award: Washington Mutual Center Roof Garden, Seattle, Washington. Phillips Farevaag Smallenberg
2002 Award: Chicago City Hall Green Roof, Chicago, Illinois. David Yocca
==Examples by country== ===Australia=== Green roofs have been increasing in popularity in Australia over the past 10 years. Some of the early examples include the Freshwater Place residential tower in Melbourne (2002) with its Level 10 rooftop Half Acre Garden, CH2 building housing the Melbourne City Council (2006) – Australia’s first 6-star Green Star Design commercial office building as certified by the [[Green Building Council of Australia]], and Condor Tower (2005) with a 75-square-metre lawn on the 4th floor.
In 2010, the largest Australian green roof project was announced. The Victorian Desalination Project <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aquasure.com.au|title=Home|website=www.aquasure.com.au}}</ref> will have a “living tapestry” of 98,000 Australian indigenous plants over a roof area spanning more than 26,000 square metres. The roof will form part of the desalination plant’s sophisticated roof system, designed to blend the building into the landscape, and provide acoustic protection, corrosion resistance, thermal control, and reduced maintenance. The green roof was designed by ASPECT Studios, ARM / pecvkvonhartel architecture, and will be installed by Fytogreen Australia.
Since 2008, City Councils and influential business groups in Australia have become active promoting the benefits of green roofs. “The Blueprint to Green Roof Melbourne” is one program being run by the Committee for Melbourne.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.growingup.org.au/|title=Best Remodeling Ideas To Increase Your Home's Value -|website=Best Remodeling Ideas To Increase Your Home’s Value}}</ref>
In June 2014 ecological artist Lloyd Godman, with Stuart Jones and Grant Harris in a ground breaking experiment installed Tillandsia plants at level 92, 91, 65 and 56 on Eureka Tower. The air plants, are extremely light, grow with no soil or watering system and have survived for nearly a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/extreme-gardening-on-the-92nd-floor-of-the-eureka-tower-20150323-1m45sm.html|title=Extreme gardening on the 92nd floor of the Eureka Tower|first=Aisha|last=Dow|date=23 March 2015|publisher=The Age}}</ref>
===Canada=== [[File:Wheatfield in Ottawa.jpg|right|thumb|The green roof on top of the [[Canadian War Museum]] in [[Ottawa]] looks like a wheatfield, with the towers of [[Parliament Hill|Canada's Parliament]] visible in the distance]] The city of [[Toronto]] approved a by-law in May 2009<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2009/05/toronto-green-roofs-law-passed.php |title=Toronto Makes Green Roofs the Law, Approves Controversial Bike Lanes }}</ref> mandating green roofs on residential and industrial buildings. There is criticism from [[Steven W. Peck|Green Roofs for Healthy Cities]] that the new laws are not stringent enough, since they will only apply to residential building that are a minimum of six stories high. By 31 January 2011, industrial buildings were required to render 10% or 2,000 m<sup>2</sup> of their roofs green.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/council-approves-stringent-green-roof-rules/article1154619/ |title=Council approves stringent green-roof rules |work=Globe and Mail |location=Toronto |date=23 August 2012 }}</ref> [[Toronto City Hall]]'s Podium roof was renovated to include a 32,000 square foot rooftop garden, the largest publicly accessible roof in the city. The green roof was opened to the public in June 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.toronto.ca/nps/revitalization/greenpodiumroof/ |title=Toronto City Hall's Podium Green Roof |location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada |work=City of Toronto |date=27 June 2013 }}</ref> Many green roofs in Canada also use sustainable [[Rainwater harvesting in Canada|Rainwater harvesting]] practices.
In 2008, the [[Vancouver Convention Centre]] installed a six-acre living roof of indigenous plants and grasses on its West building, making it the largest green roof in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenroofs.com/projects/pview.php?id=545 |title=Projects - Vancouver Convention Centre Expansion Project |website=Greenroofs.com |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref> The new [[Canadian War Museum]] in [[Ottawa]], opened in 2005, also features a grass-covered roof.
During the renovation of the [[Hamilton City Hall]] in [[Hamilton, Ontario]] that spanned from 2007 to 2010, many efforts were taken to enhance the environmentally friendly nature of the structure, which included the addition of a grass-covered roof.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ryan McGreal |url=http://raisethehammer.org/article/1092/city_hall_reno_photo_tour:_part_2 |title=City Hall Reno Photo Tour: Part 2 |publisher=Raise the Hammer |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref>
[[Simon Fraser University]]'s [[Burnaby]] campus contains a substantial number of green roofs.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.burnaby.ca/City-Services/Planning/Environmental-Planning/Green-Development.html?PageMode=Print | title=Green Development}}</ref>
===Costa Rica=== Living green roofs have been built and grown at Saint Michael's Sustainable Community since 2012. Native plants, mostly flowers chosen for the environment, maximum shade and mass provide a colorful and functional living roof. The community has the largest number of green roofs in the country.
===Egypt=== In [[Egypt]], soil-less agriculture is used to grow plants on the roofs of buildings. No soil is placed directly on the roof itself, thus eliminating the need for an insulating layer; instead, plants are grown on wooden tables. Vegetables and fruit are the most popular candidates, providing a fresh, healthy source of food that is free from pesticides.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/745/en2.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Environment | May your roof be green |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=8 June 2005 |accessdate=25 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120703190639/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/745/en2.htm |archivedate=3 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A more advanced method, ([[aquaponics]]), being used experimentally in Egypt, is farming fish next to plants in a closed cycle. This allows the plants to benefit from the ammonia excreted by the fish, helping the plants to grow better and at the same time eliminating the need for changing the water for the fish, because the plants help to keep it clean by absorbing the ammonia. The fish also get some nutrients from the roots of the plants.
===Finland=== In Finland, green roofs are still scarce. Some experimental green roofs have been built in big cities. However, the capital city of Helsinki has published guidelines for enhancing the building of green roofs in the city. There is on-going research on the topic as the conditions in the southern Europe are very different from those in the north and knowledge acquired there can't be directly applied to colder climates. The fifth dimension - [https://www.researchgate.net/project/Fifth-Dimension-Green-Roofs-and-Walls-in-Urban-Areas-research-program Green roofs and walls in urban areas -research program] aims to produce high-level scientific and broadly applicable knowledge on optimal green roof and -wall solutions in Finland.
===France=== [[File:Green Roof at Vendée Historial, les Lucs.jpg|thumb|200px|Green roof planted with native species at L'Historial de la Vendée, a new museum in western France]] In France, an {{convert|8000|m2|sqft}} extensive, cable-supported green roof has been created on the International School in Lyon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenroofs.com/chic_sustainability.htm |title=Chic Sustainability |publisher=Greenroofs.com |date=14 March 2006 |accessdate=25 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503071548/http://www.greenroofs.com/chic_sustainability.htm |archivedate=3 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Another huge green roof of roughly {{convert|8000|m2|sqft}} has been incorporated into the new museum [[L'Historial de la Vendée]] which opened in June 2006 at [[Les Lucs-sur-Boulogne]].
===Germany=== Long-held green roof traditions started in the early industrialization period more than 100 years ago exist in Germany. In the 1970s, green roof technology was elevated to the next level. Serious storm-water issues made cities think about innovative solutions, preferably with living plants. Modern green roof technology with high performance, lightweight materials were utilized to grow hardy vegetation even on roofs that can hardly support any additional load. In the 1980s modern green roof technology was common knowledge in Germany while it was practically unknown in any other country in the world. In Stuttgart, with one of the most innovative Department of Parks and Recreation and with the worlds oldest horticultural Universities, modern green roof technology was perfected and implemented on a large scale.
With the first green roof industry boom in Germany there were quality issues recorded. The FLL formed a committee that is focused on modern green roof technology. FLL stands for Forschungsgesellschaft Landschaftsentwicklung Landschaftsbau e.V. (FLL)or in English: The German Landscape Research, Development and Construction Society. The FLL is an independent non-profit organization. It was founded in 1975 by eight professional organizations for “the improvement of environmental conditions through the advancement and dissemination of plant research and its planned applications”. The FLL green roof working group is only one of 40 committees which have published a long list of guidelines and labor instructions. Some of these guidelines also available in English including the German FLL-Guideline for the Planning, Execution and Upkeep of Green-Roof Sites. The results of the research and synthesis done by FLL members are constantly updated and promulgated utilizing the same principles which govern the compilation of DIN standards and are published as either guiding principles or labor instructions.
The current Green Roof Guideline was published in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenrooftechnology.com/_literature_98993/Introduction_to_the_German_FLL_-_Guideline_for_Green_Roofs_2011 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304041742/http://www.greenrooftechnology.com/_literature_98993/Introduction_to_the_German_FLL_-_Guideline_for_Green_Roofs_2011 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Today most elements of the German FLL are part of standards and guidelines around the world (FM Global, ASTM, NRCA, SPRI etc.).
Fachvereinigung Bauwerksbegrünung (FBB) was founded in 1990 as the second green roof association after DDV (Deutscher Dachgaertner Verband) in 1985. FBB was founded as an open forum for manufacturers and planners, merchants and operators in 1990. The organization was born from the then-visionary idea of understanding the relationship between nature and constructions not as oppositional, but as an opportunity. Both the green roofing and conventional roofing industries are equally represented. The FBB has developed to become an innovative lobbying group with a strong market presence, internationally known through its cooperation with other European associations. Today, approximately 100 member companies use the multifaceted services offered by FBB, which offers a greater degree of market expertise and competitiveness. "Kompetenz im Markt".
Today, about 10,000,000m<sup>2</sup> (or 100,000,000 square feet) of new green roofs are being constructed each year. According latest studies about ¾ of these are extensive; the last ¼ are roof gardens. The cities with the most green roofs in Germany are Berlin and [[Stuttgart]]. Surveys about the status of regulation are done by the FBB. Nearly one third of all German cities have regulations to support green-roof and rain-water technology. Green-roof research institutions are located in several cities as including [[Hannover]], Berlin, [[Geisenheim]] and [[Neubrandenburg]].
Germany is the country with the most green roofs in the world and it is the country with the most advanced knowledge in modern green roof technology. Green roofs in Germany are part of the 2 –3 years apprentice educations system of landscaping professionals. Since green roof are common knowledge and common sense it is interesting to take a look at the [[:de:Dachbegrünung|German Wikipedia page for green roofs]] – there is no need to describe projects, case studies or related research. The green roof technology was implemented before the internet age.
===Greece=== [[File:The Treasury - Syntagma.jpg|thumb|200px|The ''oikostegi'', a green roof on the Treasury building in Athens]] The Greek Ministry of Finance has now installed a green roof on the Treasury in Constitution Square in Athens.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mnec.gr/el/press_office/DeltiaTypou/articles/article0933.html |title=Διαδικτυακή Πύλη Υπουργείου Οικονομικών – Κεντρική Σελίδα |publisher=Mnec.gr |date=20 April 2012 |accessdate=25 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418212542/http://www.mnec.gr/el/press_office/DeltiaTypou/articles/article0933.html |archivedate=18 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The so-called "oikostegi" (Greek – ''oiko'', pronounced ''eeko'', meaning building-ecological, and ''stegi'', pronounced ''staygee'', meaning roof-abode-shelter) was inaugurated in September, 2008. Studies of the thermodynamics of the roof in September 2008 concluded that the thermal performance of the building was significantly affected by the installation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mech.ntua.gr/gr/staff/DEP/rogdakis_gr |title=Σχολή Μηχανολόγων Μηχανικών Ε.Μ.Π. – Μέλος ΔΕΠ |publisher=Mech.ntua.gr |accessdate=25 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502231758/http://www.mech.ntua.gr/gr/staff/DEP/rogdakis_gr |archivedate=2 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In further studies, in August 2009, energy savings of 50% were observed for air conditioning in the floor directly below the installation. The ten-floor building has a total floor space of 1.4 hectares. The oikostegi covers 650 m<sup>2</sup>, equalling 52% of the roof space and 8% of the total floor space. Despite this, energy savings totalling €5,630 per annum were recorded, which translates to a 9% saving in air conditioning and a 4% saving in heating bills for the whole building.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oikosteges.gr/index.php/greenroofs/research |title=Μελέτες |publisher=Oikosteges.gr |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> An additional observation and conclusion of the study was that the thermodynamic performance of the oikostegi had improved as biomass was added over the 12 months between the first and second study. This suggests that further improvements will be observed as the biomass increases still further. The study also stated that while measurements were being made by thermal cameras, a plethora of beneficial insects were observed on the roof, such as butterflies, honey bees and ladybirds. Obviously this was not the case before installation. Finally, the study suggested that both the micro-climate and biodiversity of Constitution Square, in Athens, Greece had been improved by the oikostegi.
===Iceland=== [[File:Church at Hof.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Sod roof Church at Hof, Iceland]] [[Sod roof]]s are frequently found on traditional farmhouses and farm buildings in [[Iceland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenroofs.com/Greenroofs101/history.htm |title=Greenroofs101: History |publisher=Greenroofs.com |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref>
===Switzerland=== Switzerland has one of Europe's oldest green roofs, created in 1914 at the Moos lake water-treatment plant, [[Wollishofen]], [[Zürich]]. Its filter tanks have {{convert|30000|m2|sqft|}} of flat concrete roofs. To keep the interior cool and prevent bacterial growth in the filtration beds, a drainage layer of gravel and a 15-cm (6-in) layer of soil was spread over the roofs, which had been waterproofed with [[asphalt]]. A meadow developed from seeds already present in the soil; it is now a haven for many plant species, some of which are now otherwise extinct in the district, most notably 6,000 ''Orchis morio'' ([[green-winged orchid]]). More recent Swiss examples can be found at Klinikum 1 and Klinikum 2, the [[Cantons of Switzerland|Cantonal]] Hospitals of [[Basel]], and the [[Sihlpost]] platform at Zürich's main railway station.
===Sweden=== What is claimed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenroof.se/?pid=38&sub=20 |title=Green Roof – Augustenborg's Botanical Roof Garden – History |publisher=Greenroof.se |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> to be the world's first green roof [[botanical garden]] was set up in [[Augustenborg, Malmö|Augustenborg]], [[Malmö]] in May 1999. The International Green Roof Institute (IGRI) opened to the public in April 2001 as a research station and educational facility. (It has since been renamed the Scandinavian Green Roof Institute (SGRI), in view of the increasing number of similar organisations around the world.) Green roofs are well-established in Malmö: the Augustenborg housing development near the SGRI botanical garden incorporates green roofs and extensive landscaping of streams, ponds, and soak-ways between the buildings to deal with storm water run-off.
The new [[Bo01]] urban residential development (in the [[Västra Hamnen]] (Western Harbour) close to the foot of the [[Turning Torso]] office and apartment block, designed by [[Santiago Calatrava]]) is built on the site of old shipyards and industrial areas, and incorporates many green roofs.
In 2012, the shopping mall [[Emporia (shopping mall)|Emporia]] with its 27,000 square metre roof garden, was opened. The size of the roof garden is approximately equivalent to 4 soccer fields, which makes it one of the biggest green roof parks in Europe that is accessible to the public.
===United Kingdom=== [[File:Sky Garden Kanes Foods Green Roof.JPG|thumb|The Sky Garden Wildflower Roof topping the Kanes Salad Factory, Evesham.]] In 2003 English Nature concluded that 'in the UK policy makers have largely ignored green roofs'.<ref>Grant, G., Engleback, L., and Nicholson, B., ''Green Roofs: their existing status and potential for conserving biodiversity in urban areas [Report No. 498]'', Publisher: English Nature Reports (2003)</ref> However, British examples can be found with increasing frequency. The [[Kensington Roof Gardens]] are a notable early roof garden which was built above the former [[Derry & Toms]] department store in [[Kensington]], London in 1938.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londongardensonline.org.uk/gardens-online-record.asp?ID=KAC055 |title=London Gardens Online |publisher=London Gardens Online |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> More recent examples can be found at the [[University of Nottingham]] [[Jubilee Campus]], and in London at Sainsbury's Millennium Store in Greenwich, the [[Horniman Museum]] and at [[Canary Wharf]]. The Ethelred Estate, close to the River [[Thames]] in central London, is the British capital's largest roof-greening project to date. [[Toxteth]] in Liverpool is also a candidate for a major roof-greening project.
In the United Kingdom, intensive green roofs are sometimes used in built-up city areas where residents and workers often do not have access to gardens or local parks. Extensive green roofs are sometimes used to blend buildings into rural surroundings, for example by [[Rolls-Royce Motor Cars]], who has one of the biggest green roofs in Europe (covering more than 32,000 m<sup>2</sup> on their factory at Goodwood, West Sussex.<ref>[http://www.rolls-roycemotorcars.com/the-company/environmental/#LivingRoof ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103075110/http://www.rolls-roycemotorcars.com/the-company/environmental/ |date=3 January 2014 }}</ref>
The University of Sheffield has created a Green Roof Centre of Excellence and conducted research, particularly in a UK context, into green roofs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegreenroofcentre.co.uk/about_us |title=About TGRC |publisher=The Green Roof Centre |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> Dr Nigel Dunnett of Sheffield University published a UK-centric book about green roofing in 2004 (updated 2008).<ref>Dunnett, N., Kingsbury, N., ''Planting Green Roofs and Living Walls'', Publisher: Timber Press (2004)</ref>
[[Fort Dunlop]] has the largest green roof in the UK since its redevelopment between 2004 and 2006.
The UK also boasts one of the most innovative food preparation facilities in Europe, the Kanes salad factory in [[Evesham]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fstoppress.com/articles/wild-flower-roof/|title=F Stop Press - Specialists in News and PR in the Midlands|website=www.fstoppress.com|accessdate=23 June 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304082902/http://www.fstoppress.com/articles/wild-flower-roof/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It is topped with a wildflower roof featuring nearly 90 species of wildflower and natural grasses. The seed mix was prepared in consultation with leading ecologists to try and minimise the impact on the local environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kanesfoods.co.uk/sustainability-home/eco-factory/|title=Eco Factory « Kanes Foods|website=kanesfoods.co.uk}}</ref> The pre grown wildflower blanket sits on top of a standing seam roof and is combined with solar panels to create an eco friendly finish to the entire factory.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hereford-worcester-18724335|title=Worcestershire garden roof salad factory opens|date=5 July 2012|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref> The development also won the 2013 National Federation of Roofing Contractors Sustainable Roof Award for Green Roofing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sky-garden.co.uk/gallery/kanes.php|title=Kanes Foods Wildflower Blanket Green Roof - Gallery - Sky Garden|website=www.sky-garden.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfrc.co.uk/roofing-awards-2013|title=The National Federation of Roofing Contractors|website=The National Federation of Roofing Contractors}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:Green City.jpg|thumb|200px|An intensive roof garden in [[Manhattan]]]] [[File:CaliforniaAcademyofSciences.jpg|thumb|200px|The new [[California Academy of Sciences]] building in San Francisco's [[Golden Gate Park]] has a green roof that provides {{convert|2.5|acre|m2}} of native vegetation designed as a habitat for indigenous species, including the threatened [[Bay checkerspot butterfly]]. According to the Academy's fact sheet on the building,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.calacademy.org/geninfo/newsroom/releases/2005/Green_building_facts.html|title = California Academy of Sciences – Newsroom|accessdate = 10 June 2008|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080403122805/http://www.calacademy.org/geninfo/newsroom/releases/2005/Green_building_facts.html|archivedate = 3 April 2008|df = dmy-all}}</ref> the building consumes 30–35% less energy than required by code.]] One of the largest expanses of extensive green roof is to be found in the US, at [[Ford Motor Company]]'s [[River Rouge Plant]], [[Dearborn, Michigan|Dearborn]], Michigan, where {{convert|42000|m2|sqft|}} of assembly plant roofs are covered with [[sedum]] and other plants, designed by [[William McDonough]]; the $18 million assembly avoids the need of what otherwise would be $50 million worth of mechanical treatment facilities on site. Built over Millennium Park Garage, Chicago's {{convert|24.5|acre|m2|adj=on}} [[Millennium Park]] is considered one of the largest intensive green roofs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nelson |first=Bryn |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/24056306/greenroofspoppingupinbigcities |title=Green roofs popping up in big cities - Business - Going Green |publisher=MSNBC |date=15 April 2008 |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> Other well-known American examples include Chicago’s City Hall and the former Gap headquarters, now the headquarters of YouTube, in San Bruno, CA. The U.S. military has two major green roofs in the [[Washington metropolitan area|Washington, D.C. area]]: the [[United States Coast Guard|U.S. Coast Guard]] headquarters ({{convert|550000|sqft|m2|}}) and [[the Pentagon]] ({{convert|180000|sqft|m2|}}).<!--Recently, the [[American Society of Landscape Architects]] retrofitted their existing headquarters building in Washington, D.C. with a green roof designed by landscape architect [[Michael Van Valkenburgh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asla.org/greenroof|title=ASLA Green Roof Demonstration Project}}</ref>
Another example of a green roof in the United States is the Ballard Library in Seattle. This green roof has over 18,000 plants to help with insulation and reduce runoff. The plants used on the roof include ''[[Achillea tomentosa]]'' (woolly yarrow), ''[[Armeria maritima]]'' (sea pink, sea thrift), ''[[Carex inops]] pensylvanica'' (long-stoloned sedge), ''[[Eriophyllum lanatum]]'' (Oregon sunshine), ''[[Festuca rubra]]'' (red creeping fescue), ''[[Festuca idahoensis]]'' (Idaho fescue), ''[[Phlox subulata]]'' (creeping phlox), ''[[Saxifraga caespitosa]]'' (tufted saxifrage), ''[[Sedum oreganum]]'' (Oregon stonecrop), ''[[Sedum album]]'' (white stonecrop), ''[[Sedum spurium]]'' (two-row stonecrop), ''[[Sisyrinchium idahoense]]'' (blue-eyed grass), ''[[Thymus serpyllum]]'' (wild thyme), ''[[Triteleia hyacinthina]]'' (fool's onion). -->
An early green-roofed building (completed in 1971) is the {{convert|358000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} Weyerhaeuser Corporate Headquarters building in Federal Way, Washington. Its 5-story office roof system comprises a series of stepped terraces covered in greenery. From the air, the building blends into the landscape.
The largest green roof in New York City was installed in midtown [[Manhattan]] atop the [[United States Postal Service]]'s Morgan Processing and Distribution Center. Construction on the {{convert|109000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} project began in September 2008, and was finished and dedicated in July 2009. Covered in native vegetation and having an expected lifetime of fifty years, this green roof will not only save the USPS approximately $30,000 a year in heating and cooling costs, but will also significantly reduce the amount of storm water contaminants entering the municipal water system.<ref>{{cite web |title = USPS News Release: U.S. Postal Service Opens First Green Roof |date = 22 July 2009 |url = http://www.usps.com/communications/newsroom/2009/pr09_063.htm |accessdate = 11 February 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101231222639/http://www.usps.com/communications/newsroom/2009/pr09_063.htm |archivedate = 31 December 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.usps.com/communications/newsroom/greennews/pdf/greenkit_5.pdf | format=PDF | title=Green Roof: Morgan Processing and Distribution Center (P&DC) |accessdate=2014-03-03 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140801200244/http://www.capitolroofinginc.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/greenkit-5.pdf |archivedate= 1 August 2014}}</ref> <!-- Atop the [[Museum of Modern Art]] is a modern sculptural garden spanning over 16,750 square feet (7,500 + 9,250). This rooftop is physically inaccessible to the public but has some of the most visible rooftop space in New York. [[Ken Smith (architect)|Ken Smith]] designed MoMA rooftop as a Landscape Architect by using 185 plastic rocks, 560 artificial boxwoods, 300 pounds of clear crushed glass, 4 tons of recycled rubber mulch. His design was awarded the [[American Society of Landscape Architecture]] for design in 2009. --> [[File:20080708 Chicago City Hall Green Roof.JPG|thumb|300px|Chicago City Hall Roof Garden]] In 2001, atop [[Chicago City Hall]], the {{convert|38,800|sqft|adj=on}} roof gardens were completed, serving as a pilot project to assess the impact green roofs would have on the [[heat island]] effect in urban areas, rainwater runoff, and the effectiveness of differing types of green roofs and plant species for Chicago's climate. Although the rooftop is not normally accessible to the public, it is visually accessible from 33 taller buildings in the area. The garden consists of 20,000 plants of more than 150 species, including shrubs, vines and two trees. The green roof design team was headed by the Chicago area firm Conservation Design Forum in conjunction with noted "green" architect [[William McDonough]]. With an abundance of flowering plants on the rooftop, beekeepers harvest approximately {{convert|200|lb|kg}} of honey each year from hives installed on the rooftop. Tours of the green roof are by special arrangement only. Chicago City Hall Green Roof won merit design award of the [[American Society of Landscape Architecture]] (ASLA) competition in 2002.
The {{cvt|14,000|sqft|m2}} of outdoor space on the seventh floor of [[Zeckendorf Towers]], formerly an undistinguished rooftop filled with potted plants, make up the largest residential green roof in New York.<ref name="zeckendorftowers" /><ref>[http://www.dnainfo.com/20101116/murray-hill-gramercy/union-squares-zeckendorf-towers-unveil-citys-largest-green-roof Zeckendorf Towers Unveils City's Largest Green Roof] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120014828/http://www.dnainfo.com/20101116/murray-hill-gramercy/union-squares-zeckendorf-towers-unveil-citys-largest-green-roof |date=20 January 2011 }}, DNAinfo, 16 November 2010.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/26/realestate/26posting.html A New Roof That Works for a Living], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 23 December 2010.</ref> The roof was transformed in 2010 as part of Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]]'s NYC Green Infrastructure campaign, and supposedly serves to capture some of the rain that falls on it rather than letting it run off and contribute to flooding in the adjacent [[14th Street – Union Square (New York City Subway)|Union Square subway station]].<ref name="zeckendorftowers">[http://zeckendorftowers.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/ZT-Rooftop.pdf One Union Square East Opens City's Largest Residential Green Roof], Zeckendorf Towers press release of 15 November 2010.</ref>
Some cost can also be attributed to maintenance. Extensive green roofs have low maintenance requirements but they are generally not maintenance free. German research has quantified the need to remove unwanted seedlings to approximately 6 seconds/m<sup>2</sup>/year.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Deutscher Gartenbau |author=Kolb, W. and T. Schwarz |year=2002 |title=Gepflegtes grün auf dem dach |issue=7 |pages=32–34 }}</ref> Maintenance of green roofs often includes fertilization to increase flowering and succulent plant cover. If aesthetics are not an issue, fertilization and maintenance are generally not needed. Extensive green roofs should only be fertilized with controlled-release fertilizers in order to avoid pollution of the storm water. Conventional fertilizers should never be used on extensive vegetated roofs.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Emilsson | first1 = T. | last2 = Czemiel Berndtsson | first2 = J. | last3 = Mattsson | first3 = J-E | last4 = Rolf | first4 = K. | year = 2007 | title = Effect of using conventional and controlled release fertilizer on nutrient runoff from various vegetated roof systems | url = | journal = Ecological Engineering | volume = 29 | issue = 3| pages = 260–271 | doi = 10.1016/j.ecoleng.2006.01.001 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Czemiel Berndtsson | first1 = J. | last2 = Emilsson | first2 = T. | last3 = Bengtsson | first3 = L. | year = 2006 | title = The influence of extensive vegetated roofs on runoff water quality | url = | journal = Science of the Total Environment | volume = 355 | issue = 1–3| pages = 48–63 | doi = 10.1016/j.scitotenv.2005.02.035 | pmid = 16442432 }}</ref> German studies have approximated the nutrient requirement of vegetated roofs to 5 gN/m<sup>2</sup>. It is also important to use a substrate that does not contain too many available nutrients. The FLL guidelines specify maximum-allowable nutrient content of substrates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fll.de |title=FLL: Startseite |website=Fll.de |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref>
One of the oldest American green roofs in existence is atop the Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, built in 1936. This roof was primarily an aesthetic undertaking for the enjoyment of the center's workers, and remains to this day, having been refurbished in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenroofs.com/projects/pview.php?id=666 |title=Projects - Rockefeller Center Roof Gardens |website=Greenroofs.com |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23}}</ref>
With the passage of Denver's Green Roof Initiative<ref>{{cite web|title=Denver's Green Roof Initiative|url=https://www.denvergov.org/content/denvergov/en/denver-development-services/commercial-projects/green-roof-initiative.html|website=DenverGov}}</ref> in the November 2017 elections, effective January 2018, new buildings or existing buildings meeting the initiative's thresholds are required to have rooftop gardens, optionally combined with solar photovoltaic panels.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murray|first1=Jon|title=Initiated Ordinance 300: Denver Green Roof Initiative|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/10/06/initiated-ordinance-300-denver/|website=The Denver Post|date=6 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Chow|first1=Lorraine|title=Denver Becomes Latest City to Require Green Roofs|url=https://www.ecowatch.com/denver-green-roofs-2508372741.html|website=EcoWatch|accessdate=17 November 2017|language=en|date=10 November 2017}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Architecture|Environment|Gardening|Sustainable development|Water}} *[[Arcology]] *[[Blue roof]] *[[Ecovillage]] *[[Energy-efficient landscaping]] *[[Hanging Gardens of Babylon]] *[[Low-impact development (U.S. and Canada)|Low-impact development]] *[[Rainwater harvesting]] *[[Ralph Hancock (landscape gardener)|Ralph Hancock]], designer, The Rockefeller Center Roof Gardens *[[Roof garden]] *[[Sod roof]], traditional roof in Scandinavia *[[Sustainable city]] *[[Subtropical climate vegetated roof]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
106. Hofmann, M., and S. S. Renner. 2017. Bee species recorded between 1992 and 2017 from green roofs in Asia, Europe, and North America, with key characteristics and open research questions. Apidologie, 19 Dec 2017 DOI: 10.1007/s13592-017-0555-x
==Further reading== *Snodgrass, E. and McIntyre, L., ''The Green Roof Manual: A Professional Guide to Design, Installation, and Maintenance'' Publisher: Timber Press (2010). *Dunnett, N. and Kingsbury, N., ''Planting Green Roofs and Living Walls'' Publisher: Timber Press (updated 2008). *Miller-Klein, Jan. ''Gardening for Butterflies, Bees and other beneficial insects'' {{ISBN|978-0-9555288-0-4}} has large section on green and brown roofs and brownfields, including how to make your own, with contributions from several UK practitioners. *{{cite journal | last1 = Scholz-Barth | first1 = Katrin | year = 2005 | title = Harvesting $ from Green Roofs: Green Roofs Present a Unique Business Opportunity with Tangible Benefits for Developers | url = | journal = Urban Land | volume = 64 | issue = 6| pages = 83–7 }} *Hilary, David. ''Creating My Green Roof: A guide to planning, installing, and maintaining a beautiful, energy-saving green roof.'" {{ISBN|978-1-4783-6807-6}} (2015). *Roland Appl, Reimer Meier, Wolfgang Ansel: ''Green Roofs – Bringing Nature Back to Town''. Publisher: International Green Roof Association IGRA, {{ISBN|978-3-9812978-1-2}} *Diversity of Fauna on Green Roofs [https://web.archive.org/web/20120319200626/http://www.greenroofs.org/grtok/materials_browse.php?id=59&what=view Diversity of fauna]
