revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = protected | name = Guichen Bay Conservation Park | state = sa | iucn_category = iii | image = | caption = | image_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|37|5|16|S|139|46|50|E|display=inline,title}} | relief = yes | nearest_town_or_city = [[Robe, South Australia|Robe]] | area = 1.27 | area_footnotes = {{cite web|title=Protected Areas Information System - reserve list (as of 17 Feb 2014)|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/b88e6e26-4bd9-4c68-8fff-9e800114eb69/park-management-protected-areas-gen.pdf|publisher=Department of Environment Water and Natural Resources|accessdate=26 March 2014|pages=}} | established = {{start date|1967|7|27|df=y}} | established_footnotes = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_footnotes = | managing_authorities = [[Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources (South Australia)|Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources]] | url = | embedded = }} '''Guichen Bay Conservation Park''' is a [[protected area]] in the Australian state of [[South Australia]] overlooking [[Guichen Bay]] located in the gazetted locality of [[Mount Benson, South Australia|Mount Benson]] about {{convert|8|km|abbr=off}} north of the town centre of [[Robe, South Australia|Robe]].{{cite web|title=Search result for "Guichen Bay Conservation Park" (Record no. SA0028362) with the following layers selected - "Suburbs and Localities" and " Place names (gazetteer)" |url=http://maps.sa.gov.au/plb/# |work=Property Location Browser|publisher=Government of South Australia |accessdate=15 July 2016}} While protected status was first conferred to the land in 1967, its current status as a conservation park under the ''[[National Parks and Wildlife Act 1972]]'' was proclaimed in 1972. The following statements sourced respectively from the conservation park’s management plan and the now-discontinued [[Register of the National Estate]] summarises its conservation significance:
The Park contains some of the Guichen Bay beach ridge plain; a classic example of Holocene beach ridge development of worldwide interest which records the naturalhistory of the Bay over the last 7000 years.
Because of its inaccessibility this Park is rarely visited by people. The fairly dense coastal heath provides a home for the secretive [[Rufous bristlebird|DASYORNIS BROADBENTI (rufous bristle bird)]], while along the seashore [[dotterels]] and [[oystercatchers]] are common.
The conservation park is classified as an [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|IUCN]] [[IUCN protected area categories#Category III — Natural Monument or Feature|Category III protected area]].{{cite web|title=CAPAD 2012 South Australia Summary (see 'DETAIL' tab)|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/0f927a4e-336a-490c-a896-ec37874a5c73/files/capad2012sa.xlsx|work=CAPAD 2012|publisher=Australian Government - Department of the Environment|accessdate=6 February 2014|date=6 February 2014}}{{cite book|title= Small Coastal Parks of the South East Management Plan|date=1994|publisher=National Parks and Wildlife Service, Department of Environment and Planning, South Australia|page =19|url= http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/b92dc434-54d2-410c-b414-9e4f00b1f557/PARKS_PDFS_SML_COAST_PKS_SE_MP.pdf|edition=|accessdate=29 July 2014}}{{cite web|title=Register of the National Estate (Non-statutory archive), Guichen Bay Conservation Park, Robe, SA, Australia|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/ahdb/search.pl?mode=place_detail;place_id=8042|publisher=Commonwealth of Australia, Department of the Environment|accessdate=27 October 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.protectedplanet.net/24351 Guichen Bay Conservation Park webpage on protected planet] {{Limestone Coast}} {{Protected areas of South Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Guichen Bay Conservation Park}} [[Category:Conservation parks of South Australia]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Australia]] {{Protected-area-stub}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Vodou to [[:Category:Voodoo]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 December 18]].
revision.text:
{{for|the ''République de Guinée''|Guinea}} {{Unreferenced|date=January 2008}} In [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]], '''Guinee''' is the spirit world. It is where the souls of the dead live. It is controlled by the loa Baron Samedi, believed to be the symbol of life and death.
There are seven gates through which Guinee can be entered. They are as follows:
#[[Baron La Croix]] #[[Guédé Nibo]] #[[Guédé Plumaj]] #[[Baron Cimetière|Baron Cimitière]] #[[Guédé Babaco]] #[[Baron Kriminel]] #[[Baron Samedi]]
The spirits of the dead have to pass through these seven gates to be reunited to the already dead ones.
Many practitioners of this faith believe that these seven gates are physically present in different areas in New Orleans.
{{Afro-American Religions}}
[[Category:Voodoo]] [[Category:African mythology]] [[Category:Mythological cosmologies]] [[Category:Afterlife places]]
{{Haiti-stub}} {{Africa-myth-stub}}

{{main|ISO 3166-2}}
'''ISO 3166-2:HM''' is the entry for [[Heard Island and McDonald Islands]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]].
Currently no ISO 3166-2 codes are defined in the entry for Heard Island and McDonald Islands. The territory has no defined subdivisions.
Heard Island and McDonald Islands is officially assigned the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code {{mono|HM}}.
==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:HM ISO Online Browsing Platform: HM] * [http://www.statoids.com/uhm.html Heard and McDonald Islands], Statoids.com
{{ISO 3166}}
[[Category:ISO 3166|2:HM]] [[Category:Heard Island and McDonald Islands]]

{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:MM''' is the entry for [[Myanmar]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Myanmar, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[regions and states of Burma|7 regions, 7 states, and 1 union territory]]. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|MM}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Myanmar. The second part is two digits: * 01–07: regions * 11–17: states * 18: union territory ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[Burmese language|my]])
(conventional names) ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter |- | id="II-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_ii-3_2011-12-13.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter II-3}}] | {{nowrap|2011-12-13}}
''(corrected
{{nowrap|2011-12-15}})'' | Addition of local generic administrative terms, source list update and addition of a comment. |} ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Myanmar]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (A-C)#BM: Burma|FIPS region codes of Myanmar]] ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:MM ISO Online Browsing Platform: MM] * [http://www.statoids.com/umm.html Divisions of Myanmar], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:MM]] [[Category:Regions and states of Myanmar|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:Myanmar-related lists]]

/* Rivers and valleys */ DAB resolved
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2008}} '''Leize''' is a widespread [[hydronym]]ic root meaning 'pit','ravine'. It appears in modern Basque dictionaries as ''leze'' 'cave'.
It may be found at the origin of river or place names as:
==Rivers and valleys== *the [[Leizaran]] (from ''Leize Haran'' 'valley of the Leize'), a river from [[Leitza]] in [[Navarre]]. *the [[Léez]], a left tributary of the [[Adour]]. *the [[Léès]], a right tributary of the Léez. * the [[Néez (Hautes-Pyrénées)|Néez]], a tributary of the Gave de Pau, in Gascony. * the [[Néez (Pyrénées-Atlantiques)|Néez]], another tributary of the Gave de Pau, in Gascony. *the Leze, a river flowing through a cave in [[Araia (Álava)|Araia]]. *the [[Lèze]], a left tributary of the [[Ariège River]]. *the Lèze and the Lezà, two small tributaries of the [[Baïse de Lasseube]]. *the [[Lez River|Lez]], a coastal river in [[Hérault]]. *the [[Lez (Salat)|Lez]], a left tributary of the [[Salat River|Salat]] ([[Ariège (department)|Ariège]]). *the [[Lez (Rhône)|Lez]], a left tributary of the [[Rhône River|Rhône]]. *the Leza, *the Lezo, in [[La Rioja (Spain)|La Rioja]], [[Spain]] *the [[Lizonne]] or Nizonne, a tributary of the [[Dronne]] ([[Dordogne]] basin) *the Lizou, a tributary of the [[Larcis|Arcis]] ([[Adour]] basin) *the Lis or Lys, a left tributary of the [[Échez]] (Adour basin) *the Lis or Lys, a right tributary of the [[Bouès]] (Adour basin) *the Lis Circus where the ski resort of [[Cauterets]] is located. *the Lis Valley near [[Luchon]] in the [[Pyrenees]]. *the Lys, a left tributary of the [[Layon]] ([[Anjou]]). *the band [[Lize?]]
The Pyrenean hydronym [[Neste]] is related.
On the other hand, the '''[[Lys River|Lys]]''' or '''Leie''' is based on another root, the [[Gaulish]] word [[liga (root)|liga]] 'silt'.
== Municipalities ==
* [[Lées-Athas]], commune of the [[Aspe Valley]] ([[Pyrénées-Atlantiques]]) * [[Les, Catalonia|Les]], municipality of the [[Val d'Aran]]. * [[Lez, Haute-Garonne|Lez]], commune of [[Haute-Garonne]] * [[Lez (Aveyron)|Lez]], former commune of [[Aveyron]], today integrated into [[Taussac]] * Lez, village of the commune of [[Saint-Béat]] in [[Haute-Garonne]]. * [[Lys, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Lys]], commune of [[Pyrénées-Atlantiques]] * [[Saint-Lys]] (ex ''Saint-Nicolas de Lys''), commune in the southwest of [[Toulouse]]. * Leizpartz, a hamlet of [[Saint-Étienne-de-Baïgorry]]
== Antroponyms == * ''Lexeia'', an antic Aquitanian female name
[[Category:Placename element etymologies]] [[Category:Hydronymy]]

page.title: List of Catholicoi of all Armenians

revision.text:
This is a list of the '''[[Catholicos of All Armenians|Catholicoi of all Armenians]]''' ({{lang-hy|Ամենայն Հայոց Կաթողիկոս}}), head [[bishop]]s of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] ({{lang-hy|Հայ Առաքելական Եկեղեցի}}).
==Catholicoi of Armenia== ''(Name in English, dates, [[Armenian language|Armenian]] name in [[Eastern Armenian]] spelling)''
===Apostolic Era=== *[[Saint Jude|St. Thaddeus the Apostle]] (43–66) -- Սբ. Թադևոս Առաքյալ *[[Bartholomew|St. Bartholomew the Apostle]] (60–68) -- Սբ. Բարդուղիմեոս Առաքյալ *St. Zacharias (68–72) -- Սբ. Զաքարիա *St. Zementus (72–76) -- Սբ. Զեմենդոս *St. Atrnerseh (77–92) -- Սբ. Ատրներսեհ *St. Mushe (93–123) -- Սբ. Մուշե *St. Shahen (124–150) -- Սբ. Շահեն *St. Shavarsh (151–171) Սբ. Շավարշ *St. Leontius (172–190) -- Սբ. Ղեոնդիոս
===Sophene Era=== *[[St. Merozanes]] (240–270) -- Սբ. Մերուժան *[[Gregory the Illuminator|St. Gregory I the Illuminator]] (288–325) -- Սուրբ Գրիգոր Ա Պարթև (Լուսավորիչ)
===First [[Vagharshapat|Echmiadzin]] era (301–452)=== '''[[Arsacid Dynasty of Armenia|Arsacid Dynasty]] (from 301 to 428 the episcopal office is hereditary)''' *[[Gregory the Illuminator|St. Gregory I the Illuminator]] (301–325) -- Սուրբ Գրիգոր Ա Պարթև (Լուսավորիչ) *[[St. Aristaces I]] (325–333) -- Սբ. Արիստակես Ա Պարթև *[[St. Vrtanes I]] (333–341) -- Սբ. Վրթանես Ա Պարթև *[[St. Husik I]] (341–347) -- Սբ. Հուսիկ Ա Պարթև '''Assyrian descent''' *[[Daniel I of Armenia]] (347) -- Դանիել Ա '''Ashishatts Dynasty''' *[[Pharen I of Armenia]] (348–352) -- Փառեն Ա Աշտիշատցի '''[[Arsacid Dynasty of Armenia|Arsacid Dynasty]]''' *[[St. Nerses I|St. Nerses I the Great]] (353–373) -- Սուրբ Ներսես Ա Մեծ (Պարթև) '''Albaniosid Dynasty''' *[[Sahak I]] (373–377) -- Սահակ Ա Մանազկերտցի *[[Zaven I]] (377–381) -- Զավեն Ա Մանազկերտցի *[[Aspuraces I]] (381–386) -- Ասպուրակես Ա Մանազկերտցի '''[[Arsacid Dynasty of Armenia|Arsacid Dynasty]]''' *[[Isaac of Armenia|St. Sahak I]] (387–428) -- Սբ. Սահակ Ա Պարթև '''Assyrian descent''' *[[Brkisho of Armenia]] (428–432) -- Բրկիշո *[[Samuel of Armenia]] (432–437) -- Սամվել '''Non-Hereditary Bishop''' *[[St. Hovsep I]] (437–452) -- Սբ. Հովսեփ Ա Հողոցմեցի
===[[Dvin (ancient city)|Dvin]] era (452–927)=== *[[Melitus I of Armenia|Melitus I]] (452–456) -- Մելիտե Ա Մանազկերտցի *[[Moses I of Armenia|Moses I]] (456–461) -- Մովսես Ա Մանազկերտցի *[[St. Kyud I]] (461–478) -- Սբ. Գյուտ Ա Արահեզացի *[[St. John I of Armenia|St. John I]] (478–490) -- Սբ. Հովհաննես Ա Մանդակունի *[[Babken I of Armenia|Babken I]] (490–516) -- Բաբկեն Ա Ոթմսեցի *[[Samuel I of Armenia|Samuel I]] (516–526) -- Սամվել Ա Արծկեցի *[[Mushe I]] (526–534) -- Մուշե Ա Այլաբերցի *[[Sahak II of Armenia|Sahak II]] (534–539) -- Սահակ Բ Ուղկեցի *[[Christopher I of Armenia|Christopher I]] (539–545) -- Քրիստափոր Ա Տիրառիջցի *[[Ghevond I]] (545–548) -- Ղեվոնդ Ա Եռաստեցի *[[Nerses II of Armenia|Nerses II]] (548–557) -- Ներսես Բ Բագրևվանդցի *[[John II of Armenia|John II]] (557–574)-- Հովհաննես Բ Գաբեղենցի *[[Moses II of Armenia|Moses II]] (574–604) -- Մովսես Բ. Եղիվարդեցի **vacant 604–607, administered by [[Verthanes Qerthol]] the Gramatic *[[Abraham I of Armenia|Abraham I]] (607–615) -- Աբրահամ Ա Աղբաթանեցի *[[Komitas Aghtsetsi|Komitas I]] (615–628) -- Կոմիտաս Ա Աղցեցի *[[Christopher II of Armenia|Christopher II]] (628–630), died aft. 630 — Քրիստափոր Բ Ապահունի *[[Ezra I of Armenia|Ezra I]] (630–641) -- Եզր Ա Փառաժնակերտցի *[[Nerses III the Builder]] (641–661) -- Ներսես Գ Տայեցի (Շինարար) *[[Anastasius I of Armenia|Anastasius I]] (661–667) -- Անաստաց Ա Ակոռեցի *[[Israel I of Armenia|Israel I]] (667–677) -- Իսրայել Ա Ոթմսեցի *[[Sahak III]] (677–703) -- Սահակ Գ. Ձորոփորեցի *[[Elias I of Armenia|Elias I]] (703–717) -- Եղիա Ա Արճիզեցի *[[St. John III the Philosopher]] (717–728) -- Սբ. Հովհաննես Գ Օձնեցի (Փիլիսոփա) *[[David I of Armenia|David I]] (728–741) -- Դավիթ Ա Արամոնեցի *[[Dertad I]] (741–764) -- Տրդատ Ա Ոթմսեցի *[[Dertad II]] (764–767) -- Տրդատ Բ Դասնավորեցի *[[Sion I of Armenia|Sion I]] (767–775) -- Սիոն Ա Բավոնեցի *[[Isaiah I of Armenia|Isaiah I]] (775–788) -- Եսայի Ա Եղիպատրուշեցի *[[Catholicos Stephen I of Armenia|Stephen I]] (788–790) -- Ստեփանոս Ա Դվնեցի *[[Joab I of Armenia|Joab I]] (790–791) -- Յովաբ Ա Դվնեցի *[[Solomon I of Armenia|Solomon I]] (791–792) -- Սողոմոն Ա Գառնեցի *[[George I of Armenia|George I]] (792–795) -- Գևորգ Ա Բյուրականցի *[[Joseph I of Armenia|Joseph I]] (795–806) -- Հովսեփ Բ Փարպեցի *[[David II of Armenia|David II]] (806–833) -- Դավիթ Բ Կակաղեցի *[[John IV of Armenia|John IV]] (833–855) -- Հովհաննես Դ Ավայեցի *[[Zacharias I of Armenia|Zacharias I]] (855–876) -- Զաքարիա Ա Ձագեցի *[[George II of Armenia|George II]] (877–897) -- Գևորգ Բ Գառնեցի *[[Mashdotz I]] (897–898) -- Մաշտոց Ա Եղվարդեցի
===[[Akdamar Island|Aghtamar]] era (927–947)=== *[[John V the Historian]] (898–929) -- Հովհաննես Ե Դրասխանակերտցի *[[Stephen II of Armenia|Stephen II]] (929–930) -- Ստեփանոս Բ Ռշտունի *[[Theodore I of Armenia|Theodore I]] (930–941) -- Թեոդորոս Ա Ռշտունի *[[Yeghishe I]] (941–946) -- Եղիշե Ա Ռշտունի
===Arghina era (947–992)=== *[[Ananias I of Armenia|Ananias I]] (949–968) -- Անանիա Ա Մոկացի *[[Vahan I of Armenia|Vahan I]] (968–969) -- Վահան Ա Սյունեցի *[[Stephen III of Armenia|Stephen III]] (969–972) -- Ստեփանոս Գ Սևանցի *[[Khachig I of Armenia|Khachig I]] (973–992) -- Խաչիկ Ա Արշարունի
===[[Ani]] era (992–1058)=== *[[Sarkis I of Armenia|Sarkis I]] (992–1019), d. aft. 1019 — Սարգիս Ա Սևանցի *[[Peter I of Armenia|Peter I]] (1019–1058) -- Պետրոս Ա Գետադարձ
''During this time the see was transferred to [[Cilicia]], from 1058 until 1441 (see [[List of Armenian Catholicoi of Cilicia]] for continued succession).''
==Catholicoi of the Mother See of Holy Echmiadzin and All Armenians==
===Second [[Vagharshapat|Echmiadzin]] era (1441–present)=== *[[Giragos I of Armenia|Giragos I]] (1441–1443) -- Կիրակոս Ա Վիրապեցի *[[Gregory X of Armenia|Gregory X]] (1443–1465) -- Գրիգոր Ժ Ջալալբեկյանց **[[Aristaces II of Armenia|Aristaces II]] (''Coadjutor'') (1465–1469) -- Արիստակես Բ Աթոռակալ *[[Sarkis II the Relic-Carrier]] (1469–1474) -- Սարգիս Բ Աջատար *[[John VII the Relic-Bearer]] (1474–1484), d. 1506—Հովհաննես Է Աջակիր *[[Sarkis III the Other]] (1484–1515) -- Սարգիս Գ Մյուսայլ *[[Zacharias II]] (1515–1520) -- Զաքարիա Բ Վաղարշապատցի *[[Sarkis IV]] (1520–1536) -- Սարգիս Դ Վրաստանցի *[[Gregory XI of Armenia|Gregory XI]] (1536–1545) -- Գրիգոր ԺԱ Բյուզանդացի *[[Stepanos V of Salmast|Stepanos V]] (1545–1567) -- Ստեփանոս Ե Սալմաստեցի *[[Michael I of Armenia|Michael I]] (1567–1576) -- Միքայել Ա Սեբաստացի *[[Gregory XII of Armenia|Gregory XII]] (1576–1590) -- Գրիգոր ԺԲ Վաղարշապատցի *[[David IV of Armenia|David IV]] (1590–1629), d. 1633—Դավիթ Դ Վաղարշապատցի *[[Moses III of Armenia|Moses III]] (1629–1632) -- Մովսես Գ Տաթևացի *[[Philip I of Armenia|Philip I]] (1633–1655) -- Փիլիպոս Ա Աղբակեցի *[[Jacob IV of Armenia|Jacob IV]] (1655–1680) -- Հակոբ Դ Ջուղայեցի *[[Eliazar I of Armenia|Eliazar I]] (1681–1691) -- Եղիազար Ա Այնթափցի *[[Nahabed I of Armenia|Nahabed I]] (1691–1705) -- Նահապետ Ա Եդեսացի *[[Alexander I of Armenia|Alexander I]] (1706–1714) -- Ալեքսանդր Ա Ջուղայեցի *[[Asdvadzadur of Armenia|Asdvadzadur]] (1715–1725) -- Աստվածատուր Ա Համադանցի *[[Karapet II of Armenia|Karapet II]] (1726–1729) -- Կարապետ Բ Ուլնեցի *[[Abraham II of Armenia|Abraham II]] (1730–1734) -- Աբրահամ Բ Խոշաբեցի *[[Abraham III of Armenia|Abraham III]] (1734–1737) -- Աբրահամ Գ Կրետացի *[[Lazar I of Armenia|Lazar I]] (1737–1751) -- Ղազար Ա Ջահկեցի *[[Minas I of Armenia|Minas I]] (1751–1753) -- Մինաս Ա Ակնեցի *[[Alexander II of Armenia|Alexander II]] (1753–1755) -- Ալեքսանդր Բ Բյուզանդացի **[[Sahak V]] (elected but never consecrated) (1755) -- Սահակ Ե **''vacant'' (1755–1759) *[[Jacob V of Armenia|Jacob V]] (1759–1763) -- Հակոբ Ե Շամախեցի *[[Simeon I of Armenia|Simeon I]] (1763–1780) -- Սիմոն Ա Երևանցի *[[Luke I of Armenia|Luke I]] (1780–1799) -- Ղուկաս Ա Կարնեցի **[[Joseph II of Armenia|Joseph II]] (elected but never consecrated) (1800), d. 1801 — Հովսեփ Բ **[[David V of Armenia|David V]] (1801–1807) -- Դավիթ Ե Էնեգեթցի (Ղորղանյան) *[[Daniel II of Armenia|Daniel II]] (1802–1808) -- Դանիել Բ Սուրմառեցի *[[Yeprem I of Armenia|Yeprem I]] (1809–1830), d. 1835—Եփրեմ Ա Ձորագեղցի *[[John VIII of Armenia|John VIII]] (1831–1842) -- Հովհաննես Ը Կարբեցի *[[Nerses V]] (1843–1857) -- Ներսես Ե. Աշտարակեցի *[[Matthew I of Armenia|Matthew I]] (1858–1865) -- Մատթէոս Ա Կոնստանդնուպոլսեցի (Չուխաճեան) *[[George IV of Armenia|George IV]] (1866–1882) -- Գէորգ Դ Կոնստանդնուպոլսեցի (Քէրեստեճեան) **''vacant'' (1882–1885) *[[Magar of Armenia|Magar]] (1885–1891) -- Մակար Ա. Թեղուտցի *[[Mkrtich Khrimian|Mkrtich I Khrimian]] (1892–1907) -- Մկրտիչ Ա Վանեցի (Խրիմեան Հայրիկ) *[[Matthew II of Armenia|Matthew II]] (1908–1910) -- Մատթևոս Բ Կոնստանդնուպոլսեցի (Իզմիրլեան) *[[George V of Armenia|George V]] (1911–1930) -- Գևորգ Ե Սուրենեանց (Տփղիսեցի) **''vacant'' (1930–1932) *[[Khoren I of Armenia|Khoren I]] (1932–1938) -- Խորեն Ա Մուրադբեկեան (Տփղիսեցի) **''vacant'' (1938–1945) *[[George VI of Armenia|George VI]] (1945–1954) -- Գևորգ Զ Չորեքչյան (Նորնախիջևանցի) *[[Vazgen I]] (1955–1994) -- Վազգեն Ա Պալճյան (Բուխարեստցի) *[[Karekin I]] (1994–1999) -- Գարեգին Ա Սարգիսյան (Քեսաբցի) *[[Karekin II]] (1999–present) -- Գարեգին Բ Ներսիսյան (Ոսկեհատցի)
==See also== *[[Catholicos of All Armenians]] *[[List of Catholicos of the East]] *[[List of Armenian Catholicoi of Cilicia]] *[[List of Armenian Patriarchs of Constantinople]] *[[List of Armenian Patriarchs of Jerusalem]] *[[List of Armenian Catholic Patriarchs of Cilicia]]

revision.comment: /* Other recurring characters */
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Extras'' characters}} The British television sitcom ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'' centres on the main characters of Andy Millman, Maggie Jacobs and Darren Lamb, in addition to several more recurring characters.
==Main characters==
===Andy Millman=== [[File:Ricky Gervais 2010.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Ricky Gervais]] (pictured in 2010) played the lead, a down-on-his-luck actor]] Portrayed by [[Ricky Gervais]], Andrew "Andy" Millman is the lead character of ''Extras''. Andy's dream to become an actor – he left his steady day job at [[Natwest]] in [[Wokingham]] in order to pursue it - is endlessly frustrated by the fact that his agent [[#Darren Lamb|Darren Lamb]] is incompetent, circumstances seem to conspire against him, and the only work he can get is as a [[extra (drama)|film extra]]. His best friend is fellow extra [[#Maggie Jacobs|Maggie Jacobs]], but her staunch desire to help, coupled with a lack of tact and intelligence, means that she more often than not causes him just as much trouble.
At the end of Series 1, Millman successfully managed to sell a [[sitcom]] called ''When the Whistle Blows'', which proves to be a commercial but not a critical success.
In contrast to Gervais' other famed role as [[David Brent]], who, through his desire to be liked by those around him comes off as pathetic, Millman often makes little or no attempt to be liked - often being a downright curmudgeon - but frequently comes across as being a much more likeable character than Brent. This may be due to his increased sense of self-awareness and understanding; when compared to Brent, Millman is all too aware of when he has stepped over the line and become genuinely offensive (although this doesn't stop him from causing genuine offence). Also unlike Brent, who was largely in denial about the world around him, Millman is a more depressed and misanthropic character with a more realistic appraisal of the world and how it works. Whereas Brent was based on a former [[supervisor|boss]] of Gervais, Millman's personality is more autobiographical in origin.<ref>[http://www.rickygervais.com/podcasts2.php Ricky Gervais... Obviously<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A running joke is that Millman did not lose his virginity until the age of 28 (although the first time this is mentioned, Maggie says he was 22), and to a woman who looked like [[Ronnie Corbett]] (who turns up in a later episode as himself). Andy's nemesis throughout the programme is [[#Greg Lindley-Jones|Greg Lindley-Jones]], who also started out as an extra before finding success in a number of productions and becoming a well-respected actor, much to Andy's annoyance.
===Maggie Jacobs=== [[File:Ashley Jensen.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Ashley Jensen]] (pictured in 2008) played naive Jacobs]] Portrayed by [[Ashley Jensen]], Maggie Jacobs is characterised as a genuinely kind and supportive individual who only wants to help out. Unfortunately for her and those around her, she is also portrayed as being rather socially inept and lacking in any sort of internal censor or sense of tact, which means that she's more likely to say precisely the wrong thing at the wrong time to the wrong person, and thus create more trouble for herself and those around her (especially Andy, whom she frequently embarrasses by inadvertently puncturing his pretensions towards being an [[actor]]). Although the character possesses no malicious intent, she also appears to be rather childlike and poorly educated when it comes to matters of race and [[political correctness]] - which, when coupled with her general tactlessness, frequently results in her causing genuine offence through inadvertent insults and stereotypes. In series two her earthy ways are shown to contrast greatly with the pretensions of Andy's new friends. Gervais has stated that he thinks the personality of Maggie resembles a female version of [[Karl Pilkington]], whose friendship with Gervais was developing during the time Extras was being written.<ref>[https://twitter.com/rickygervais Ricky Gervais Twitter 17/11/2011<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> During the series Andy even explains that he and Maggie are friends because she's so stupid and it amuses him, which is precisely what Gervais has said about Pilkington.
Maggie is rather man-hungry, and throughout the series she is constantly on the lookout for 'Mr. Right.' However, owing to circumstance and her aforementioned tendency to commit social ''faux-pas,'' the relationships she starts with men throughout the series rarely last long. However, there have been instances in which the men she is interested in turn out to be very much less than desirable, through no fault of her own. In one episode she was constantly pestered and eventually kissed by [[Orlando Bloom]], even though she had told him that she did not find him particularly attractive.
===Darren Lamb=== [[File:StephenMerchantAltNov09.jpg|left|thumb|130px|[[Stephen Merchant]] (pictured in 2009) played the lead's inept agent]] Portrayed by [[Stephen Merchant]], Darren Lamb is Andy Millman's agent. He is utterly incapable of breaking an act, and his usual negotiating tactic is to simply agree with whatever anyone else says, or suggest someone other than his client for the part. He's very good at deducting his 12.5% commission ("15% for adverts") despite frequently having done nothing to contribute to his act's success. For example, in series two episode two, whilst in the pub, he asks for £27.50 from Barry for the £220 he was paid for fixing someone's gutter, despite having no involvement in getting him the job. He can often be seen begging for this type of payment. His lack of professional skills is typified by the occasion he inadvertently left his office phone unplugged for two days without noticing. He is also known to make inappropriate remarks at the least helpful of times. Lamb works part-time at the [[Carphone Warehouse]], but in Episode 4 of Series 2, he mentions he only works on Saturdays while "Narinder" is pregnant.
Despite these (and more) overwhelming examples of incompetence, Lamb is nevertheless the agent of the series' protagonist, the frustrated [[#Andy Millman|Andy Millman]], who is more than aware of his agent's utter uselessness but nevertheless feels compelled to retain him out of a slightly perverse mixture of responsibility and sympathy. Lamb is also the agent of "[[List of Extras characters#Barry off EastEnders|Barry from ''EastEnders'']]".
In episode six of the second series, an increasingly stressed Millman threatens to sack Lamb after he is caught masturbating and relaxing in his office. However, Lamb manages to arrange a meeting between Millman and his hero [[Robert De Niro]], with the indication given that he managed to keep his job as a result.
Lamb does not have a regular girlfriend and his rather crude way of chatting up women (as seen in episode two of series two) means few have any wish to fulfil his sexual desires. In the fourth episode he actually managed to invite Maggie to his house, things go well until Lamb tries to break an unflushable faeces in his toilet into pieces with a whisk, causing Maggie to leave his house in disgust.
===Barry off ''EastEnders''=== [[File:Shaun Williamson.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Shaun Williamson]] (pictured in 2008) played a failed soap-opera actor]] [[Shaun Williamson]] plays himself as one of Darren's clients. He used to play [[Barry Evans (EastEnders)|Barry Evans]] on the British soap opera ''[[EastEnders]]'', but left to pursue a multi-million pound contract elsewhere and failed. Darren Lamb doesn't use his real name, but instead calls him "Barry off ''EastEnders''" or just "Barry" and occasionally "Barr". This also extends to other characters as seen in episode 1.2, where fellow ''EastEnders'' actor [[Ross Kemp]] only seems to know Shaun Williamson after being told his ''EastEnders'' character name. He carries an air of accepted defeat, and helps Lamb around his office, appearing to be marginally the more competent of the two. They later team up with another ex-Eastender, [[Dean Gaffney]], at the Carphone Warehouse. Andy and Dean are the only ones who ever call him "Shaun".
===Greg Lindley-Jones=== Portrayed by [[Shaun Pye]], Greg Lindley-Jones is an arrogant and mean-spirited [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] graduate and [[#Andy Millman|Andy's]] enemy. Like Andy, he started out as an [[Extra (actor)|extra]], struggling to get more significant roles. However, unlike Andy, he has managed to secure lines in various productions such as ''[[The Bill]]'' and consequently he possesses a rather high opinion of himself and is constantly bullying Andy. Andy rarely gets ahead in his encounters with Greg. In the first episode of series one it is revealed he is subsidised by his wealthy parents. While both Andy and Greg are suitably advantaged so that they can afford to work full-time in minor acting roles, Greg's through a privileged background and Andy's through a previous career at the bank. Greg is notably annoyed when Andy tries to celebrate his BBC series triumph with fellow extras in Season 1 Episode 6.
Greg gradually gains more recognition as a successful stage, television and eventually film actor. In the Christmas special he boasts to Andy how the fictitious film ''[[Lord Byron|Byron]]: A Life'', (in which he starred alongside [[Clive Owen]]) is number one in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] film charts and number two in [[United States of America|America]]. Andy becomes envious of the fact Greg is now a well-respected [[Hollywood]] actor whilst he is only recognised for featuring in a lowbrow [[sitcom]].
==Other recurring characters== * Bunny ([[Gerard Kelly]]) - three episodes, a camp pantomime director whose daughter appears in the first series. He reappears in the Sir Ian McKellen episode and the Christmas Special. * Damon Beesley ([[Martin Savage (actor)|Martin Savage]]), the very camp comedy script writer who is brought in to work alongside Andy. * Iain Morris ([[Guy Henry (actor)|Guy Henry]]) - The head of Comedy at the BBC, Morris is one of the contributors to stealing artistic direction of 'When the Whistle Blows' from Andy. He has a strong friendship with Damon Beesley, agreeing with virtually anything the latter suggests for the sitcom no matter how ridiculous, and becomes increasingly arrogant and condescending when Andy raises his concerns about it. He is also gay and takes it very personally when any implied homophobia is used in his presence. He appears in three episodes as well as a minor role in the Christmas Special. * "Make-up woman" ([[Sarah Preston]]) - three episodes. Asks for signed pictures but no one can remember her name. * [[Liza Tarbuck]] - although she mainly appears in character as Rita in ''When the Whistle Blows'', she is also seen in make-up as herself.
==''When the Whistle Blows''== {{main|Extras (TV series)#When the Whistle Blows}} ;Ray Stokes: Ray is the manager, played by Andy Millman, in turn played by Ricky Gervais. His catchphrase is an incredulous "Are you having a laugh!? Is he/she having a laugh?". The character was based on a man Millman worked for before deciding to pursue acting full-time, and originally his catchphrase was merely something Millman wrote in because it was something that man used to say. Millman's co-writer decided to develop it into a catchphrase. To play the part of Ray, Millman is forced into wearing oversized glasses and a curly black wig to add the "hilarity", despite the fact that the real Ray Stokes did not look like this. Many of Ray's mannerisms, such as raising and lowering his glasses, suggest that he could be a parody of [[Reg Holdsworth]], an old character from the long-running British soap ''[[Coronation Street]]''.
;Rita: Rita is played by [[Liza Tarbuck]], who also sings the ''When The Whistle Blows'' [[theme song]]. She is a [[single parent]] and is the central, straight character of the show. She is married in the Christmas Special.
;Gobbler: Gobbler is a large, unintelligent character, played by Andrew Buckley. His inability to understand his co-workers' jokes often prompts his catchphrase, "I don't get it!" It is suggested that he has appalling personal hygiene. He becomes intelligent after falling off a donkey in the Christmas Special.
;Brains: Brains, played by Jamie Chapman, is the stereotypical smart one of the group, sporting glasses, a quiffed hairstyle and a pedantic tone. His rather detailed knowledge of all subjects does not impress Ray, who will inevitably come out with the "are ya 'avin' a laugh?" line. He 'comes out' in the Christmas Special.
;Kimberley: Kimberley, played by Sarah Moyle is the only other female character on the show. She seems to lead a rather homely lifestyle. In the Christmas Special, she received a promotion.
;Keith: Keith is played by TV presenter [[Keith Chegwin]] in the pilot episode. His character was originally called "Alfie", but a frustrated Millman changed it because Keith Chegwin was confused at being addressed with a different name. We are told he is always late for work, but in this instance turns up late because he was at his sister's funeral. This also confused Chegwin, who confided: "the thing is, my sister's not dead".
There are relatively few other characters in the sitcom, but they include Chris Martin (playing himself), and a Japanese couple, who also spawn another catchphrase "Velly velly solly" (as seen on a T-shirt worn by a crowd member in the Christmas Special). Ray's wife [[unseen character|is mentioned, but never appears]] - which is an old cliché of British comedy, e.g., ''[[Minder (TV series)|Minder]]'' and [[Dad's Army]]. Andy appears in a dual role as Ray's twin sister.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[[HBO]].com: ''[http://www.hbo.com/extras/cast/ Extras — cast and crew]'' :*[http://www.hbo.com/extras/cast/character/andy_millman.html Andy Millman] :*[http://www.hbo.com/extras/cast/character/maggie_jacobs.html Maggie Jacobs] :*[http://www.hbo.com/extras/cast/character/darren_lamb.html Darren Lamb] :*[http://www.hbo.com/extras/cast/character/barry.html Barry]

page.title: List of Iranian dynasties and countries

revision.comment: /* Independent states */
revision.text:
The following is an incomplete list of historical [[Dynasty|dynasties]] which were at some time Iranian or the country they ruled were [[Iranian languages|Iranian-speaking]] and of modern countries with significant [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] populations or with an official Iranian language. The [[Iranian peoples|Iranians]] consist of [[Persian people|Persians]], [[Medes]], [[Scythians]], [[Kurdish people|Kurds]], [[Bactrians]], [[Pashtuns]], [[Tajiks]], [[Baloch people|Baloch]], [[Parthian Empire|Parthians]], [[Sarmatians]], [[Alans]], [[Ossetians]], [[Cimerians]], and many more peoples.
== Current states == === Independent states === *{{flagicon|Iran}} [[Iran]] *{{flagicon|Afghanistan}} [[Afghanistan]] *{{flagicon|Tajikistan}} [[Tajikistan]] *{{flagicon|South Ossetia}} [[South Ossetia]] (''de facto'')
=== Federal subjects of Russia === *{{flagicon image|Flag of North Ossetia.svg}} [[North Ossetia-Alania]]
=== Autonomous regions === *{{flagicon|China}} [[Taxkorgan Tajik Autonomous County]] in [[China]] *{{flagicon|Iraqi Kurdistan}} [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] in [[Iraq]] *{{flagicon|Rojava}} [[Rojava]] in [[Syria]] *{{flagicon|Tajikistan}} [[Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region]] in [[Tajikistan]]
== Historical confederation of tribes and Iranian dynasties == *[[Scythians]] *[[Cimmerians]] *[[Kidarites]] *[[Xionites]] *[[Dahae]] *[[Sarmatians]] *[[Saka]] *[[Bactria]] *[[Sogdiana]] *[[The Pahlavas]] *[[Massagetaeans]] *[[Roxolani]] *[[Siraces]] *[[Iazyges]]
=== Europe === *[[Alania]] – of proto-[[Ossetians|Ossetian]] origin
=== Direct Iranian dynasties === *[[Medes]] (ca. 678 BCE–549 BCE) of [[Media (region)|Median]] origin *[[Orontid dynasty]] (570–200 BC) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin<ref>Allsen, Thomas T. (2011). ''The Royal Hunt in Eurasian History''. University of Pennsylvania Press. {{ISBN|978-0812201079}}. p. 37.; "The Orontid dynasty of Armenia (ca. 401-200), whose ruling house was of Achaemenid origin, originally administered the territory as satraps and later as independent kings."</ref><ref>Sartre, Maurice (2005). ''The Middle East Under Rome''. Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|978-0674016835}}. p. 23; "The Commagene kings claimed to be descended from the Orontids, a powerful Iranian family that had ruled the area during the Achaemenid period. They were related to the Achaemenids who had built a kingdom (...)".</ref><ref>Babaie, Sussan.; Grigor, Talinn. ''Persian Kingship and Architecture: Strategies of Power in Iran from the Achaemenids to the Pahlavis''. (2015). I.B.Tauris. {{ISBN|978-1848857513}}. p. 80.; "Iranian culture deeply influenced Armenia, and Iranian dynasties ruled Armenia during several important periods, including the Orontids (c. sixth century – c. early second century BCE) and Arsacids (54–428 CE)."</ref><ref>TIGRAN II. Garsoian, N. (2005). Encyclopaedia Iranica. quote = "Tigran (Tigranes) II was the most distinguished member of the so-called Artašēsid/Artaxiad dynasty, which has now been identified as a branch of the earlier Eruandid [Orontid] dynasty of Iranian origin attested as ruling in Armenia from at least the 5th century B.C.E."</ref><ref>[[Cyril Toumanoff]] (Georgetown University Press, 1963; ''Studies in Christian Caucasian History'', part III. ''The Orontids of Armenia''. ). p. 278; "The eponym's ''praeonemen'' Orontes is as Iranian as the dynasty itself, derived from the Avestan auraund/aurvant ('mighty,' 'hero') and related to the Pehlevi arvand."</ref> *[[Achaemenid Empire]] (550–330 BC) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Atropatene]] (320s BC–3rd century AD) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin *[[Mithridatic dynasty]] (281-47/37 BC) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Parthian Empire]] ("Arsacid dynasty of Parthia"; 247 BC–224 AD) of [[Parthia]]n origin **[[Arsacid dynasty of Armenia]] (52–428) of [[Parthia]]n origin **[[Arsacid dynasty of Iberia]] (c. 189–284) of [[Parthia]]n origin **[[Arsacid dynasty of Caucasian Albania]] (1st century-510) of [[Parthia]]n origin *[[Indo-Scythians]] (200 BCE–400 AD) of [[Scythians|Scythian]] origin *[[Artaxiad dynasty]] (190 BC-12 AD) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin *[[Indo-Parthian Kingdom]] (12 BC–before 100 AD?) Of [[Parthia]]n origin *[[Sasanian Empire]] (224–651) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Chosroid dynasty]] (284–807) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin *[[Mihranids]] (330–821) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin *[[Afrighids]] (305–995) of [[Khwarezmian language|Khwarezmian]] origin *[[Dabuyid dynasty]] (642–760) Of [[Persian people|Persian]] and [[Tabaristan|Tabari]] origin *[[Masmughans of Damavand]] (650–760) Of [[Parthia]]n origin *[[Bavand dynasty]] (651–1349) Of [[Parthia]]n origin *[[Paduspanids]] (665–1598) of [[Persian people|Persian]] and [[Tabaristan|Tabari]] origin *[[Bukhar Khudahs]] (before 681-890s) of [[Sogdians|Sogdian]] origin *[[Principality of Ushrusana]] (???-892/3) of [[Sogdians|Sogdian]] origin *[[Qarinvand dynasty]] (7th-century–11th-century) of [[Parthia]]n origin *[[Rustamid dynasty]] (767–909) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Justanids]] (791–974) of [[Dailamite]] origin *[[Shirvanshah]] (1207–1607) originally of [[Arabs|Arab]] origin, but speedily [[Persian people|Persianized]]<ref name="EIB">Barthold, W., C.E. Bosworth "Shirwan Shah, Sharwan Shah. "Encyclopaedia of Islam. Edited by: P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel and W.P. Heinrichs. Brill, 2nd edition</ref><ref name="BosworthEIR">C.E. Bosworth, "ŠERVĀNŠAHS" in Encyclopaedia Iranica. Excerpt 1: "ŠERVĀNŠAHS (Šarvānšāhs), the various lines of rulers, originally Arab in ethnos but speedily Persianized" Excerpt 2:" ). Just as an originally Arab family like the Rawwādids in Azerbaijan became Kurdicized from their Kurdish milieu, so the Šervānšāhs clearly became gradually Persianized, probably helped by intermarriage with the local families of eastern Transcaucasia; from the time of Manučehr b. Yazid (r. 418-25/1028-34), their names became almost entirely Persian rather than Arabic, with favored names from the heroic national Iranian past and with claims made to descent from such figures as Bahrām Gur".</ref> within their culturally Persian environment.<ref name="BosworthEIR"/> *[[Samanids]] (819–999) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Tahirid dynasty]] (821–873) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Banijurids]] (848–908) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Saffarid dynasty]] (861–1003) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Sajid dynasty]] (889/890–929) of [[Sogdiana|Sogdian]] origin *[[Farighunids]] (10th century-1010) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Sallarid dynasty]] (919–1062) of [[Dailamites|Dailamite]] origin *[[Ziyarid dynasty]] (931–1090) of [[Dailamites|Dailamite]] origin *[[Banu Ilyas]] (932–968) of [[Sogdia]]n origin *[[Buyid dynasty]] (934–1055) of [[Dailamites|Dailamite]] origin *[[Shaddadids]] (951–1174) of [[Kurds|Kurdish]] origin *[[Marwanids]] (990–1085) of [[Kurds|Kurdish]] origin *[[Ma'munids]] (995–1017) of [[Khwarezmian language|Khwarezmian]] origin *[[Kakuyids]] (1008–1141) of [[Dailamites|Dailamite]] origin *[[Ghurid Dynasty]] (1011–1215) of [[Tajik people|Tajik]] origin *[[Nasrid dynasty (Sistan)]] (1029–1225) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Hazaraspids]] (1115–1424) of [[Kurds|Kurdish]] origin *[[Atabegs of Yazd]] (1141–1319) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Ayyubid dynasty]] (1171–1341) of [[Kurds|Kurdish]] origin *[[Principality of Bitlis]] (1182–1847) of [[Kurds|Kurdish]] origin *[[Mihrabanids]] (1236–1537) of [[Persian people|Persian]] origin *[[Kurt Dynasty]] (1244–1381) Of [[Tajik people|Tajik]] origin *[[Afrasiab dynasty]] (1349–1504) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin *[[Marashiyan|Marashis]] (1359-1596) of [[Mazandarani people|Mazandarani]] origin *[[Lodi dynasty]] (1451-1526) of [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] origin *[[Sur Empire]] (1540–1556) of [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] origin *[[Safavid dynasty]] (1501–1736) of mixed origin; [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] and [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]], which included numerous intermarriages with [[Georgians|Georgian]], [[Circassians|Circassian]] and [[Pontic Greeks|Pontic Greek]] dignitaries *[[Kalhora dynasty]] (1701-1783) of [[Baloch people|Baloch]] origin *[[Zand dynasty]] (1750–1794) of [[Lurs|Luri]] origin *[[Afsharid dynasty]] (1736–1796) Iranian dynasty of [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] origin *[[Qajar dynasty]] (1789–1925) Iranian dynasty of [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] origin *[[Hotaki dynasty]] (1709–1738) of [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] origin *[[Talysh Khanate]] (1747–1826) of [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin *[[Durrani Empire]] (1747–1862) of [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] origin *[[Talpur]] (1783–1843) of [[Baloch people|Baloch]] origin *[[Barakzai dynasty]] (1826–1973) of [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] origin *[[Pahlavi dynasty]] (1925–1979) of [[Mazanderani people|Mazandaran]] origin
== Former and defunct Iranian governments == *{{flagicon image|QalatFlag.svg}} [[Khanate of Kalat]] (1666–1955) *{{flagicon image|Flag of Persian Socialist Soviet Republic.svg}} [[Soviet Republic of Gilan]] (1920–1921) *{{flagicon image|KhorasanFlag1921.jpg}} [[Autonomous Government of Khorasan]] (1921) *{{flagicon image|Flag of Kingdom of Kurdistan (1922-1924).svg }} [[Kingdom of Kurdistan]] (1921–1924) *{{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg}} [[South Ossetian Autonomous Oblast]] (1922-1990) *{{flagicon image|Red kurdistan 1923 1929.png}} [[Kurdistansky Uyezd]] (1923–1929) *{{flagicon image|Kurdish flag (1932).png}} [[Republic of Ararat]] (1927–1930) *{{flagicon image|Flag of Tajik SSR.svg}} [[Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic]] (1929–1991) *{{flagicon image|Flag of North Ossetian ASSR.svg}} [[North Ossetian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]] (1936–1992) *{{flagicon image|Flag of the Republic of Mahabad.svg}} [[Republic of Mahabad]] (1946–1947) *{{flagicon image|QalatFlag.svg}} [[Baluchistan States Union]] (1952-1955) *{{flagicon image|Flag of the Talysh-Mughan Republic.svg}} [[Talysh-Mughan Autonomous Republic]] (1993)

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of streets by city]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The following is a list of the east–west arterial thoroughfares in the city of [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]]. Numbered avenues run east-west with street numbers increasing to the north. In 1982 a quadrant system was adopted. Quadrant Avenue (1 Avenue; only constructed west of the river), along with Windermere Boulevard and the south leg of [[Anthony Henday Drive]], dividing the north and south quadrants. Edmonton currently has three quadrants: northwest (NW), southwest (SW), and northeast (NE); the vast majority of the city falls within the northwest quadrant. Addresses on 41 Avenue and south have been encouraged to include NW to avoid confusion with addresses in the SW quadrant. {{horizontal TOC|align=center|nonum=yes}} == Artery roads == === 41 Avenue SW === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=41 Avenue SW |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=19.6 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=184 Street SW |junction=[[Calgary Trail & Gateway Boulevard]], 50 Street SW |direction_b=East |terminus_b=Meridian (1) Street
(city limits) }} '''41 Avenue SW''' is a developing major [[arterial road]] in south Edmonton. It is a rural grid road that earned the name 41 Avenue SW when Edmonton expanded southward, and is the boundary between Edmonton and [[Leduc County]].{{cite web | url=http://www.municipalaffairs.alberta.ca/cfml/pdf_search/pdf/CITY/0098/Edmonton_OC_538_81_1982_No6.pdf | title=Order in Council (O.C.) 538/81 | publisher=Province of Alberta | date=June 11, 1981| accessdate=April 10, 2018}} East of Meridian (1) Street, it enters [[Strathcona County]] and continues as Township Road 512. Prior to the 1982 general annexation, the roadway is within Strathcona County, with the Leduc and Strathcona County boundary following Township Road 510, {{convert|2|mi|km|order=flip}} to the south. As part of the annexation, the strip land west of Range Road 234 (Meridian Street when it leaves Edmonton) was transferred to Leduc County. ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Chappelle, Edmonton|Chappelle]] |[[Allard, Edmonton|Allard]] |[[The Orchards at Ellerslie, Edmonton|The Orchards at Ellerslie]] }} {{-}} === Ellerslie Road (9 Avenue SW) === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=Ellerslie Road |alternate_name=9 Avenue SW |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=20.4 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=Windermere Golf & Country Club |junction=[[Terwillegar Drive|Terwillegar Drive (170 Street SW)]], 111 Street SW, [[Calgary Trail & Gateway Boulevard]], 91 Street SW, [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street SW]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=Meridian (1) Street
(city limits) }} '''Ellerslie Road''' (or '''9 Avenue SW''') is a major [[arterial road]] in south [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]]. The original rural area was named Ellerslie by early [[Scottish people|Scottish settlers]], and the name was applied to the local school district by 1895.{{cite web |url=https://www.edmonton.ca/residential_neighbourhoods/Neighbourhoods/EllerslieDemographicProfile.pdf |publisher=City of Edmonton |title=Ellerslie Neighbourhood Profile |date=2014 |accessdate=2016-12-17}} When the rural grid road Township Road 514 was later built, it soon earned the nickname Ellerslie Road. When the Ellerslie area was [[Edmonton annexations#1982 general annexation|annexed by Edmonton]] in 1982, the City of Edmonton extended its own numbering system to existing roads. The 1982 annexation pushed Edmonton`s boundaries south of 1 Avenue, so the city adopted a [[Address (geography)#Quadrants|quadrant system]], renaming Township Road 514 to 9 Avenue SW – though Ellerslie Road has remained the preferred name by Edmontonians. Since 1999, Ellerslie Road has become a major arterial, serving the significant residential development in the extensive string of neighbourhoods across the [[Ellerslie, Edmonton (area)|Ellerslie area]], the [[Heritage Valley, Edmonton|Heritage Valley area]], the [[Windermere, Edmonton (area)|Windermere area]] and the [[Southeast Edmonton|Southeast Edmonton area]] of the city. As part of the [[Windermere Estates, Edmonton|Windermere]] Neighbourhood Structure Plan, Ellerslie Road was realigned near [[Terwillegar Drive|170 Street SW (Terwillegar Drive)]] and becomes ''Hiller Road'' west of the intersection. The bypassed rural road alignment will become a multi use trail.{{cite web|author1=Current Planning Branch|title=Windermere Neighbourhood Structure Plan|url=https://www.edmonton.ca/residential_neighbourhoods/plans_in_effect/Windermere_NSP_Consolidation.pdf|website=City of Edmonton|publisher=Sustainable Development|accessdate=April 10, 2018|page=21|date=April 2014}} ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Windermere Estates, Edmonton|Windermere]] |[[Ambleside, Edmonton|Ambleside]] |[[Rutherford, Edmonton|Rutherford]] |[[MacEwan, Edmonton|MacEwan]] |[[Richford, Edmonton|Richford]] |[[Blackmud Creek, Edmonton|Blackmud Creek]] |[[Blackburne, Edmonton|Blackburne]] |[[Summerside, Edmonton|Summerside]] |[[Ellerslie, Edmonton|Ellerslie]] |[[Walker, Edmonton|Walker]] |[[Charlesworth, Edmonton|Charlesworth]] }} {{-}} === 23 Avenue NW === {{Infobox street |marker_image=[[Image:23 Avenue copy.png|200px]] |name=23 Avenue |alternate_name= |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=16.4 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=[[Terwillegar Drive]] / Riverbend Road |junction=111 Street, [[Calgary Trail & Gateway Boulevard]], 91 Street, [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=Tamarack Boulevard |embedded= }} {{main article|23 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''23 Avenue NW''' is a major arterial road in south Edmonton. It runs through several neighbourhoods including [[Mill Woods]] and [[The Meadows, Edmonton|The Meadows]], and commercial areas including [[South Edmonton Common]], and [[Mill Woods Town Centre Mall]]. {{-}} === 34 Avenue NW === {{Infobox street |marker_image=[[Image:34 Avenue.png|200px]] |name=34 Avenue NW |alternate_name=34 Avenue |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=9.7 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=119 Street |junction=[[111 Street, Edmonton|111 Street]], [[Calgary Trail]], [[Gateway Boulevard]], 91 Street, 66 Street, [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=34 Street / Silver Berry Road }} '''34 Avenue NW''' is a major arterial road in south [[Edmonton]]. It mostly runs through residential neighbourhoods, with the exception of an area between 91 Street and Calgary Trail, sometimes called "[[auto row]]", due to all the car dealerships along the route. It provides a through route for [[Mill Woods]], and ends in the neighbourhood of [[Silver Berry, Edmonton|Silver Berry]], turning into Silver Berry Road. ;Neighbourhoods {{Columns |col1={{bulleted list |[[Westbrook Estates, Edmonton|Westbrook Estates]] |[[Sweet Grass, Edmonton|Sweet Grass]] |[[Greenfield, Edmonton|Greenfield]] |[[Steinhauer, Edmonton|Steinhauer]] |[[Duggan, Edmonton|Duggan]] |[[Richfield, Edmonton|Richfield]] |[[Tipaskan, Edmonton|Tipaskan]] |[[Kameyosek, Edmonton|Kameyosek]]}} |col2={{bulleted list |[[Lee Ridge, Edmonton|Lee Ridge]] |[[Hillview, Edmonton|Hillview]] |[[Tawa, Edmonton|Tawa]] |[[Weinlos, Edmonton|Weinlos]] |[[Minchau, Edmonton|Minchau]] |[[Bisset, Edmonton|Bisset]] |[[Silver Berry, Edmonton|Silver Berry]]}} }} {{-}} === 51 Avenue / Roper Road === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=51 Avenue / Roper Road |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=10.2 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=125 Street / 51A Avenue |junction=122 Street, [[111 Street, Edmonton|111 Street]], [[Calgary Trail]], [[Gateway Boulevard]], 91 Street, [[75 Street, Edmonton|75 Street]], [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=36 Street }} '''51 Avenue''' and '''Roper Road''' is a major arterial road in south [[Edmonton]]. It runs north of [[Whitemud Drive]], passing through residential neighbourhoods west of [[Calgary Trail]], passing the north side of [[Southgate Centre]], and industrial neighbourhoods to the east. It currently ends at 38 Street with a future extension proposed to 34 Street. ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Lansdowne, Edmonton|Lansdowne]] |[[Malmo Plains, Edmonton|Malmo Plains]] |[[Lendrum Place, Edmonton|Lendrum Place]] |[[Pleasantview, Edmonton|Pleasantview]] |[[Empire Park, Edmonton|Empire Park]] }} {{-}} === 61/63 Avenue / Argyll Road === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=61/63 Avenue / Argyll Road |alternate_name=Allandale Road |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=6.8 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=113 Street / 60 Avenue |junction=[[111 Street, Edmonton|111 Street]], [[104 Street, Edmonton|104 Street]], [[Gateway Boulevard]], 91 Street, [[75 Street, Edmonton|75 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[Sherwood Park Freeway]] }} '''61/63 Avenue''' and '''Argyll Road''' is a major arterial road in south Edmonton. It undergoes a number of name changes through its length. The majority of the artery travels west-east, however the named portion travel from south-west to north-east. The route begins as 61 Avenue, near the [[University of Alberta]] south campus, where it turns north and becomes 113 Street at the intersection with 60 Avenue. The [[Edmonton Light Rail Transit|LRT]] travels alongside 61 Avenue between 113 Street to [[111 Street, Edmonton|111 Street]], where it continues south. It continues east until it transitions northeast to 63 Avenue, with the short south-west to north-east section called '''Allendale Road'''. East of [[104 Street, Edmonton|104 Street (Calgary Trail)]] the roadway goes under the name of 63 Avenue, dividing between residential and industrial areas. East of 86 Street, the roadway travels south-west to north-east and becomes Argyll Road, ending at the [[Sherwood Park Freeway]]. ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Lendrum Place, Edmonton|Lendrum Place]] |[[Parkallen, Edmonton|Parkallen]] |[[Pleasantview, Edmonton|Pleasantview]] |[[Allendale, Edmonton|Allendale]] |[[Hazeldean, Edmonton|Hazeldean]] |[[Argyll, Edmonton|Argyll]] |[[Avonmore, Edmonton|Avonmore]] }} {{-}} === Whyte (82) Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=Whyte Avenue |alternate_name=82 Avenue |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=16.4 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=114 Street / [[University Avenue (Edmonton)|University Avenue]] |junction=[[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]], [[104 Street, Edmonton|104 Street]], [[Gateway Boulevard]], [[75 Street, Edmonton|75 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[Sherwood Park Freeway]] }} {{main article|Whyte (82) Avenue}} '''Whyte (82) Avenue''' is an arterial road in south-central Edmonton. It became the main street of the City of [[Strathcona, Alberta|Strathcona]] as it formed, and now runs through [[Old Strathcona]]. Whyte (82) Avenue is part of a {{convert|40|km|mi|adj=mid|-long}} continuous roadway that runs through [[Sherwood Park]], Edmonton, and [[St. Albert, Alberta|St. Albert]] that includes [[Wye Road]], [[Sherwood Park Freeway]], portions of [[University Avenue (Edmonton)|University Avenue]] and [[Saskatchewan Drive]], [[Groat Road]], and [[St. Albert Trail]]. {{-}} === 87 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=87 Avenue |alternate_name=Webber Greens Drive, Buena Vista Road |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=10.0 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=Winterburn Road (215 Street) |junction=[[Anthony Henday Drive]], 178 Street, [[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]], 159 Street, 156 Street, 149 Street, 142 Street |direction_b=East |terminus_b=132 Street }} '''87 Avenue''' is a major [[arterial road]] in west [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]]. It runs parallel, and services the residential areas, north of [[Whitemud Drive]]. A number of Edmonton landmarks line 87 Avenue, including [[West Edmonton Mall]], [[Misericordia Community Hospital]], and Meadowlark Health and Shopping Centre. West of [[Anthony Henday Drive]] it becomes ''Webber Greens Drive'' where it terminates at Winterburn Road (215 Street), while east of 142 Street it becomes ''Buena Vista Road'' enroute to the [[Valley Zoo]]. 87 Avenue was identified as the alignment of the western phase of the [[Valley Line (Edmonton)|Valley Line]] of the [[Edmonton Light Rail Transit|Edmonton LRT]] between 159 Street and the Lewis Farms transit centre (just west of Anthony Henday Drive), serving West Edmonton Mall.{{cite web|title=Valley Line - West|url=https://www.edmonton.ca/projects_plans/transit/valley-line-west.aspx|website=City of Edmonton|accessdate=April 16, 2018|language=en}} No timeline has been set for the construction of the west phase. A separate, short segment of 87 Avenue runs between [[Groat Road]] and [[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]], serving the [[University of Alberta]]. ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Webber Greens, Edmonton|Webber Greens]] |[[Suder Greens, Edmonton|Suder Greens]] |[[Aldergrove, Edmonton|Aldergrove]] |[[Belmead, Edmonton|Belmead]] |[[Thorncliff, Edmonton|Thorncliff]] |[[Summerlea, Edmonton|Summerlea]] |[[West Meadowlark Park, Edmonton|West Meadowlark Park]] |[[Elmwood, Edmonton|Elmwood]] |[[Meadowlark Park, Edmonton|Meadowlark Park]] |[[Lynnwood, Edmonton|Lynnwood]] |[[Jasper Park, Edmonton|Jasper Park]] |[[Parkview, Edmonton|Parkview]] |[[Laurier Heights, Edmonton|Laurier Heights]] }} {{-}} === 97/98 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=97/98 Avenue |alternate_name= |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=6.6 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=111 Street |junction=[[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]], [[105 Street, Edmonton|105 Street]], Connors Road, Scona Road, [[75 Street, Edmonton|75 Street]], [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=49 Street }} {{main article|97/98/101 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''97/98 Avenue''' is a major arterial road in central and east Edmonton. 97 Avenue begins as a residential street at 111 Street and becomes an arterial road at [[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]] at the northern approach to the [[High Level Bridge (Edmonton)|High Level Bridge]]. It passes passes underneath the grounds of the [[Alberta Legislature Building|Alberta Legislature]] and crosses the [[North Saskatchewan River]] via the [[James MacDonald Bridge]], where it becomes 98 Avenue. It continues east to [[Capilano Mall (Edmonton)|Capilano Mall]] where the roadway splits so that the main roadway turns northeast along Terrace Road (eventually becoming 101 Avenue and Baseline Road) while 98 Avenue continues east along the southern perimeter of Capilano Mall as a [[collector road]]. East of [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]], 98 Avenue becomes a local road and ends at 49 Street. {{-}} === 100 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=100 Avenue |alternate_name= |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=6.6 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=[[Stony Plain Road]] |junction=[[Anthony Henday Drive]], [[184 Street, Edmonton|184 Street]], 178 Street, [[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]], 156 Street, 149 Street |direction_b=East |terminus_b=146 Street }} {{main article|100 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''100 Avenue''' is a major arterial road in central and west Edmonton. The road starts as [[Stony Plain Road]] ([[Alberta Highway 16A|Highway 16A]]), and as it approaches [[Anthony Henday Drive]] it separates into westbound and eastbound one-way streets. The westbound lanes occupy Stony Plain Road, while the eastbound street becomes 100 Avenue. It continues east and becomes a [[two-way street]] at 163 Street. At 149 Street, 100 Avenue becomes a residential street while inbound traffic to [[Downtown Edmonton|downtown]] is directed to take 156 Street to Stony Plain Road; 100 Avenue ends at 146 Street. 100 Avenue begins again after [[Groat Road]] as a local road (named Victoria Park Road west of 116 Street), and continues through Downtown Edmonton. {{-}} === 101 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=101 Avenue |alternate_name= |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=3.9 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=84 Street |junction=[[Wayne Gretzky Drive|Wayne Gretzky Drive / 75 Street]], [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[34 Street, Edmonton|34 Street]] (city limits) }} {{main article|97/98/101 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''101 Avenue''' is a major arterial road in east Edmonton. 101 Avenue begins at 84 Street as a residential collector road to Terrace Road at [[Capilano Mall (Edmonton)|Capilano Mall]]. 101 Avenue continues east from Terrace Road, with through traffic following 101 Avenue – Terrace Road to 98 Avenue. At 34 Street, 101 Avenue enters [[Strathcona County]] and becomes Baseline Road. 101 Avenue is the alignment for two other major named roadways in Edmonton; [[Jasper Avenue]] through downtown and the portion [[Stony Plain Road]] west of 149 Street. {{-}} === 102 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=102 Avenue |alternate_name= |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=3.9 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=[[Stony Plain Road]] |junction=[[124 Street, Edmonton|124 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=111 Street }} {{main article|Stony Plain Road}} '''102 Avenue''' short arterial road west of downtown Edmonton. It begins at [[Stony Plain Road]] east of 142 Street (through traffic follows westbound Stony Plain Road) and travels east. At [[124 Street, Edmonton|124 Street]], 102 Avenue becomes a residential street while inbound traffic to [[Downtown Edmonton|downtown]] is directed to take 124 Street to [[Jasper Avenue]]; 102 Avenue ends at 111 Street. 102 Avenue begins again at [[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]] and passes through downtown Edmonton, ending at a five-way intersection at Jasper Avenue and 95 Street. {{-}} === 103A/104 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=103A/104 Avenue |alternate_name= |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=3.7 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=121 Street / [[Stony Plain Road]] |junction=[[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]], [[105 Street, Edmonton|105 Street]], 101 Street, [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[Jasper Avenue]] }} {{main article|Stony Plain Road}} '''103A/104 Avenue''' short arterial road in central Edmonton. 104 Avenue begins at 121 Street (westbound traffic continues as [[Stony Plain Road]]) and continues east through [[Downtown Edmonton]] along the former downtown alignment of the [[Canadian National Railway]]. At 101 Street, the roadway becomes 103A Avenue and ends at the intersection of [[Jasper Avenue]] and 92 Street. It passes by major landmarks such as [[MacEwan University]] City Centre Campus, [[Rogers Place]], the [[CN Tower (Edmonton)|CN Tower]], [[Edmonton City Hall]], and the [[Royal Alberta Museum]]. {{-}} === 106 Avenue / Rowland Road === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=106 Avenue / Rowland Road |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=5.2 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=95 Street |junction=84 Street, [[Wayne Gretzky Drive]], [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=40 Street }} '''106 Avenue / Rowland Road''' is a short arterial road in east Edmonton. The roadway begins as ''Rowland Road'' at 95 Street, two blocks south of [[Jasper Avenue]], and travels east, crossing the [[North Saskatchewan River]] along the [[Dawson Bridge]]. After leaving the river valley, it becomes ''106 Avenue'' at 84 Street and travels east through mature residential neighbourhoods. At [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]], it 106 Avenue downgrades to a residential street and ends at 40 Street. Rowland Road and 106 Avenue were once designated as part of the highway which headed due east from Edmonton as it connected Jasper Avenue to [[97/98/101 Avenue, Edmonton|101 Avenue]]. Along with 79 Street (later 84 Street) the route was part of [[Alberta Highway 15|Highway 15]] from the 1930s to 1940;{{cite map|publisher = Department of Public Works|year = 1932|title = Alberta Official Road Map|url=http://libguides.ucalgary.ca/c.php?g=382137&p=2761183}} [[Alberta Highway 16|Highway 16]] from the 1940 to 1953;{{cite map|publisher = Department of Public Works|year = 1940|title = Alberta Official Road Map|url = https://c8.staticflickr.com/9/8662/30161696495_c10d409dae_o.jpg|inset = Edmonton}} and [[Alberta Highway 16A|Highway 16A]] from the 1953 the 1970s.{{cite map|author = The H.M. Gousha Company|publisher = The Shell Oil Company|year = 1956|title = Shell Map of British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba|url = http://www.davidrumsey.com/luna/servlet/workspace/handleMediaPlayer?lunaMediaId=RUMSEY~8~1~212317~5500351|inset = Edmonton}} ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Aldergrove, Edmonton|Aldergrove]] |[[Belmead, Edmonton|Belmead]] |[[Thorncliff, Edmonton|Thorncliff]] |[[Summerlea, Edmonton|Summerlea]] |[[West Meadowlark Park, Edmonton|West Meadowlark Park]] |[[Elmwood, Edmonton|Elmwood]] |[[Meadowlark Park, Edmonton|Meadowlark Park]] |[[Lynnwood, Edmonton|Lynnwood]] |[[Jasper Park, Edmonton|Jasper Park]] |[[Parkview, Edmonton|Parkview]] |[[Laurier Heights, Edmonton|Laurier Heights]] }} {{-}} === 107 Avenue / Stadium Road === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=107 Avenue / Stadium Road |alternate_name=Avenue of Nations, 107A Avenue |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=12.2 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=''dead end'' west of 186 Street |junction=[[184 Street, Edmonton|184 Street]], [[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]], [[Mayfield Road, Edmonton|Mayfield Road]], 156 Street, 142 Street, [[Groat Road]], [[124 Street, Edmonton|124 Street]], [[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]], [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[112 Avenue, Edmonton|112 Avenue]] / 86 Street }} {{main article|107 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''107 Avenue''' a major arterial road in central Edmonton. It serves Edmonton's west side industrial district, the old town of [[Jasper Place]], the multicultural area north of [[Downtown Edmonton]]. The portion between 95 and 116 Streets has been dubbed ''Avenue of Nations''. It becomes 107A Avenue at 101 Street and becomes Stadium Road at 92 Street, where it passes [[Commonwealth Stadium (Edmonton)|Commonwealth Stadium]] and it continues as 86 Street north of [[112 Avenue, Edmonton|112 Avenue]]. {{-}} === 111/112 Avenue / Mayfield Road === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=111/112 Avenue / Mayfield Road |alternate_name=Norwood Boulevard |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=14.3 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=[[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]] / [[Stony Plain Road]] |junction=163 Street, 156 Street, 149 Street, [[Groat Road]], [[124 Street, Edmonton|124 Street]], [[109 Street, Edmonton|109 Street]], [[Kingsway, Edmonton|Kingsway]], [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]], 82 Street, [[Wayne Gretzky Drive]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] }} {{main article|111/112 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''Mayfield Road''' and '''111/112 Avenue''' a major arterial road in central Edmonton. The roadway begins at the [[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]] / [[Stony Plain Road]] [[split intersection]] and travels northeast to 163 Street and becomes 111 Avenue, passing a number of landmarks including the [[Telus World of Science (Edmonton)|Telus World of Science]], [[Westmount Centre]], [[Kingsway Mall]], [[Royal Alexandra Hospital, Edmonton|Royal Alexandra Hospital]], and [[Glenrose Rehabilitation Hospital]]. The portion between 101 Street and 90 Street has the name ''Norwood Boulevard'' in addition to 111 Avenue. At 90 Street the roadway becomes 112 Avenue and passes [[Commonwealth Stadium (Edmonton)|Commonwealth Stadium]]; 112 Avenue ends at [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]]. 111 Avenue also has a western segment which continues west of Mayfield Road. It is a [[collector road]] which originates at [[Anthony Henday Drive]], passes through the northwestern industrial areas, and ends at 163 Street just north its intersection with 111 Avenue / Mayfield Road. {{-}} === 118 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=118 Avenue |alternate_name=Alberta Avenue |part_of= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=16.1 |length_ref= |length_notes=West: {{cvt|7.6|km}}
East: {{cvt|8.5|km}} |direction_a=West |terminus_a=[[184 Street, Edmonton|184 Street]] |junction=[[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]], 156 Street, 149 Street, [[St. Albert Trail]] / [[Groat Road]], 127 Street, [[124 Street, Edmonton|124 Street]], 121 Street / [[Kingsway, Edmonton|Kingsway]]
[[Princess Elizabeth Avenue]], [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]], 82 Street, [[Wayne Gretzky Drive]], 66 Street, [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[Yellowhead Trail]] / [[Victoria Trail]] }} {{main article|118 Avenue, Edmonton}} '''118 Avenue''' is the designated name of two major [[arterial road]]s in central Edmonton, separated by the [[Edmonton City Centre (Blatchford Field) Airport|Edmonton City Centre Airport]]. The segments are connected by [[Kingsway, Edmonton|Kingsway]] and [[Princess Elizabeth Avenue]]. It passes several major landmarks including [[Northern Alberta Institute of Technology|Northern Alberta Institute of Technology (NAIT)]], [[Northlands]] and [[Northlands Coliseum]]. 118 Avenue is also known as ''Alberta Avenue'' between 109 Street and [[Wayne Gretzky Drive]] and is part of the ''Alberta Avenue-Eastwood Business Revitalization Zone''. {{-}} === 127 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=127 Avenue |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=6.5 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=127 Street |junction=113A Street, [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]], 82 Street |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[Fort Road, Edmonton|Fort Road]] }} '''127 Avenue''' is a major in north Edmonton which runs parallel [[Canadian National|CN Rail]] Yards opposite to [[Yellowhead Trail]] ([[Alberta Highway 16|Highway 16]]). It is an arterial road between 127 Street and 82 Street and a [[collector road]] to the east. 127 Street has a [[right-in/right-out]] intersection at [[Fort Road, Edmonton|Fort Road]] adjacent its intersection with 66 Street. ;Neighbourhoods {{bulleted list |[[Calder, Edmonton|Calder]] |[[Lauderdale, Edmonton|Lauderdale]] |[[Killarney, Edmonton|Killarney]] |[[Balwin, Edmonton|Balwin]] }} {{-}} === 137 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=137 Avenue |alternate_name=LeClair Way |location=[[St. Albert, Alberta|St. Albert]], [[Edmonton]] |length_km=18.4 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=[[Ray Gibbon Drive]] |junction=[[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]], 156 Street, 149 Street, [[St. Albert Trail]], 127 Street, Castle Downs Road, [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]], 82 Street, 66 Street, [[Fort Road, Edmonton|Fort Road]] / [[Manning Drive]], [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]], [[Victoria Trail]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=20 Street NW }} '''137 Avenue''' is a major arterial road in north Edmonton. This road travels through residential, industrial and commercial areas, including shopping and entertainment centres and districts. The road starts at [[Ray Gibbon Drive]], in southwest [[St. Albert, Alberta|St. Albert]] named '''LeClair Way'''. After entering Edmonton, at Sir Winston Churchill Avenue, it passes under [[Anthony Henday Drive]], and continues through north Edmonton. 137 Avenue passes Golden West Golf Course and St. Albert Trail Golf Course between [[170 Street, Edmonton|170 Street]] and [[St. Albert Trail|St. Albert Trail]] (Mark Messier Trail / [[Alberta Highway 2|Highway 2]]). Past there is the St. Albert Trail and [[Pembina, Edmonton|Pembina]] commercial areas, and [[Castle Downs, Edmonton|Castle Downs]] neighbourhood. The avenue between Castle Downs Road and [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]] forms the southern boundary of the old [[CFB Griesbach]]. At 97 Street ([[Alberta Highway 28|Highway 28]]) the road passes through the northgate commercial area with [[Northgate Centre]] and [[North Town Centre]], and at 66 Street it passes [[Londonderry Mall]]. 137 Avenue again passes through commercial districts at [[Manning Drive]] and [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] ([[Alberta Highway 15|Highway 15]]), the latter being called [[Clareview Town Centre, Edmonton|Clareview Town Centre]], and between which the [[Edmonton Light Rail Transit|LRT]] passes over. One final commercial area is located by [[Victoria Trail]] before 137 Avenue turns into 20 Street NW at [[North Saskatchewan River valley parks system|Hermitage Park]]. ;Neighbourhoods {{Columns |col1={{bulleted list |[[Pembina, Edmonton|Pembina]] |[[Wellington, Edmonton|Wellington]] |[[Baranow, Edmonton|Baranow]] |[[Kensington, Edmonton|Kensington]] |[[Carlisle, Edmonton|Carlisle]] |[[Rosslyn, Edmonton|Rosslyn]] |[[Griesbach, Edmonton|Griesbach]] |[[Northmount, Edmonton|Northmount]] |[[Glengarry, Edmonton|Glengarry]]}} |col2={{bulleted list |[[Delwood, Edmonton|Delwood]] |[[Kildare, Edmonton|Kildare]] |[[Belvedere, Edmonton|Belvedere]] |[[York, Edmonton|York]] |[[Sifton Park, Edmonton|Sifton Park]] |[[Clareview Town Centre, Edmonton|Clareview Town Centre]] |[[Belmont, Edmonton|Belmont]] |[[Kernohan, Edmonton|Kernohan]] |[[Bannerman, Edmonton|Bannerman]]}} }} {{-}} === 153 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=153 Avenue |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=15.1 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=142 Street |junction=127 Street, Castle Downs Road, [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]], 82 Street, 66 Street, [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]], [[Manning Drive]], [[Victoria Trail]], [[Anthony Henday Drive]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=Meridian (1) Street }} 153 Avenue is a major arterial road in north Edmonton. It runs through the residential areas of north Edmonton, running from 142 Street in the west to Meridian (1) Street, just east of [[Anthony Henday Drive]]. 153 Avenue also exists as a small rural grid road between a dead end east of Anthony Henday Drive and 17 Street NE. ;Neighbourhoods {{Columns |col1={{bulleted list |Rampart (Industrial) |[[Carlton, Edmonton|Carlton]] |[[Oxford, Edmonton|Oxford]] |[[Cumberland, Edmonton|Cumberland]] |[[Baranow, Edmonton|Baranow]] |[[Dunluce, Edmonton|Dunluce]] |[[Caernarvon, Edmonton|Caernarvon]] |[[Beaumaris, Edmonton|Beaumaris]] |[[Griesbach, Edmonton|Griesbach]]}} |col2={{bulleted list |[[Eaux Claires, Edmonton|Eaux Claires]] |[[Evansdale, Edmonton|Evansdale]] |[[Belle Rive, Edmonton|Belle Rive]] |[[Mayliewan, Edmonton|Mayliewan]] |[[Ozerna, Edmonton|Ozerna]] |[[Kilkenny, Edmonton|Kilkenny]] |[[McLeod, Edmonton|McLeod]] |[[Matt Berry, Edmonton|Matt Berry]]}} |col3={{bulleted list |[[Hollick-Kenyon, Edmonton|Hollick-Kenyon]] |[[Casselman, Edmonton|Casselman]] |[[Miller, Edmonton|Miller]] |[[Brintnell, Edmonton|Brintnell]] |[[Ebbers, Edmonton|Ebbers]] |[[Gorman, Edmonton|Gorman]] |[[Kirkness, Edmonton|Kirkness]] |[[Fraser, Edmonton|Fraser]]}} }} {{-}} === 167 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=167 Avenue |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=9.7 |length_ref= |length_notes=West: {{cvt|3.4|km}}
East: {{cvt|6.3|km}} |direction_a=West |terminus_a=142 Street |junction=127 Street, 112 Street
[[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]] / Castle Downs Road, 82 Street, 66 Street, [[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street]] |direction_b=East |terminus_b=[[Manning Drive]] }} 167 Avenue is the designated name of two major arterial roads in north Edmonton, separated by the [[Castle Downs, Edmonton|Castle Downs]] neighbourhood. The western segment runs between 142 Street and 112 Street while the eastern segment runs between [[97 Street, Edmonton|97 Street]] and [[Manning Drive]]; the two segments are connected by 112 Street and Castle Downs Road. There is also a rural section between 34 Street NW and the [[North Saskatchewan River]], segmented by [[Anthony Henday Drive]]. ;Neighbourhoods {{Columns |col1=Western segment {{bulleted list |[[Carlton, Edmonton|Carlton]] |[[The Palisades, Edmonton|The Palisades]] |[[Oxford, Edmonton|Oxford]] |[[Rapperswill, Edmonton|Rapperswill]] |[[Dunluce, Edmonton|Dunluce]] |[[Canossa, Edmonton|Canossa]]}} |col2=Eastern segment {{bulleted list |[[Eaux Claires, Edmonton|Eaux Claires]] |[[Lago Lindo, Edmonton|Lago Lindo]] |[[Klarvatten, Edmonton|Klarvatten]] |[[Belle Rive, Edmonton|Belle Rive]] |[[Mayliewan, Edmonton|Mayliewan]] |[[Schonsee, Edmonton|Schonsee]] |[[Ozerna, Edmonton|Ozerna]] |[[Matt Berry, Edmonton|Matt Berry]] |[[McConachie, Edmonton|McConachie]] |[[Hollick-Kenyon, Edmonton|Hollick-Kenyon]] |[[Brintnell, Edmonton|Brintnell]]}} }} {{-}} === 259 Avenue === {{Infobox street |marker_image= |name=259 Avenue |part_of={{jct|province=AB|Hwy|37}} |alternate_name= |location=[[Edmonton]] |length_km=8.1 |length_ref= |length_notes= |direction_a=West |terminus_a=50 Street NW (city limits) |junction=[[Alberta Highway 28A|Highway 28A]] (17 Street NE) |direction_b=East |terminus_b=33 Street NE (city limits) }} {{main article|Alberta Highway 37}} '''259 Avenue''' is the designated name of Highway 37 along Edmonton's northernmost city boundary between Range Road 241 ([[50 Street, Edmonton|50 Street NW]]) and Range Road 232 (33 Street NE). The rural highway does not enter city limits, as the city's boundary is on the south side of the [[right of way]]. {{-}} == See also == * [[List of streets in Edmonton]] * [[Transportation in Edmonton]] == References == {{reflist|2|refs= {{cite map|author=City of Edmonton|title=Edmonton SLIM Maps|url=https://maps.edmonton.ca/|website=City of Edmonton}} {{google maps|title=Edmonton|url=https://www.google.ca/maps/@53.5320604,-113.5196165,11z?hl=en|accessdate=April 16, 2018}} }} {{Streets in Edmonton|state=expand}} [[Category:Roads in Edmonton| ]] [[Category:Edmonton-related lists|Avenues]] [[Category:Lists of streets by city|Edmonton]]

page.title: List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions

It is based on data for [[carbon dioxide]], [[methane]], [[nitrous oxide]], [[perfluorocarbon]], [[hydrofluorocarbon]], and [[sulfur hexafluoride]] emissions compiled by the [[World Resources Institute]].{{Cite web |date= |title=Climate Analysis Indicators Tool (CAIT) Version 2.0. (Washington, DC: World Resources Institute, 2014) |author= |publisher=World Resources Institute |url=http://cait2.wri.org/ |accessdate=2017-06-12}} The emissions data shown below do not include [[Land use, land-use change and forestry|land-use change and forestry]]. Because individual countries vary vastly in size and population, consider referring to [[List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions per capita]] which may be more relevant. == List of countries by 2014 emissions == {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" |- !
