[[Modern South Arabian languages|South Arabian]] |religion = [[Sunni Islam]] |capital = Aden |largest city = Aden |government_type = [[Federal state|Federal]] [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] [[one-party]] [[socialist state|socialist]] [[republic]] |title_leader = [[General Secretary of the Yemeni Socialist Party|General Secretary]] |leader1 = Abdul Fattah Ismail |year_leader1 = 1978–1980 |leader2 = Ali Nasir Muhammad |year_leader2 = 1980–1986 |leader3 = Ali Salim al-Beidh |year_leader3 = 1986–1990 |title_representative = [[President of South Yemen|President]] |representative1 = Qahtan al-Shaabi |year_representative1 = 1967–1969 (first) |representative2 = [[Haidar Abu Bakr al-Attas|Haidar al-Attas]] |year_representative2 = 1986–1990 (last) |title_deputy = [[Prime Minister of South Yemen|Prime Minister]] |deputy1 = Faysal al-Shaabi |year_deputy1 = 1969 |deputy2 = Muhammad Ali Haitham |year_deputy2 = 1969–1971 |deputy3 = Ali Nasir Muhammad |year_deputy3 = 1971–1985 |deputy4 = [[Haidar Abu Bakr al-Attas|Haidar al-Attas]] |year_deputy4 = 1985–1986 |deputy5 = Yasin Said Numan |year_deputy5 = 1986–1990 |legislature = [[Supreme People's Council (South Yemen)|Supreme People's Council]] |era = Cold War |event_start = Independence declared |date_start = 30 November |year_start = 1967 |event1 = [[United Nations member states|UN membership]] |date_event1 = 14 December 1967 |event2 = Constitution adopted |date_event2 = 31 October 1978 |event_end = [[Unification of Yemen|Unification]] |date_end = 22 May |year_end = 1990 |stat_year1 = 1990 |stat_area1 = 360133 |stat_pop1 = 2585484 |currency = [[South Yemeni dinar]] |calling_code = 967 |footnotes = [[ISO 3166-1]] = South
[[ISO 3166-3]] = Yemen }} '''South Yemen''' is the common English name for the '''People's Democratic Republic of Yemen''' ({{lang-ar|جمهورية اليمن الديمقراطية الشعبية}} ''{{transl|ar|Jumhūriyat al-Yaman ad-Dīmuqrāṭīyah ash-Sha'bīyah}}''), which existed from 1967 to 1990 as a state in the [[Middle East]] in the southern and eastern provinces of the present-day [[Yemen|Republic of Yemen]], including the island of [[Socotra]]. It was also referred to as '''Democratic Yemen''' or '''Yemen (Aden)'''. South Yemen's origins can be traced to 1874 with the creation of the British [[colony of Aden]] and the [[Aden Protectorate]], which consisted of two-thirds of the present-day Yemen. However, Aden became a province within the [[British Raj]] in 1937. After the collapse of Aden Protectorate, the [[Aden Emergency|state of emergency]] was declared in 1963 when the [[National Liberation Front (South Yemen)|National Liberation Front]] (NLF) and the [[Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen]] (FLOSY) rebelled against British rule. The [[Federation of South Arabia]] and the [[Protectorate of South Arabia]] merged to become South Yemen on 30 November 1967 and became a [[Marxism|Marxist]] [[socialist state|socialist]] [[republic]] in 1970 supported by the [[Soviet Union]]. Despite its efforts to bring stability into the region, it was involved in a [[South Yemen Civil War|brief civil war]] in 1986. With the [[Revolutions of 1989|collapse of communism]], South Yemen was unified with the [[Yemen Arab Republic]] (commonly known as "[[North Yemen]]") on 22 May 1990, to form the present-day Yemen. After four years, however, South Yemen declared its secession from the north, which resulted in the north occupying south Yemen and the [[1994 civil war in Yemen|1994 civil war]]. Another [[South Yemen insurgency|attempt to restore South Yemen]] continues on since 2017. ==History== {{main|History of Yemen}} ===British rule=== In 1838, Sultan [[Muhsin Bin Fadl]] of the state of [[Sultanate of Lahej|Lahej]] ceded 194 km² (75 sq. miles) including [[Aden Province|Aden]] to the [[British Empire|British]]. On 19 January 1839, the [[British East India Company]] landed [[Royal Marines]] at Aden to occupy the territory and stop attacks by [[pirate]]s against British shipping to [[India]]. It then became an important trading hub between [[British India]] and the [[Red Sea]], and following the opening of the [[Suez canal]] in 1869, it became a [[coal]]ing station for ships en route to [[India]]. Aden was ruled as part of [[British India]] until 1937, when the city of Aden became the [[Colony of Aden]]. The Aden [[hinterland]] and [[Hadhramaut]] to the east formed the remainder of what would become South Yemen and was not administered directly by Aden but were tied to Britain by treaties of protection with local rulers of traditional polities that, together, became known as the [[Aden Protectorate]]. [[Economic development]] was largely centered in Aden, and while the city flourished, the states of the Aden Protectorate [[Economic stagnation|stagnated]]. ===Decolonization=== In 1963, Aden and much of the Protectorate were joined to form the [[Federation of South Arabia]] with the remaining states that declined to join, mainly in Hadhramaut, forming the separate [[Protectorate of South Arabia]]. Both of these polities were still tied to Britain with promises of total independence in 1968. Two [[nationalism|nationalist]] groups, the [[Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen]] (FLOSY) and the [[National Liberation Front (Yemen)|National Liberation Front]] (NLF), began an armed struggle known as the [[Aden Emergency]] on 14 October 1963 against British control and, with the temporary closure of the [[Suez Canal]] in 1967, the British began to withdraw. One faction, NLF, was invited to the Geneva Talks to sign the independence agreement with the British. However, Britain - who during its occupation of Aden signed several treaties of protection with the local sheikhdoms and emirates of the [[Federation of South Arabia]] - excluded them in the talks and thus the agreement stated "...the handover of the territory of South Arabia to the (Yemeni) NLF...". Southern Yemen became independent as the People's Republic of Southern Yemen on 30 November 1967, and the National Liberation Front consolidated its control in the country. In June 1969, a radical [[Marxist]] wing of the NLF gained power and on 1 December 1970, reorganized the country into the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen (PDRY). Subsequently, all political parties were amalgamated into the National Liberation Front, renamed the [[Yemeni Socialist Party]], which became the only legal party. The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen established close ties with the [[Soviet Union]], the [[People's Republic of China]], [[Cuba]], and the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|Palestinian Liberation Organization]]. [[East Germany]]'s constitution of 1968 even served as a kind of blueprint for the PDRY's first constitution.{{Cite book|url=http://www.transcript-verlag.de/978-3-8376-3225-5/a-spectre-is-haunting-arabia|title=A Spectre is haunting Arabia - How the Germans brought their Marxism to Yemen|last=Müller|first=Miriam M.|publisher=Transcript|year=2015|isbn=978-3-8376-3225-5|location=Bielefeld|pages=257ff}} The major communist powers assisted in the building of the PDRY's [[armed forces]]. Strong support from Moscow resulted in Soviet naval forces gaining access to naval facilities in South Yemen. ===Disputes with North Yemen=== {{Infobox military conflict | conflict = North Yemen–South Yemen Border Conflict of 1972 | partof = the [[Cold War]] | image = Divided Yemen.svg | image_size = 300px | caption = North & South Yemen | date = 1972 | place = North Yemen–South Yemen border | coordinates = | map_type = | map_relief = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_marksize = | map_caption = | map_label = | territory = [[Status quo ante bellum|None]] | result = Stalemate | status = | combatants_header = | combatant1 = {{Flag|North Yemen|23px}} '''Supported by:'''
{{flag|Saudi Arabia|1938|23px}}
{{flag|Jordan}}
{{flagicon|United States|23px}} [[United States of America|United States]]
{{flag|Republic of China|23px}}
{{flag|United Kingdom}}
{{flag|West Germany}} | combatant2 = [[FIle:Flag of South Yemen.svg|25px]] South Yemen
[[National Democratic Front (Yemen)|National Democratic Front]]
'''Supported by:'''
{{flag|Soviet Union|1955|23px}}
{{flag|Cuba|23px}}
{{flag|East Germany|23px}}
{{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovakia]]
{{flagicon|Libya|1972}} [[Libyan Arab Republic|Libya]] | commander1 = {{Flagicon|North Yemen|23px}} [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] | commander2 = {{Flagicon image|Presidential standard of South Yemen 1967-1990.svg|23px}} [[Abdel Fattah Ismail]] | units1 = | units2 = | strength1 = | strength2 = 24,000 | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | notes = | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Insurgencies in Yemen}} }} [[File:Arabia 1914.png|thumbnail|The Arabian peninsula in 1914]] Unlike the early decades of [[East Germany]] and [[West Germany]], [[North Korea]] and [[South Korea]], or [[North Vietnam]] and [[South Vietnam]], [[North Yemen]] (YAR) and South Yemen (PDRY) remained relatively friendly, though relations were often strained. Fighting broke out in 1972, and a short-lived, small proxy border conflict was resolved with negotiations, where it was declared unification would eventually occur.{{citation |title=North and South Yemen: In Search of Unity |publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]] |date=January 19, 1990 |via={{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/51196986/CIA-Study-on-Yemeni-Unification |title=CIA Study on Yemeni Unification |publisher=Scribd}}}}{{cite book |last=Gause |first=Gregory |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0yUzV-g2X2QC&pg=PA98 |title=Saudi-Yemeni relations: domestic structures and foreign influence |publisher=Columbia University Press |year=1990 |page=98|isbn=9780231070447 }} However, these plans were put on hold in 1979, as the PDRY funded Red rebels in the YAR, and war was only prevented by an [[Arab League]] intervention. The goal of unity was reaffirmed by the northern and southern heads of state during a summit meeting in [[Kuwait]] in March 1979. In 1980, PDRY president [[Abdul Fattah Ismail]] resigned and went into exile in [[Moscow]], having lost the confidence of his sponsors in the [[Soviet Union|USSR]].{{cite book |last=Halliday |first=Fred |title=Revolution and Foreign Policy: The Case of South Yemen, 1967–1987 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2002 |page=35}} His successor, [[Ali Nasir Muhammad]], took a less interventionist stance toward both North Yemen and neighbouring [[Oman]]. ===Civil war=== {{main|South Yemen Civil War}} On January 13, 1986, a violent struggle began in Aden between Ali Nasir's supporters and supporters of the returned Ismail, who wanted power back. Fighting, known as the [[South Yemen Civil War]], lasted for more than a month and resulted in thousands of casualties, Ali Nasir's [[coup d'état|ouster]], and Ismail's death. Some 60,000 people, including the deposed Ali Nasir, fled to the YAR. [[Ali Salim al-Beidh]], an ally of Ismail who had succeeded in escaping the attack on pro-Ismail members of the Politburo, then became General Secretary of the Yemeni Socialist Party.{{cite journal |last=Katz |first=Mark |url=http://digilib.gmu.edu:8080/jspui/bitstream/1920/3127/1/civil%20conflict%20in%20south%20yemen.pdf |title=Civil Conflict in South Yemen |journal=Middle East Review |date=Fall 1986 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718172214/http://digilib.gmu.edu:8080/jspui/bitstream/1920/3127/1/civil%20conflict%20in%20south%20yemen.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }} ===Reforms and attempts for unification=== {{main|Yemeni unification}} Against the background of the [[perestroika]] in the USSR, the main backer of the PDRY, political reforms were started in the late 1980s. Political prisoners were released, political parties were formed and the system of justice was reckoned to be more equitable than in the North. In May 1988, the YAR and PDRY governments came to an understanding that considerably reduced tensions including agreement to renew discussions concerning unification, to establish a joint oil exploration area along their undefined border, to demilitarize the border, and to allow Yemenis unrestricted border passage on the basis of only a national identification card. In 1990, the parties reached a full agreement on joint governing of Yemen, and the countries were effectively merged as [[Yemen]].{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} == Reviving South Yemen == {{main|Southern Movement}} Since 2007, some Southerners have been actively protesting for independence, in a movement known as 'Al Hirak' or the [[Southern Movement]]. During the [[Yemeni Civil War (2015)|Yemen Civil War 2015]], in response to incursions by the [[Houthis]] and military forces loyal to deposed Yemeni president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], members of the Southern Movement formed 'Popular Resistance' militias. Since the [[Battle of Aden (2015)|Battle of Aden]], these armed groups have sought to defend the South against Houthi/Saleh attempts to take over the country and have taken the current state of civil war as opportunity to further their struggle for independence. In late January 2018, separatists loyal to the [[Southern Transitional Council]] successfully seized control of the Saudi-backed Yemeni government [[headquarter]]s in Aden in an apparent [[2018 Yemeni coup d'état|coup d'etat]] against the [[Cabinet of Yemen|Hadi government]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42852285|title=Separatist clashes flare in south Yemen|date=30 January 2018|publisher=|access-date=30 January 2018|via=www.BBC.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/monde/yemen-les-separatistes-sudistes-a-la-recherche-de-l-independance-perdue-28-01-2018-2190258_24.php|title=Yémen: les séparatistes sudistes, à la recherche de l'indépendance perdue|date=28 January 2018|work=[[Le Point]]|accessdate=28 January 2018}} ==Politics and social life== South Yemen's ethnic groups are [[Arab]]s (92.8%), [[Somali people|Somali]]s (3.7%), Blacks 1.1%, Indians and Pakistanis (1%), and other (1.4%) (2000). The only recognized political party in South Yemen was the [[Yemeni Socialist Party]], which ran the country and the economy along self-described [[Marxist]] lines, modeled on the [[Soviet Union]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} The constitution prescribed [[universal suffrage]]. The [[Supreme People's Council (South Yemen)|Supreme People's Council]] was appointed by the General Command of the [[National Liberation Front (Yemen)|National Liberation Front]] in 1971. In Aden, there was a structured judicial system with a [[supreme court]]. Education was paid for through general taxation. There was no housing crisis in South Yemen. Surplus housing built by the [[United Kingdom|British]] meant that there were few homeless people in Aden, and people built their own houses out of [[adobe]] and mud in the rural areas. South Yemen developed as a [[Marxist]], mostly [[secular]]{{cite news |last=Laessing |first=Ulf |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/01/22/us-yemen-women-idUSTRE60L2ZD20100122 |title=Women of southern Yemen port remember better times |agency=Reuters |date=January 22, 2010}} society ruled first by the [[National Liberation Front (Yemen)|National Liberation Front]], which later morphed into the ruling [[Yemeni Socialist Party]]. The only avowedly Marxist nation in the Middle East, South Yemen received significant foreign aid and other assistance from the [[USSR]]{{cite news |last=Gart |first=Murray |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956703,00.html |title=South Yemen New Thinking in a Marxist Land |work=Time |date=January 9, 1989}} and [[East Germany]], which stationed several hundred officers of the [[Stasi]] in the country to train the nation's secret police and establish another arms trafficking route to Palestine.Müller, Miriam Manuela. A Spectre Is Haunting Arabia: How the Germans Brought Their Communism to Yemen. Transcript, 2015.In-text Citation The East Germans didn't leave until 1990, when the Yemeni government declined to pay their salaries which had been terminated with the dissolution of the Stasi during [[German reunification]].Stokes, Lee. “East German Security Quit South Yemen.” United Press Agency, 11 May 1990.In-text Citation ===Sports=== In 1976, the [[South Yemen national football team]] participated in the [[Asia Cup]], where the team lost to Iraq 1-0 and to Iran 8-0. They entered their only World Cup qualification campaign in [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]] and were knocked out in the first round by Bahrain. On September 2, 1965, South Yemen played their first international match against [[Egypt national football team|the United Arab Republic]], to whom they lost 14-0. On November 5, 1989, South Yemen played its last international match against [[Guinea national football team|Guinea]], to whom they lost 1-0. The team stopped playing when the North and South united in 1990 to form the modern state of Yemen. In 1988, the South Yemen Olympic team [[South Yemen at the 1988 Summer Olympics|made its debut in Seoul]]. Sending only eight athletes, the country won no medals. This was the only time the country went to the Olympics until unification in 1990. ==Governorates== Following independence, South Yemen was divided into six [[governorate]]s ([[Arabic language|Arabic]] sg. ''muhafazah''), with roughly natural boundaries, each given a name by [[Numeral (linguistics)|numeral]]. From 1967 to 1978, they were named officially by numerals only; from 1979 to 1990, they were given new official names. The islands: [[Kamaran]] (until 1972, when it was seized by North Yemen), Perim (Meyun), [[Socotra]], Abd-el-Kuri, Samha (inhabited), Darsah and others uninhabited from the [[Socotra]] archipelago were districts (''mudiriyah'') of the First/Aden Governorate being under Prime-Minister of the state supervision.{{cite book | last = Ismael | first = Tareq Y. | authorlink = Tareq Y. Ismael |author2=Jacqueline S. Ismael | title = The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen: Politics, Economics, and Society; The Politics of Socialist Transformation | publisher = Lynne Rienner Pub |date=October 1986 | location = | url = | doi = | isbn = 978-0-931477-96-6}} {| class="wikitable" !Numeral !Name !Approximate Area (km.²) !Capital |rowspan=7|[[Image:Image-South Yemen governorates.png|right|280px|Map of the governorates]] |- |I |[['Adan Governorate|'Adan]] |6,980 |[[Aden]] |- |II |[[Lahij Governorate|Lahij]] |12,766 |[[Lahij]] |- |III |[[Abyan Governorate|Abyan]] |21,489 |[[Zinjibar]] |- |IV |[[Shabwah Governorate|Shabwah]] |73,908 |[[Ataq]] |- |V |[[Hadhramaut Governorate|Hadhramawt]] |155,376 |[[Mukalla]] |- |VI |[[Al Mahrah Governorate|al-Mahrah]] |66,350 |[[Al Ghaydah]] |} ==Economy== There was little [[industry|industrial]] output, or mineral wealth exploitation, in South Yemen, until the mid-1980s, following the discovery of significant petroleum reserves in the central regions near [[Shibam]] and [[Mukalla]]. The main sources of income were [[agriculture]], mostly [[fruit]], [[cereal crop]]s, [[cattle]] and [[sheep]], [[fishing]] and later, oil exports. The national [[budget]] was 13.43 million dinars in 1976, and the [[gross national product]] was [[US dollar|US$]]150 million. The total national [[debt]] was $52.4 million. ==Airlines== The following airlines had operated from the PDRY:{{cite web |url=http://www.airlinehistory.co.uk/RestofWorld/South%20Yemen/Airlines.asp |title=Airlines - South Yemen |work=The World's Airlines |publisher=David Lyall}} *[[Aden Airways]]{{cite web |url=http://www.adenairways.com/Aden%20Airways/index.htm |publisher=Peter Pickering |work=Aden Airways |title=History |accessdate=13 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427151220/http://www.adenairways.com/Aden%20Airways/index.htm |archivedate=2009-04-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }} (1949–1967). Ceased operations on 30 June 1967 at the time of British withdrawal from the [[Federation of South Arabia|Federation]] and the [[Protectorate of South Arabia]]. *[[Alyemda]] – Democratic Yemen Airlines (1961–1996). Joined [[Yemenia]], the airline of the former YAR *Yemen Airways (1989–1990) ==See also== {{portal|Communism}} *[[List of leaders of South Yemen]] *[[History of Yemen]] *[[Democratic Republic of Yemen]] *[[South Yemen Movement]] *[[South Yemen insurgency]] *[[Dhofar Rebellion]] *[[Yemen]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Refbegin}} {{CIA World Factbook}} {{Refend}} ==External links== {{commonscat|South Yemen}} * [http://www.nationalanthems.info/yes-79.htm South Yemen Anthem (1969-1979)]
[[National anthem of Yemen]] (Second and Last Anthem of South Yemen) * [http://worldstatesmen.org/YemenPDR1978.pdf Constitution of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen] {{Socialist states}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:States and territories established in 1967]] [[Category:States and territories disestablished in 1990]] [[Category:South Yemen| ]] [[Category:Communism in Yemen]] [[Category:Communist states]] [[Category:Former member states of the United Nations|Yemen, South]] [[Category:Former socialist republics|Yemen]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Asia]] [[Category:1994 disestablishments in Asia]] [[Category:Historical regions]] [[Category:Former polities of the Cold War]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Lago_del_Segrino_(aprile 2013)_03.JPG|thumb|250px|The small [[Lago del Segrino|Lake Segrino]].]]
The '''''Triangolo lariano''''' is a [[Geography|geographic]] area in [[Lombardy]] ([[Italy]]) within the [[Province of Como]]. It is represented by a territorial intermediate institution named ''[[:simple:Italian mountain community|Comunità montana]] del Triangolo lariano'', with base in [[Canzo]].
== Topography == [[Image:Bollettone-Corni_di_Canzo.JPG|thumb|250px|Mounts [[Corni di Canzo]] ([[Canzo]]'s Horns) (in the foreground), with Pizzo dei Tre Signori in the background.]]
There are three big lakes in [[Italy]]<ref>[http://www.mit.gov.it/mit/mop_all.php?p_id=07307 Governative administration of the big lakes]. In Italian.</ref> who reach a depth of more than 300 [[metre]]s and cover an area of hundreds of [[square kilometre]]s. They are aligned west-east, since they all are within the [[Alpine foothills|pre-alpine]] zone of [[Lombardy]] region. The most west is the [[Lake Maggiore]], and it marks the boundary with the region of [[Piedmont]]; the most east is [[Lake Garda]], marking the boundary with the region of [[Veneto]]; the central one is [[Lake Como]].<ref>[http://www.italia.it/en/travel-ideas/lakes/lombardy-the-lakes-region.html Page on Lombardy and lakes on Governative national Italian portal for tourism]</ref>
It is distinguishable from its characteristic shape of an upside-down “[[Y]]” or a [[Greek alphabet|Greek letter]] “[[Lambda|λ]]”. The triangle formed by the two diagonal branches of the lake is named in [[Italian language|Italian]] ''Triangolo lariano''. This phrase is composed by the noun ''triangolo'' (= triangle) and the adjective ''lariano'', meaning “related to the Larius”, the [[Latin language|Latin]] name of [[Lake Como]].<ref>[http://www.treccani.it/vocabolario/lariano/ ''Lariano'' on an authoritative Italian dictionary]</ref>
It consists in a [[peninsula]] – whose end is the village of [[Bellagio, Lombardy|Bellagio]] –, but it can be considered as quite an [[island]], because the third side of the triangle (not occupied by the [[Lake Como]]) is dotted with seven smaller lakes. The touristic town of [[Canzo]] lies at the center of the ''Triangolo lariano'' and is the chief town of the ''Comunità montana del Triangolo lariano'' (literally, “Mountain community of ''Triangolo lariano''”), a territorial institution who brings together the 31 [[Comune|municipalities]] of the peninsula, of about 71,000 inhabitants.<ref>[http://212.78.2.155/cmtl/hh/index.php Official presentation of the agency]. In Italian.</ref>
== History ==
{{Multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = Coat-of-arms of the [[Duchy of Milan]] and Coat-of-arms of ''[[Curtis Casalensis]]'' ([[Middle Ages]] institutions). | footer_align = center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Arms_of_the_House_of_Sforza.svg | width1 = 113 | caption1 = | image2 = Corte_de_Casale_Canz_Canzo_02.png | width2 = 100 | caption2 = }}
During the [[Middle Ages]], the territory of ''Triangolo lariano'' was divided into four main institutions, three of which was part of the State of [[Milan]]; one, instead, was under the rule of the Commune of [[Como]]: * One was the [[Pieve]] of Asso ([[Valassina]] valley) of the [[Archdiocese of Milan]] and, then, also of the [[Duchy of Milan]]. * Another one was the ''[[Curtis Casalensis]]'', a league of free communes with [[Canzo]] as chief town, within the jurisdiction of the [[Duchy of Milan]] too. * Part of the former [[Pieve]] of ''Incino'' (= [[Erba, Lombardy|Erba]]), [[Duchy of Milan]]. * Finally, communes who were under the rule of Como ([[Bellagio, Lombardy|Bellagio]] itself, and the villages on the western coast of the [[Lake Como|Lake]]).<ref>Longoni, Virginio (1999). ''Fonti per la storia del Triangolo Lariano. Il medioevo, Canzo'': Comunità Montana del Triangolo Lariano, Assessorato alla Cultura.</ref>
== Lakes and mountains ==
The “Triangle” has an altitude between 320 and 1,682 m.a.s.l.<ref>[http://www.cmtl.it/gis/ Map on the official site of ''Comunità montana del Triangolo lariano'']</ref> The most famous mountains are: [[Corni di Canzo]] ([[Canzo]]’s Horns) (1,372 m) and Mount [[Cornizzolo]] (1,241 m), both in [[Canzo]], divided by Mount Raj (1,261 m), also in [[Canzo]], as a tourist destination because of the variety and attractiveness of the landscape;<ref>[http://www.lifemgn-serviziecosistemici.eu/EN/Documents/LIFE+MGN_Brochure_EN.pdf Official presentation of the protected areas of Lombardy]</ref> [[Monte San Primo|Mount San Primo]] (1,682 m) and Mount [[Palanzone]] (1,436 m) for their highness. Mount [[Bollettone]] (1,317 m) too, for its proximity to [[Como]], is often visited.<ref>[http://www.gulliver.it/itinerario/4123/] (Accessed on July 25, 2015).</ref>
The seven small lakes forming the southern border of the region are: Lake of [[Pusiano]], [[Lago di Annone|Lake of Annone]] (divided into ''Lake of Annone'' strictly said and Lake of [[Oggiono]]), Lake of [[Garlate]], [[Lago di Alserio|Lake of Alserio]], Lake of [[Montorfano]], and, finally, the [[Lago del Segrino|Lake Segrino]] – placed in the southern border of the land of [[Canzo]] –, a marvelous little glacial lake, celebrated by several authors and poets.<ref>[[Ippolito Nievo]], ''La pazza del Segrino'', [[Milan]], Sanvito 1860; [[Antonio Fogazzaro]], ''[[Malombra (novel)|Malombra]]'', [[Milan]], Brigola 1881; [[Carlo Emilio Gadda]], ''La cognizione del dolore'', Letterarura 1941/Einaudi 1963. [http://www.lagodelsegrino.com/index.php?fl=2&op=mcs&id_cont=785&eng=Gli%20artisti%20e%20il%20Segrino&idm=785 Page on the official site of the Nature reserve].</ref>
''Triangolo lariano'' is also the name of a [[Special Protection Area]] (593 [[hectare]]s) protected by European laws, located in the [[Corni di Canzo]] (Horns of [[Canzo]]). Its protection concerns 84 precious [[bird]] [[species]] (including the [[European honey buzzard|honey buzzard]], the [[peregrine falcon]], the [[rock partridge]], the [[eagle owl]], the [[nightjar]], the [[tawny pipit]], the [[red-backed shrike]], and the [[ortolan bunting]]) and the habitats, e.g. the natural dry grasslands and [[scrubland]] facies on calcareous substrates (Festuco-Brometalia) – with significant blossoming of [[Orchidaceae|orchids]] –, the [[limestone]] pavements and the petrifying springs with [[tufa]] formation (Cratoneurion), and the calcareous [[beech]] forests of Central Europe Cephalanthero-Fagion. Inside is another [[nature reserve]], the [[Site of Community Importance]] “''Sasso Malascarpa''" (328 [[hectare]]s), with 52 protected [[species]], among which are the [[greater horseshoe bat]], various kinds of [[Lanius|backed shrike]], and the rare [[Austropotamobius pallipes|white-clawed crayfish]]. A peculiar habitat of the reserve consists in the stone springs with [[travertine]] formation. The alternation of woods, meadows–pastures, and rock formations in the mountains of [[Canzo]], makes the landscape particularly popular for tourism.<ref>[http://www.lifemgn-serviziecosistemici.eu/EN/Documents/LIFE+MGN_Brochure_EN.pdf Official presentation of the protected areas of Lombardy]</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Canzo]] * ''[[Curtis Casalensis]]'' * [[Lago del Segrino]] * [[Corni di Canzo]] ([[Canzo]]'s Horns) * [[Cornizzolo]] * [[Giubiana]] * [[Canzés dialect]] * [[Brianza]] * [[Province of Como]]

Canzo: Comunità Montana del Triangolo Lariano, Assessorato alla Cultura. * Longoni, Virginio (1999). ''Fonti per la storia del Triangolo Lariano. Il medioevo'', Canzo: Comunità Montana del Triangolo Lariano, Assessorato alla Cultura.

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/189.202.57.197|189.202.57.197]] ([[User talk:189.202.57.197|talk]]) to last version by Cilac
Fix [[:Category:CS1 maint: Extra text|CS1 cite error]] (extra text in "page" or "edition" parameter), and genfixes
revision.text:
[[File:Valle de México José Maria Velazco 3.jpg|thumb|right|A 19th-century painting of the Valley of Mexico by [[José María Velasco Gómez|José María Velasco]].]] [[File:Lake Texcoco c 1519.png|thumb|right|The lake system within the Valley of Mexico at the time of the [[Spanish Conquest of Mexico|Spanish Conquest]] in around 1519.]] [[File:Basin of Mexico 1519 map-en.svg|thumb|right|The Valley of Mexico basin, ca. 1519]]
The '''Valley of Mexico''' ({{lang-es|Valle de México}}; {{lang-nah|Tepētzallāntli Mēxihco}}) is a highlands [[plateau]] in central [[Mexico]] roughly coterminous with present-day [[Mexico City]] and the eastern half of the [[State of Mexico]]. Surrounded by mountains and volcanoes, the Valley of Mexico was a centre for several [[pre-Columbian]] [[civilization]]s, including [[Teotihuacan]], the [[Toltec]], and the [[Aztec]]. The ancient Aztec term ''[[Anahuac (Aztec)|Anahuac]] (Land Between the Waters) '' and the phrase '''Basin of Mexico''' are both used at times to refer to the Valley of Mexico. The Basin of Mexico became a well known site that epitomized the scene of early Classic Mesoamerican cultural development as well.
The Valley of Mexico is located in the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]].<ref name="PorruaCuenca">{{cite book |title=Diccionario Porrua de Historia, Biografia y Geografia de Mexico 6th ed. – Mexico, Cuenca de |year=1995 |publisher=Editorial Porrua |location=africa
|language=Spanish |isbn= 968-452-907-4 |page=2238 |volume=3}}</ref><ref name="casestudy">{{cite web |url = http://casestudies.lead.org/index.php?cscid=100 |title = Mexico City: Opportunities and Challenges for Sustainable Management of Urban Water Resources |date = December 2004 |accessdate = 2008-11-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081207190625/http://casestudies.lead.org/index.php?cscid=100 |archivedate = 2008-12-07 |df = }}</ref> The valley contains most of the [[Greater Mexico City|Mexico City Metropolitan Area]], as well as parts of the [[State of Mexico]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Tlaxcala]] and [[Puebla]]. The Valley of Mexico can be subdivided into four basins, but the largest and most-studied is the area which contains [[Mexico City]]. This section of the valley in particular is colloquially referred to as the "Valley of Mexico".<ref name="lafragua">{{cite paper |last=Lafregua |first=J |author2=Gutierrez, A |author3=Aguilar E |author4=Aparicio J |author5=Mejia R |author6=Santillan O |author7=Suarez MA |author8=Preciado M |title=Balance hídrico del Valle de Mexico |publisher=Anuario IMTA |year=2003 |url=http://chac.imta.mx/instituto/historial-proyectos/th/2003/HDR1-Balance.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qCrS33C1?url=http://chac.imta.mx/instituto/historial-proyectos/th/2003/HDR1-Balance.pdf |archivedate=2010-06-03 |df= }}</ref> The valley has a minimum elevation of {{convert|2200|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] and is surrounded by mountains and volcanoes that reach elevations of over {{convert|5000|m|sp=us}}.<ref name="natresearch">{{cite book |title= Mexico City's Water Supply: Improving the Outlook for Sustainability. |author= National Research Council Staff |year=1995 |publisher= National Academies Press |location= Washington, D.C., USA |isbn=978-0-309-05245-0 |pages=}}</ref> It is an enclosed valley with no natural outlet for water to flow and a gap to the north where there is a high [[mesa]] but no high mountain peaks. Within this vulnerable watershed all the native fishes were extinct by the end of the 20th century.<ref>Noted in passing by Christian Lévêque, ''Biodiversity Dynamics and Conservation: The Freshwater Fish of Tropical Africa'', 1997 "Introduction" p. xi.</ref> Hydrologically, the valley has three features. The first feature is the lakebeds of five now-extinct lakes, which are located in the southernmost and largest of the four sub-basins. The other two features are [[Foothills|piedmont]], and the mountainsides that collect the precipitation that eventually flows to the lake area. These last two are found in all four of the sub-basins of the valley.<ref name="PorruaCuenca"/><ref name="lafragua"/> Today, the Valley drains through a series of artificial canals to the [[Tula River]], and eventually the [[Pánuco River]] and the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. [[Seismic activity]] is frequent here, and the valley is considered an earthquake prone zone.<ref name="yip">{{cite paper | last= Yip | first=Maricela |author2=Madl, Pierre | title= Air Pollution in Mexico City | pages=16 | publisher= University of Salzburg, Austria | date=2002-04-16 | url= http://biophysics.sbg.ac.at/mexico/air.htm | accessdate=2008-11-25 }}</ref>
The valley has been inhabited for at least 12,000 years, attracting humans with its mild climate (average temperatures between 12 and 15 °C, or 54 and 59 °F), abundant game and ability to support large-scale agriculture.<ref name="Kirkwood">{{cite book |title= History of Mexico |last=Kirkwood |first=Burton |year=2000 |publisher= Greenwood Publishing Group, Incorporated |location= Westport, Connecticut, USA |isbn=978-0-313-30351-7 }}</ref><ref name="Acosta">{{cite web |url = http://www.ucm.es/info/arqueoweb/word/8(2)/acostaochoa.doc |last = Acosta Ochoa |first = Guillermo |title = Las ocupaciones preceramicas de la Cuenca de Mexico Del Poblamiento a las primeras sociedades agricolas |language = Spanish |accessdate = 2008-11-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090225112400/http://www.ucm.es/info/arqueoweb/word/8(2)/acostaochoa.doc |archivedate = 2009-02-25 |df = }}</ref> Civilizations that have arisen in this area include the [[Teotihuacan]] (800 BC to 800 AD) the [[Toltec Empire]] (10th to 13th century) and the [[Aztec Empire]] (1325 to 1521).<ref name="Kirkwood"/> When the Spaniards arrived in the Valley of Mexico, it had one of the highest population concentrations in the world with about one million people.<ref name="casestudy"/> After the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Conquest]], the Spaniards rebuilt the largest and most dominant city here, [[Tenochtitlan]], renaming it Mexico City. The valley used to contain five lakes called [[Lake Zumpango]], [[Lake Xaltocan]], [[Lake Xochimilco]], [[Lake Chalco]], and the largest, [[Lake Texcoco|Texcoco]] covering about {{convert|1500|km2|sp=us}} of the valley floor,<ref name="casestudy"/> but as the Spaniards expanded Mexico City, they began to drain the lakes' waters to control flooding.<ref name="Kirkwood"/> Although violence and disease significantly lowered the population of the valley after the Conquest, by 1900 it was again over one million people.<ref name="Hamnett">{{cite book |title= Concise History of Mexico. |last=Hamnett |first=Brian R |year=1999 |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= Port Chester, New York, USA |isbn=978-0-521-58120-2 }}</ref> The 20th and 21st centuries have seen an explosion of population in the valley along with the growth of industry. Since 1900, the population has doubled every fifteen years. Today, around 21 million people live in the Mexico City Metropolitan Area which extends throughout almost all of the valley into the states of Mexico and Hidalgo.<ref name="casestudy"/>
The growth of a major urban, industrial centre in an enclosed basin has created significant air and water quality issues for the valley. Wind patterns and [[thermal inversion]]s trap contaminants in the valley. Over-extraction of ground water has caused new flooding problems for the city as it sinks below the historic lake floor. This causes stress on the valley's drainage system, requiring new tunnels and canals to be built.<ref name="yip"/><ref name="thielman">{{cite web |url= http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/1997-09/PNNL-BTAP-090997.php |last= Thielman |first= Jim |date= 1997-09-09 |title= Eurekalert |publisher=DOE/Pacific Northwest National Laboratory |accessdate=2008-11-25 }}</ref>
==History of human habitation== {{Main|History of Mexico}}
===First human habitation===
The Valley of Mexico attracted early humans because the region was rich in biodiversity and had the capacity of growing substantial crops.<ref name="Kirkwood"/> Generally speaking, humans in [[Mesoamerica]], including central Mexico, began to leave a hunter-gatherer existence in favor of agriculture sometime between the end of the [[Pleistocene]] [[Geologic time scale|epoch]] and the beginning of the [[Holocene]].<ref name="Acosta"/> The oldest known human settlement in the Valley of Mexico is located in [[Tlapacoya (Mesoamerican site)|Tlapacoya]], located on what was the edge of Lake Chalco in the southeast corner of the valley in contemporary Mexico State. There is reliable archeological evidence to suggest that the site dates as far back as 12,000 BC. After 10,000 BC, the number of artifacts found increases significantly. There are also other early sites such as those in Tepexpan, Los Reyes Acozac, [[San Bartolo Atepehuacan]], [[Chimalhuacán]] and [[Los Reyes Acaquilpan|Los Reyes La Paz]] but they remain undated. Human remains and artifacts such as obsidian blades have been found at the Tlapacoya site that have been dated as far back as 20,000 BC, when the valley was semi-arid and contained species like [[camel]]s, [[bison]] and horses that could be hunted by man.<ref name="protocolo"/> However, the precise dating of these artifacts has been disputed.<ref name="Acosta"/> [[File:Museo paleontologico de Tocuila-mandibula.JPG|thumb|left|A Columbian mammoth jaw excavated at [[Paleontological Museum in Tocuila|Tocuila]]]] Giant [[Columbian mammoth]]s once populated the area, and the valley contains the most extensive mammoth kill sites in Mexico. Most of the sites are located on what were the shores of Lake Texcoco in the north of the Federal District and the adjacent municipalities of Mexico State such as in [[Santa Isabel Ixtapan]], [[Los Reyes Acozac]], [[Tepexpan]] and [[Tlalnepantla de Baz|Tlanepantla]].<ref name="Anaya">{{cite journal |last = Anaya Rodriguez |first = Edgar |date = December 2003 |title = En la tierra del mamut |journal = Mexico Desconocido |volume = 322 |url = http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/interior/index.php?idNota=7770&p=nota |language = Spanish |accessdate = 2008-11-25 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Mammoth bones are still occasionally found in farmland here. They have been discovered in many parts of the Federal District itself, particularly during the construction of the city's [[Mexico City Metro|Metro lines]] and in the neighborhoods of [[Colonia del Valle|Del Valle]] in the center, [[Colonia Lindavista|Lindavista]] to the center-north and [[Coyoacán]] in the south of the city. The symbol for Line 4's Bondojito station of the Mexico City Metro is a mammoth, due to the fact that so many bones were uncovered during its construction. However, the richest site for mammoth remains in the valley is at the [[Paleontological Museum in Tocuila]], a {{convert|45|ha|sp=us|adj=on}} site located near the town of [[Texcoco, Mexico State|Texcoco]] in Mexico State.<ref name="Anaya"/> Although there is some evidence around the old lakeshores that the first populations here survived by hunting, gathering and possibly by scavenging, but evidence from this time period is scarce.<ref name="Acosta"/>
===Pre-Teotihuacan=== [[File:SEViewCuicuilcoDF.JPG|thumb|right|Modern-day [[Cuicuilco]]]] [[File:Acróbata de Tlatilco.JPG|thumb|Ceramic art recovered from [[Tlatilco]], [[circa]] 1300–800 BC]] [[Tlatilco]] was a large [[pre-Columbian]] village and culture in the Valley of Mexico situated near the modern-day town of the same name in the [[Mexican Federal District]]. It was one of the first significant population centers to arise in the valley, flourishing on the western shore of Lake Texcoco during the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Middle Pre-Classic period]],<ref>[http://historyofthought.as.uky.edu/index.php/Archaeology_and_Mapping See also:] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221062729/http://historyofthought.as.uky.edu/index.php/Archaeology_and_Mapping |date=December 21, 2014 }}</ref> between 1200 BC and 200 BC.<ref name="Neiderberger">{{cite book |title= The Basin of Mexico: a Multimillennial Development Toward Cultural Complexity", in Olmec Art of Ancient Mexico |last=Neiderberger |first=Christine |editor=E. P. Benson and B. de la Fuente |year=1996 |location= Washington, D.C. |isbn=0-89468-250-4 |pages=83–93}}</ref> It was originally classified as a [[necropolis]] when it was first excavated, but it was determined that the many burials there were under houses of which nothing remains. It was then classified as a major chiefdom center. The Tlatilcans were an agricultural people growing beans, [[amaranth]], squash and [[chili pepper]]s, reaching their peak from 1000 to 700 BC.<ref name="Neiderberger"/>
The next-oldest confirmed civilization is in the far south of the valley and is called [[Cuicuilco]].<ref name="lopezcamacho">{{cite web |url= http://www.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00703.html |last=Lopez Camacho |first= Javier |author2=Carlos Córdova Fernández |publisher= INAH |language=Spanish |title=Cuiculco |accessdate=2008-11-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080105180740/http://www.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00703.html |archivedate = 2008-01-05}}</ref> This archaeological site is located where [[Avenida de los Insurgentes|Avenida Insurgentes Sur]] crosses the [[Anillo Periférico]] in the [[Tlalpan]] borough of the city. The old settlement once extended far beyond the boundaries of the current site, but it is buried under lava from one of the volcanic eruptions that led to its demise, and much of the modern city is built over this lava. The settlement was located where an old river delta used to form in the valley with waters from Mount Zacatépetl located in what is now the Tlalpan Forest. Cuicuilco was believed to have reached city status by 1200 BC and began to decline around 100 BC - AD 150. However, even though the ceremonial pyramid was abandoned, the site remained a location to leave offerings up to AD 400, although lava from the nearby [[Xitle]] volcano completely covered it.<ref name="lopezcamacho"/>
===Teotihuacan and the Toltecs===
Around 2,000 years ago, the Valley of Mexico became one of the world's most densely populated areas and has remained so since.<ref name="casestudy"/> After the decline of Cuicuilco, the population concentration shifted north, to the city of Teotihuacan and later to [[Tula (Mesoamerican site)|Tula]], both outside the lake's region of the valley.<ref name="Hamnett"/> Teotihuacan became an organized village around 800 BC but it was around 200 BC that it began to reach its height. When it did, the city had approximately 125,000 inhabitants and covered {{convert|20|km2|0|sp=us}} of territory. It was dedicated primarily to the [[obsidian]] trade and at its peak was an important religious center and [[pilgrimage]] for the valley.<ref name="inah">{{cite web |url = http://dti.inah.gob.mx/index.php?Itemid=50&id=280&option=com_content&task=view |title = INAH- Teotihuacan Archaeological Site Museum |accessdate = 2008-11-25 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In the early 8th century, with the rise of the [[Toltec]] empire, Teotihuacan ceased to be a major urban centre and the population shifted to Tollan or Tula on the northern front of Valley of Mexico.<ref name="Hamnett"/>
===Aztec Empire=== After the end of the Toltec empire in the 13th century and the decline of the city of Tula, the population shifted once again, this time to the lakes region of the valley. With this migration came the concept of a city-state based on the Toltec model. By the end of the 13th century, some fifty small urban units, semi-autonomous and with their own religious centers, had sprung up around the lakeshores of the valley. These remained intact with a population of about 10,000 each under Aztec rule and survived into the colonial period. All of these city-states, including the largest and most powerful, [[Tenochtitlan]], with more than 150,000 inhabitants, claimed descent from the Toltecs. None of these cities was completely autonomous or self-sufficient, resulting in a conflictive political situation, and a complex system of agriculture in the valley.<ref name="Hamnett"/> These city-states had similar governmental structures based on the need to control flooding and store water for irrigating crops. Many of the institutions created by these hydraulic societies, such as the building and maintenance of chinampas, aqueducts and dikes, were later co-opted by the Spanish during the colonial period.<ref name="Gallup">{{cite book |title= [[Is Geography Destiny? Lessons from Latin America]] |last=Gallup |first=John Luke |year=2003 |publisher= World Bank Publications |location= Washington, D.C., USA |isbn=978-0-8213-5451-3 |pages=74–89}}</ref>
The largest and most dominant city at the time of the Spanish conquest was [[Tenochtitlan]]. It was founded by the [[Mexica]] ([[Aztecs]]) on a small island in the western part of Lake Texcoco in 1325, and was extended with the use of [[chinampa]]s, human-made extensions of agricultural land into the southern lake system, to increase productive agricultural land, covering about {{convert|9000|ha|sqmi|sp=us}}.<ref name="Hamnett"/> The inhabitants controlled the lake with a sophisticated system of [[Dike (construction)|dike]]s, canals and [[sluice]]s. Much of the surrounding land in the valley was [[Terrace (agriculture)|terraced and farmed]] as well, with a network of [[aqueduct (water supply)|aqueduct]]s channeling fresh water from springs in the mountainsides into the city itself.<ref name="casestudy"/> Despite being the dominant power, the need to rely on resources from other parts of the valley led to the [[Aztec Triple Alliance]] between Tenochtitlan, [[Texcoco (altepetl)|Texcoco]] and [[Tlacopan]] at the beginning of the empire. However, by the time the Spanish arrived in 1519, Tenochtitlan had become the dominant power of the three, causing grievances that the Spaniards were able to exploit.<ref name="Hamnett"/> However, despite Tenochtitlan's power outside the valley, it never completely controlled all of the valley itself, with the [[altepetl]] of Tlaxcala the most prominent example.<ref name="Hamnett"/>
By 1520, the estimated population of the valley was over 1,000,000 people.<ref name="casestudy"/>
===Spanish colonial rule and the Mexico City metropolitan area=== {{Main|History of Mexico City}} After the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec empire]] in 1521, the Spanish rebuilt and renamed Tenochtitlan as Mexico City. They started with essentially the same size and layout as the Aztec city but as the centuries progressed, the city grew as the lakes shrank. Just after the conquest, disease and violence had decreased the population in the valley, especially of the native peoples, but after that, the population grew all through the colonial period and in the century after [[Mexican War of Independence|independence]].<ref name="Hamnett"/>
By the early 20th century, the population of Mexico City alone had risen to over one million people. A population explosion began early in the 20th century, with the population of the city itself doubling approximately every 15 years since 1900, partly attributed to the fact that the federal government has favored development of the metropolitan area over other areas of the country.<ref name="casestudy"/> This has spurred investment in [[infrastructure]] for the city, such as [[electricity]], other power sources, [[water supply]] and [[drainage]]. These have attracted businesses which in turn have attracted more population. Since the 1950s, urbanization has spread out from beyond the bounds of the Federal District to the surrounding jurisdictions, especially to the north into the State of Mexico making for the Mexico City Metropolitan area, which fills most of the valley.<ref name="casestudy"/> Today, this metropolitan area accounts for 45 per cent of the country's industrial activity, 38 percent of GNP, and 25 percent of the population.<ref name="casestudy"/> Much of its industry is concentrated in the northern part of the Federal District and the adjoining cities in the state of Mexico.<ref name="yip"/> While population growth has slowed and even declined in the city proper, the outer limits of the metropolitan area keep growing. Much of this growth has occurred on the mountainsides of the valley, in the form of illegal settlements in ecologically sensitive areas.<ref name="casestudy"/> Overall urban settlement in the valley has expanded from about {{convert|90|km2|abbr=on|sp=us}} in 1940 to {{convert|1160|km2|abbr=on|sp=us}} in 1990.<ref name="casestudy"/> The metropolitan area has about 21 million residents and about 6 million cars.<ref name="Barclay">{{cite web |url = http://www.dcp2.org/features/47/clearing-the-smog-fighting-air-pollution-in-mexico-city-mexico-and-so-paulo-brazil |title = Clearing the Smog: Fighting Air Pollution in Mexico City, Mexico, and São Paulo, Brazil |accessdate = 25 November 2008 |last = Barclay |first = Eliza |date = 2007-06-23 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081209030638/http://www.dcp2.org/features/47/clearing-the-smog-fighting-air-pollution-in-mexico-city-mexico-and-so-paulo-brazil |archivedate = 9 December 2008 |df = }}</ref>
===Air pollution=== Mexico City is [[Air pollution in Mexico City|vulnerable to severe air pollution problems]] due to its altitude, its being surrounded by mountains and the winds patterns of the area.<ref name="yip"/><ref name="thielman"/><ref name="molina">{{cite web |url= http://www.pulseplanet.com/dailyprogram/dailies.php?POP=2977 |title= Air Pollution: Mexico City |date= 2003-07-29 |accessdate=2008-11-25 }}</ref> The altitude, with its low oxygen levels, makes for poor combustion of [[fossil fuel]]s leading to unsafe levels of [[nitrogen oxide]]s, [[hydrocarbons]], and [[carbon monoxide]].<ref name="yip"/> The valley is surrounded by mountain ranges with one small opening to the north. The surrounding mountains and climate patterns here make it difficult to clear out the smog produced.<ref name="thielman"/> The valley has internal wind patterns which circulate around the valley without a prevailing wind to push contaminants in a single direction.<ref name="yip"/> The most significant climatic phenomena here is "thermal inversion," which is prevalent in the winter months when the cooler air of the valley is trapped by relatively warmer air above. Adding to this is that prevailing winds outside the valley move from north to south, in through the Valley's one opening, where incidentally most of the region's industry is located.<ref name="yip"/> These factors diminish in the summer and the situation is helped by the arrival of the rainy season,<ref name="yip"/> but the valley's southern latitude and the abundance of sunlight allows for dangerous levels of [[ozone]] and other dangerous compounds.<ref name="molina"/> [[File:Smog boven mexico city november 1985.jpg|thumb|left|A [[NASA]] satellite image of [[smog]] in the Valley of Mexico in 1985]]
While still considered one of the most polluted places on the planet, the valley's air pollution problems are not as bad as they were several decades ago.<ref name="molina"/> One major problem that was brought under control was the [[lead]] contamination in the air with the introduction of [[Gasoline|unleaded gasoline]]. Two other contaminants that have been brought under control are carbon monoxide and [[sulfur dioxide]].<ref name="molina"/> The contamination problems that remain are primarily with ozone and [[fine particles]] ([[soot]]) (between 2.5 [[micrometer (unit)|micrometers]] and 10 micrometers).<ref name="Barclay"/><ref name="molina"/> Thirty to fifty percent of the time, Mexico City's levels of [[fine particles]] of ten micrometers, the most dangerous, exceed levels recommended by the [[World Health Organization]].<ref name="Barclay"/> In the 1940s, before large-scale burning of fossil fuels in the area, the visibility of the valley was about {{convert|100|km|-1|abbr=on|sp=us}}, allowing for daily viewing of the mountain ranges that surround the valley, including the snow-capped volcanoes of Popocatepetl and Iztaccihuatl. Since that time, the average visibility has come down to about {{convert|1.5|km|ft|-3|abbr=on|sp=us}}. Mountain peaks are now rarely visible from the city itself.<ref name="yip"/> While reduced visibility in the valley was due to sulfur emissions in the past, it is now due to [[fine particles]] in the air.<ref name="thielman"/>
The effects on humans living in an enclosed, contaminated environment have been documented, especially by [[Nobel Prize]] winner Dr [[Mario J. Molina]]. He claims [[fine particles|fine particle]] pollution is the greatest concern because of lung damage.<ref name="molina"/> According to him, the city's residents lose about 2.5 million working days every year due to health problems associated with [[fine particles]].<ref name="Barclay"/>
==Hydrology== The Valley of Mexico is a closed basin which geologically divides into three hydrologic zones, the low plain, which is essentially the bed of now-extinct lakes, the piedmont area and the surrounding mountains. The old lakebeds correspond to the lowest elevations of the valley in the south are mostly clay with a high water content and are almost entirely covered by urban development.<ref name="natresearch"/> In the piedmont area, these clays become mixed with silts and sands, and in some areas close to the mountains, the piedmont is largely composed of [[basalt]] from old lava flows. The valley is enclosed completely by mountain ranges, from which flow rain and melting snow into the valley's hydraulic system. This groundwater flow produces a number of [[Spring (hydrosphere)|springs]] in the foothills and [[upwelling]]s in the valley floor.<ref name="natresearch"/> This underground flow is the source of the five aquifers that provide much of the drinking water to Mexico City located in Soltepec, [[Apan]], [[Texcoco, Mexico State|Texcoco]], [[Chalco de Díaz Covarrubias|Chalco]]-[[Amecameca]] and underneath Mexico City itself.<ref name="lafragua"/>
===Old lake system=== [[File:Lake Chalco 1847.PNG|thumb|right|An 1847 map of [[Lake Xochimilco]] and [[Lake Chalco]]]] Before the 20th century, the Mexico City portion of the valley contained a series of lakes, with saline lakes to the north near the town of Texcoco and freshwater ones to the south.<ref name="natresearch"/> The five lakes, Zumpango, Xaltoca, Xochimilco, Chalco, and the largest, Texcoco used to cover about {{convert|1500|km2|abbr=on|sp=us}} of the basin floor.<ref name="casestudy"/> Small mountains such as the [[Sierra de Guadalupe, Mexico|Sierra de Guadalupe]] and Mount Chiconaultla partially separated the lakes from each other.<ref name="PorruaTezcoco">{{cite book |title= Mexico Diccionario Porrua de Historia, Biografia y Geografia de Mexico-Tezcoco 6th ed. |year=1995 |publisher=Editorial Porrua |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |isbn=968-452-908-2 }}</ref> All the other lakes flowed toward the lower Lake Texcoco, which was saline due to evaporation.<ref name="casestudy"/> The lakes were fed by a number of rivers such as the San Joaquin, San Antonio Abad, Tacubaya, Becerra, Mixcoac and Magdalena Contreras, carrying runoff and snowmelt from the mountains.<ref name="casestudy"/>
Long before the arrival of the Spanish, the lake system had been shrinking due to climate change.<ref name="protocolo">{{cite journal|date=August 2008 |title=Recrean 40 mil años de vida de la Cuenca de México |journal=Revista Protocolo |volume=31 |url=http://www.protocolo.com.mx/articulos.php?id_sec=11&id_art=3146&id_ejemplar=27 |language=Spanish |accessdate=25 November 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Warmer temperatures had increased evaporation and reduced rainfall in the area so that the lakes’ waters were shallow at about five meters (16 ft) deep as early as the Tlapacoya culture, around 10,000 BCE.<ref name="protocolo"/> During the Aztec Empire, the northern lakes were inaccessible by canoe during the dry season from October to May.<ref name="Hamnett"/>
===History of water control in the valley=== For 2000 years, humans have been interfering with and altering the hydraulic conditions of the valley, especially in the lakes region.<ref name="protocolo"/> The Aztecs built [[levee|dikes]] for flood control and to separate the [[saline water]] of the northern lakes from the [[fresh water]] of the southern ones. After the destruction of Tenochtitlan in 1521, the Spaniards rebuilt the Aztec dikes but found they did not offer enough flood protection.<ref name="Montoya">{{cite journal |last=Montoya Rivero |first=Maria Cristina |date=May–June 1999 |title=Del desagüe del Valle de México al drenaje profundo |trans-title=From the drainage of the Valley of Mexico to the complete dessication |journal=Mexico Desconocido |volume=30 |url=http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/notas/3841-Del-desag%FCe-del-Valle-de-M%E9xico-al-drenaje-profundo |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130111223106/http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/notas/3841-Del-desag%FCe-del-Valle-de-M%E9xico-al-drenaje-profundo |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-11 |language=Spanish |accessdate=25 November 2008 }}</ref>
The arrival of the Spanish and subsequent efforts to drain the area for flood control was a major infrastructure project, called the {{lang|es|desagüe}}, was pursued the entire colonial period.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Louisa Schell |last=Hoberman |title=Technological Change in a Traditional Society: The Case of the Desagüe in Colonial Mexico |journal=Technology and Culture |volume=21 |issue=3 |date=July 1980 |pages=386–407 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Richard |last=Boyer |title=La gran inundación: Vida y sociedad en México, 1629–1638 |trans-title=The great flood: Life and society in Mexico 1629–1638 |location=Mexico City |publisher=Sepsetentas |date=1975 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Alain |last=Musset |title=El agua en el valle de México: Siglos XVI–XVIII |trans-title=Water in the Valley of Mexico: 16th–17th centuries |location=Mexico City |publisher=Pórtico-CEMC |year=1992 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Jorge |last=Gurría Lacroix |title=El desagüe del valle de México durante la época novohispana |trans-title=The drainage of the Valley of Mexico in the era of New Spain |location=Mexico City |publisher=[[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] |year=1978 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Vera |last=Candiani |title=The Desagüe Reconsidered: Environmental Dimensions of Class Conflict in Colonial Mexico |journal=Hispanic American Historical Review |volume=92 |issue=1 |year=2012 |pages=5–39 }}</ref>
The idea of opening drainage canals first came about after a flood of the colonial city in 1555. The first canal was begun in 1605 to drain the waters of Lake Zumpango north through [[Huehuetoca]] which would also divert waters from the [[Cuautitlán]] River away from the lakes and toward the [[Tula River]]. This project was undertaken by [[Enrico Martínez]] and he devoted 25 years of his life to it. He did succeed in building a canal in this area, calling it Nochistongo, leading waters to the Tula Valley, but the drainage was not sufficient to avoid the Great Flood of 1629 in the city. Another canal, which would be dubbed the "Grand Canal" was built parallel to the Nochistongo one ending in [[Tequixquiac]]. The Grand Canal consists of one main canal, which measures {{convert|6.5|m|ft|0|sp=us}} in diameter and {{convert|50|km|-1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="PorruaValle ">{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia=Diccionario Porrúa de Historia, Biografia y Geografia de Mexico |edition= 6th. |title=Mexico, Valle de |year=1995 |publisher=Editorial Porrúa |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |isbn=968-452-907-4 |volume=3 |pages=2249–2250 }}</ref> The drainage project was continued after independence, with three secondary canals, built between 1856 and 1867. During the presidency of [[Porfirio Díaz]] (r. 1876–1911) again became a prioirity.<ref>{{cite book |first=Priscilla |last=Connolly |title=El contratista de don Porfirio: Obras públicas, deuda, y desarrollo desigual |trans-title=The contractor of Don Porfirio: Public works, debt, and unequal development |location=Mexico City |publisher=Fondo de Cultura Económica |year=1997 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Manuel |last=Perló Cohen |title=El paradigma porfiriano: Historia del desagüe del Valle de México |trans-title=The Porfirian paradigm: A history of the drainage of the Valley of Mexico |location=Mexico City |publisher=Porrúa |year=1999 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Claudia |last=Agostoni |title=Monuments of Progress: Modernization and Public Health in Mexico City, 1876–1910 |location=Calgary |publisher=[[University of Calgary]] Press |year=2003 }}</ref> Díaz completed it officially in 1894, although work continued thereafter.<ref name="Montoya"/> Despite the Grand Canal's drainage capacity, it did not solve the problem of flooding in the city.
From the beginning of the 20th century, Mexico City began to sink rapidly and pumps needed to be installed in the Grand Canal, which before had drained the valley purely with gravity.<ref name="Montoya"/> Along with the pumps, the Grand Canal was expanded with a new tunnel through the low mountains called the Xalpa to take the canal past [[Tequisquiac]].<ref name="PorruaTezcoco"/> Even so, the city still suffered floods in 1950 and 1951.<ref name="Montoya"/> Despite its age, the Grand Canal can still carry {{convert|2400000|USgal/min|m3/s|-1|lk=on|sp=us}} out of the valley, but this is significantly less than what it could carry as late as 1975 because continued sinking of the city (as much as {{convert|7|m|disp=or|abbr=off}}) weakens the system of water collectors and pumps.<ref name="Montoya"/><ref name="ellingwood">{{cite news |first=Ken |last=Ellingwood |title=Draining the basin that's Mexico City |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/apr/28/world/fg-drain28 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=April 28, 2008 |accessdate=25 November 2008 }}</ref>
As a result, another tunnel, called the [[Emisor Oriente Tunnel|Emisor Central]], was built to carry wastewater. Although it is considered the most important pipe in the country, it has been damaged by overuse and corrosion of its {{convert|20|ft|0|abbr=on|adj=on|sp=us}} diameter walls.<ref name="ellingwood"/> Because of lack of maintenance and gradual decrease in this tunnel's ability to carry water, there is concern that this tunnel will soon fail. It is continuously filled with water, making it impossible to inspect it for problems. If it fails, it would most likely be during the rainy season when it carries the most water, which would cause extensive flooding in the historic center, the airport and the boroughs on the east side.<ref name="Stevenson">{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Stevenson |title=Mexico City Faces Threat of Floods |url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2007Jun19/0,4675,Mexico |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=Fox News |date=2007-06-19 |accessdate=25 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002558/http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2007Jun19/0,4675,Mexico |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref>
Because of this, another new drainage project is planned that will cost $1.3 billion USD. The project includes new pumping stations, a new {{convert|30|mi|-1|sp=us|adj=on}} drainage tunnel and repairs to the current {{convert|7400|mi|-2|sp=us|adj=on}} system of pipes and tunnels to clear blockages and patch leaks.<ref name="ellingwood"/><ref name="tunnel">{{cite news |title=Mexico announces US$1.27 billion drain tunnel |url=http://www.wtopnews.com/?nid=389&sid=1459391 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=August 13, 2008 |accessdate=25 November 2008 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Over-pumping of groundwater in the 20th century has hastened the disappearance of the lakes. The old lake beds are almost all paved<ref name="casestudy"/> except for some canals preserved in Xochimilco, mostly for the benefit of visitors who tour them on brightly painted {{lang|es|trajineras}}, boats similar to [[gondola]]s.<ref name="china">{{cite news |title=Mexico City's 'water monster' nears extinction |url=http://english.sina.com/technology/p/2008/1102/195854.html |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=China Daily |location=Beijing |date=November 2, 2008 |accessdate=25 November 2008 }}</ref>
Desiccation has had a major environmental impact on the Valley of Mexico.<ref>{{cite book |first=Patricia |last=Romero Lankao |title=Obra hidráulica de la ciudad de México y su impacto socioambiental |location=Mexico City |publisher=Instituto Mora |year=1999 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Luis |last=Aboites Aguilar |title=El agua de la nación: Una historia política de México (1888–1946) |trans-title=The nation's water: A political history of Mexico (1888–1946) |location=Mexico City |publisher=Centro de Investigación y Estudios Superiores en Antropología Social |date=1998 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Alejandro Tortolero |last=Villaseñor |title=Tierra, agua, y bosques: Historia y medio ambiente en el México central |trans-title=Earth, water and woodland: An environmental history of Central Mexico |location=Mexico City |publisher=Potrerillos |year=1996 }}</ref>
===Drinking water and sinking lands=== [[File:Angel am ex.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The [[Independence Angel]] statue: street level has sunk below the bottom of the statue.]] {{See also|Water management in Greater Mexico City}} Historically, Mexico City's potable water supply came via aqueduct from the mountain springs on the valley sides like that in Chapultepec as most of the water in Lake Texcoco was saline.<ref name="casestudy"/> These were originally built by the Aztecs and were rebuilt by the Spaniards. In the mid-1850s, potable groundwater was found underneath the city itself, which motivated the large-scale drilling of wells. Today, 70% of Mexico City's water still comes from five principal aquifers in the valley. These aquifers are fed by water from natural springs and runoff from precipitation.
It was only when the population reached about six million that Mexico City started to need to appropriate water from outside the valley.<ref name="casestudy"/> Today, Mexico City faces a serious water deficit. Because of increased demand from a growing population, increasing industry, and ecosystem degradation in the form of deforestation of the surrounding mountains, more water is leaving the system than is entering. It is estimated that {{convert|63|m3/s|USgal/min|sp=us}} of water is needed to support the potable and agricultural irrigation needs of Mexico City's population.<ref name="casestudy"/> The main aquifer is being pumped at a rate of {{convert|55.5|m3/s|USgal/min|abbr=on}}, but is only being replaced at {{convert|28|m3/s|USgal/min|abbr=on}}, or about half of the extraction rate, leaving a shortfall of {{convert|27.5|m3/s|USgal/min|abbr=on}}.<ref name="casestudy"/> This over-extraction of groundwater from the old clay lake bed has been causing the land upon which the city rests to collapse and sink. This problem began in the early 20th century as a consequence of the drainage of the valley for flood control. Since the beginning of the 20th century, some areas of Mexico City have sunk nine meters (30 ft).<ref name="casestudy"/> In 1900, the bottom of the lake was three meters (10 ft) lower than the median level of the city center. By 1974, the lake bottom was two meters (7 ft) higher than the city.<ref name="natresearch"/> The first signs of dropping ground water levels was the drying up of natural springs in the 1930s, which coincides with the beginning of intensive exploitation of the aquifer system through wells between {{convert|100|and|200|m|sp=us}} deep.<ref name="natresearch"/> Today, Mexico City is sinking between five and forty centimeters (0.2 and 1.3 ft) per year, and its effects are visible.<ref name="casestudy"/> [[El Ángel de la Independencia]] ("The Angel of Independence") statue, located on [[Paseo de la Reforma]] was built in 1910, anchored by a foundation deep beneath what was the surface of the street at that time. However, because the street has sunk around it, steps have been added to allow access to the statue's base.<ref name="casestudy"/>
Subsidence of the valley floor beneath has caused flooding problems as now much of the city has sunk below the natural lake floor. Currently, pumps need to work 24 hours a day all year round to keep control of runoff and wastewater.<ref name="casestudy"/> Despite this, flooding is still common, especially in the summer rainy season, in lower-lying neighborhoods such as [[Iztapalapa]], forcing residents to build miniature dikes in front of their houses to prevent heavily polluted rainwater from entering their homes.<ref name="ellingwood"/> Subsidence also causes damage to water and sewer lines, leaving the water distribution system vulnerable to contamination which carries risks to public health.<ref name="natresearch"/> Measures other than drainage have been implemented to contain flooding in the city. In 1950, dikes were built to confine storm runoff.<ref name="natresearch"/> Rivers that run through the city were encapsulated in 1950 and 1951.<ref name="Montoya"/> Rivers such as the Consulado River, Churubusco River and the Remedio River are encased in concrete tunnels which take their waters directly to the drainage system to leave the Valley. Two other rivers, the San Javier and the Tlalnepantla, which used to feed the old lake system, are diverted before they reach the city and their waters now flow directly into the Grand Canal.<ref name="benitez">{{cite book |title= Historia de la Ciudad de Mexico |last=Benitez |first=Fernando |year=1984 |volume= 9 |publisher= SALVAT |location= Mexico City |language= Spanish |isbn= 968-32-0209-8 |pages=46–47}}</ref> None of water from these rivers is allowed to sink into the ground to recharge the aquifer. While the rivers and streams that flow down from the mountain peaks still begin the way they always have, their passage through the shantytowns lacking city sanitation schemes that surround Mexico City turns them into open [[combined sewer]]s. Therefore, their final stages are frequently culverted or added to the existing major culverted rivers to keep this water from contaminating the aquifer.<ref name="benitez"/>

page.title: Vehicle registration plates of Prince Edward Island

revision.comment: Possibly the last time I tidy up this article: Mexico also standardized the size of its license plates at 6" x 12" in 1956
revision.text:
{{Use Canadian English|date=April 2014}} The [[Provinces and territories of Canada|Canadian province]] of [[Prince Edward Island]] first required its residents to register their [[motor vehicle]]s and display [[Vehicle registration plate|licence plate]]s in 1913. ==Passenger baseplates== ===1913 to 1961=== In 1956, Canada, the United States and Mexico came to an agreement with the [[American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators]], the [[Automobile Manufacturers Association]] and the [[National Safety Council]] that standardized the size for licence plates for vehicles (except those for [[motorcycle]]s) at {{convert|6|in|cm}} in height by {{convert|12|in|cm}} in width, with standardized mounting holes.{{cite magazine |last=Garrish |first=Christopher |date=October 2016 |title=Reconsidering the Standard Plate Size |magazine=Plates |publisher=[[Automobile License Plate Collectors Association]] |volume=62 |number=5}} The first Prince Edward Island licence plate that complied with these standards was issued six years beforehand, in 1950. {|class="wikitable" |- !Image !First issued !Description !Slogan !Serial format !Serials issued !Notes |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1916 |Black on white |''none'' |123 |1 to approximately 800 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1919 |Blue on gray |''none'' |1234 |1 to approximately 1000 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1924 |Embossed purple numbers on silver plate with border line; "P.E.I. 1924" at left |''none'' |12-345 |1 to approximately 15-000 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1925 |Embossed red numbers on golden yellow plate with border line; "P.E.I" at left and "1925" at right |''none'' |12-345 |1 to approximately 21-000 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1928 |Embossed silver numbers on green plate with border line; "PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND" at bottom and "1928" at right |"SEED POTATOES FOXES" at left |12-345 |1 to approximately 34-000 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1930 |Embossed green numbers on gold plate with border line; "PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND" at bottom and "1930" at right |"GARDEN OF THE GULF" at left |12-345 |1 to approximately 13-000 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1931 |Embossed white numbers on red plate with border line; "PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND" at bottom and "31" at right |''none'' |12-345 |1 to approximately 16-000 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1932 |Embossed white numbers on olive green plate with border line;
